    \nEpisode I: The Girl From Yesterday (Part 10)

    "I do have to apologize," said Bethany Mae Hampton to Jimmy and Dr. Orange. She tried to collect herself in much the same way as a crowd at a bank run tried to collect its money.

    "What\u2019s going on?" asked Dr. Orange.

    "I don\u2019t know, I don\u2019t know," moaned Bethany. "It\u2019s a real...kerfuffle. I think that lady was up to no good. I think she may have been some kind of investigative reporter," she said, emphasizing the last part in a voice that would have given Dillinger the heebies. "But I will get to the bottom of this, and I fully intend to call the Georgia Bureau of Investigation."

    [Technically formed in March 1937, but I get at least one anachronism per session.]

    "We need to talk about this right now!" said Dr. Orange. "We have some serious questions about what is going on."

    Jimmy noticed that the doctor\u2019s German accent, erratic normally, seemed to suddenly become more pronounced. He took out a small notebook and began scribbling in it, while glaring at Bethany.

    [JP and OP tag-teamed here--Jimmy\u2019s Intimidation use created the circumstances that would allow Dr. Orange to use Interrogate.]

    "Yes, all right, please, right this way to my office," said Bethany nervously. "I wouldn\u2019t want anything to reflect negatively on Dr. Keaton, who is a brilliant man but perhaps not the most capable administrator."

    Bethany\u2019s office was neat and uncluttered, with hardly anything to mark at as a personal office--no family pictures, or books, or even a copy of Life magazine.

    "Now, gentlemen, I\u2019m sure we can all work this out, without any need to notify the authorities in Washington," said Bethany, sitting down behind her desk. Dr. Orange sat down in front of her, while Jimmy remained standing, trying to look menacing. "I think that Miss Fitzgibbons was some kind of agitator, maybe one of those Reds."

    "Do you have anything worth investigating here?" asked Dr. Orange.

    "Not at all. People have all these misconceptions about places like this. Everything is absolutely above-board. If you have any questions, I\u2019m happy to answer them."

    Her desk phone buzzed. Bethany picked it up and swiveled her chair around from Jimmy and Julius. She had a brief whispered conversation, and then swung quickly around and slammed the phone in the cradle. "Gentlemen, something has come up. I trust you can see yourselves out..."

    Jimmy locked the door behind her as she left, and they began to search her office. In the bottom of a desk drawer they found a small doctor\u2019s bag, full of pills and vials of medicine.

    "Wasn\u2019t she just a nurse?" said Dr. Orange.

    Jimmy rifled through the paperwork on the desk. He showed some of it to Dr. Orange, who had experience with bureaucratic organizations. They quickly came to the conclusion that Bethany was really making all the day-to-day decisions at Joy Grove.

    "I\u2019m telling you, Jimmy, she could hide anything she wanted from Keaton."

    "Just what is going on?" muttered Jimmy.



    Geronimo, realizing that their hotel was completely burned as a hideout, insisted that they drive straight to the airfield. Not long after, they were in the air, headed for Chattanooga--getting out the state being the better part of valor, in Ruby\u2019s opinion.

    "How will Jimmy and Dr. Orange find us?" asked Millicent.

    "That\u2019s why he\u2019s a private detective, dear," said Ruby.

    \nEpisode I: The Girl From Yesterday (Part 11)

    Bethany was still hip deep in open files when Jimmy and Dr. Orange slipped out of her office and drove away. They stopped at a drugstore for lunch, and Jimmy flipped through a phone book, and then the city directory, until he found the address for Mrs. Virginia Henslowe.

    "Looks like it\u2019s way out of town," he told Julius.

    Dr. Orange looked at the map. "It looks like it\u2019s in the swamp."

    By late afternoon they were motoring up a narrow dirt lane that became a causeway, crossing a marshy plain full of bogs and small ponds. A brackish, decaying smell surrounded them. Looking at the high water marks, Jimmy realized that when the tide was high enough the Henslowe estate must become an island.

    They pulled through two rotted posts that looked like they may have once been painted white. Beyond them was a classic Georgian style house in a sad state of dilapidation. The grounds around it had long ago reverted to a half-wild clearing, with high grass and saplings of scrub pine growing randomly.

    As they came closer, however, Jimmy and Dr. Orange noticed that some renovations were underway at the house--parts of it had been whitewashed recently, and new glass was in the lower floor windows. A scaffolding obscured part of the second floor.

    A shambling old man with a giant hound of some kind came around a corner of the building and waved them to a stop. "Who a\u2019 hell air you, wha\u2019 you wan\u2019 comin\u2019 roun\u2019 heah, we ain\u2019t got no need of any-un. Lessin\u2019 you wi\u2019 the ressoration people."

    "Yes," said Jimmy. "I\u2019m the architect. This is my assistant."

    "Wha\u2019 evah. I thin\u2019 you-all desroyin\u2019 t\u2019 beauty o\u2019 the house, but come on."

    They parked in front of the porch and got out of the car. The front door opened, and three young women stepped out. They were wearing antebellum dresses complete with hoop skirts, and their hair was elaborately styled in curls and ribbons.

    Jimmy stopped dead. Have I traveled in time? he thought.

    "I think Clark Gable would be dreamy as Rhett," said one of the girls as they walked by, haughtily ignoring Jimmy and the doctor.

    "I think Henry Fonda would be better."

    "Go on. Miss Mitchell said she wrote the part for him..."

    Thank God, thought Jimmy. They\u2019re re-enactors.

    He and the doctor climbed the short stairs to the porch and entered the house. A young woman in modern clothes met them in the entry hall. She had a small sorority pin on her lapel.

    "Can I help you gentlemen? We\u2019re not really open for visitors, we\u2019re still finishing the second floor renovations."

    "I\u2019m one of the architects," said Jimmy. "Some last-minute things to look at..."

    "Regulations and such," said the doctor.

    The woman brightened at the sound of the doctor\u2019s accent. "Oh, you must be here about the Viennese glass. That entire fan window there was all done in Viennese glass, some of it stained in the most beautiful colors. But of course a lot of it was shot out by some damn Yankee during the war."

    "You bought this house?" asked Jimmy.

    "No, Mrs. Henslowe is allowing us to restore it. She\u2019s lived in it her whole life, you know. Almost ninety years! She is just a living treasure."

    "Where is she now?"

    "Just upstairs. I can announce you."

    She gave them a tour as she led them upstairs. The parlor had been completely restored, with authentic pre-war furniture and wallpaper. The second floor was in much worse shape, however, and drop cloths littered with construction materials were scattered around the area. It looked as if one of the bedrooms had collapsed into the first floor.

    In a dingy but habitable sitting room they met Mrs. Henslowe, who sat in a rocking chair, her legs covered in a rug. A scrawny tabby cat sat on her lap and hissed at them as they came in.

    Mrs. Henslowe looked as broken-down as the rest of the house, but with much worse prospects of renewal. Her rheumy eyes squinted under lank strands of grey hair, and her withered hands shook with tremors as she clutched her cat to her. Jimmy was no expert on fashion, but her dress looked at least forty years out of style.

    "That is a lovely dress, and an angelic cat," said Jimmy.

    "Tom here is my friend," said Mrs. Henslowe, patting the cat\u2019s head. "Are you here about the restoration? They\u2019re putting things back the way they were when my daddy built this place. It ain\u2019t never been the same since the war. But you all\u2019s is Yankees, aint\u2019cha? We never did hold much with Yankees down here, but it\u2019s all right I suppose. One of the architects is a Yankee and he seems to care about putting this place back. Did you know my daddy built this place?"

    "I\u2019ve heard," said Dr. Orange.

    "Are you a German fella? I had a German beau back in \u201963. Came in on one of the blockade runners. He was a charming man, a count or a prince or something. Had a Heidelberg dueling scar. He was so handsome! He died though. One of Sherman\u2019s bummers put a bullet in his head. Them was terrible times."

    "Horrible," said Jimmy. "We need to make sure this house is in tip-top shape--"

    "You know my daddy built this place?"

    "--so we want to look at your rooms, and some of the guest rooms, and your son\u2019s room..."

    "Oh Doug? Dougie don\u2019t live here no more, he got a little sick so they sent him to the nervous hospital. He\u2019ll get better soon and then he can come and see the house all put back the way it was."

    "Those hospitals help us with our loved ones," said Jimmy. "And I suppose you kept his room just as he left it?"

    "Dougie hasn\u2019t been here since \u201932. He came back but he didn\u2019t like it outside the hospital anymore, so he went back. I tried to get him to stay here, but he wouldn\u2019t. He didn\u2019t hardly spend no time in his room, though. He was in the library all the time, writing to his friend. Must have been a bad man, because he never wrote Doug back once. \u2018Ceptin I got a big packet of Doug\u2019s letters back a few months ago. Seems his friend up and died and his estate returned them to me. Did you know my daddy built this house? Are you going to help fix it?"

    "Yes ma\u2019am," said Dr. Orange. "We have to go do that now."

    "All right. Well, the library\u2019s mostly restored, my daddy\u2019s books, and Dougie\u2019s books, and the family bible of course. Oh, and we got the record of all the slaves. The historical society is really interested in that."

    "Thank you for all your help, ma\u2019am," said Jimmy. "We\u2019re going to go through all the rooms and take our measurements."

    "All right," said Mrs. Henslowe. "Wait, you all\u2019s a Yankee. I don\u2019t want no damn Yankees in my house! You all better get gone!"

    "Yes ma\u2019am," said Dr. Orange.

    "And you tell that General Sherman not to come around here!"

    "We will, ma\u2019am. The South will rise again."

    "Wilhelm? Is that you?"

    Jimmy and Julius exchanged glances. "Ja?" said Dr. Orange.

    Mrs. Henslowe\u2019s head lowered to her chest and she began to snore.

    \nEpisode I: The Girl From Yesterday (Part 12)

    Doug\u2019s room proved to have been stripped for the restoration. The library was more interesting, if you were planning to start an apocalyptic cult or three over a weekend--it was filled with crumbling codices and the kind of things Aleister Crowley kept around to impress girls.

    One book showed signs of having been used often--Communion Rites of Victorian Death Cults. "Is this important?" says Dr. Orange, holding up the book.

    [Evidence Collection use turned up the book.]

    "That\u2019s the 1912 edition," said Jimmy. "It\u2019s a lot more common than the 1909 edition--that\u2019s worth a lot more. They really watered it down in the second edition, which is why the first is worth more."

    [Occult use by JP to know about the separate editions.]

    In a drawer they found a sheaf of Doug Henslowe\u2019s letters to Walter Winston. They were unusual to say the least--rambling discourses, quotes from the Bible, hand-drawn crossword puzzles and many other scraps of articles and drawings. Some of the letters have pin-pricks, or slight marks in the margins. To Dr. Orange, trained in cryptography during his days in the Reichsbanner, the letters were an obvious attempt at steganography. Well, bad encryption at any rate.

    [Cryptography use by OP.]

    It seemed clear that Winston had the same idea; scratch notes and circled words in the letters show an attempt to figure out coded messages. On one letter Dr. Orange found a frustrated message scribbled by Winston in German: "I know it\u2019s a book code, and I know the book. But it never works."

    Jimmy looked at the copy of Communion Rites of the Victorian Death Cults. Winston, he knew, was pretty wealthy, and interested in the occult. And it hit him.

    "It\u2019s this book," he said. "Winston knew Doug had it, but Winston only had the earlier, more expensive version. The pagination is completely different between them. That\u2019s why it didn\u2019t work."

    Using Doug\u2019s own encryption text, they were soon able to decipher some of the hidden messages. Most of it was pretty mundane records of Edgar Job\u2019s daily activities. But on the last letter in the series, they found Doug\u2019s final message to Winston--two words in Latin:

    CUSTUDIO CUSTODES

    "\u2019I watch the watchers\u2019," muttered Dr. Orange.

    "He went back to the hospital right after that letter," said Jimmy. "But who the hell was he watching? And who were they watching?"



    Doug\u2019s journal, however, was not among his other papers. "Doug said it would be in the last place you\u2019d ever find him," said Jimmy. "Back where it all happened in L. A.? Or...heh. I guess the grave, right?"

    "There\u2019s a cemetery out back," said Dr. Orange, looking through a window.

    Moments later he and Jimmy dashed out the back door of the Henslowe mansion. The cemetery was a small family graveyard, overgrown with weeds and underbrush. Which is probably why nobody had noticed the large tombstone with DOUGLAS HENSLOWE written on it.

    "Surprising," said Jimmy. "Doug\u2019s a bit dark." He looked up at the sky. "Getting near sundown."

    "I think we need to pick up some supplies," said Dr. Orange.

    They swung by their hotel, and then a hardware store to get picks and shovels and flashlights. Jimmy grabbed a map of Georgia so they could drive up to Chattanooga when they were done on the Henslowe grounds.

    It began to rain, lightly at first and then hard enough to beat Noah. Large drops rain pelted their car as they cautiously drove up to the Henslowe place, headlights off. They slipped through the gate and saw Carruthers the groundskeeper dragging his enormous hound along with him, holding a burning torch in the other hand.

    "Com\u2019 on less ge\u2019 in th\u2019 hut. Cool\u2019n off n\u2019 we cain warmup a lille," he said incomprehensibly.

    Jimmy and Dr. Orange waited for him to disappear into his shack. They raced as fast as they could through the slippery, bottomless red mud to the cemetery and began digging--well, sluicing--in Doug\u2019s grave. After a few hours, they found a small tin box, sealed along the edges with wax.

    [Me: I\u2019d tell you to knock off some Athletics, but it will just refresh the next day and there\u2019s no real danger here. (In game terms, you could call this a Simple Search.)]

    Something rattled inside the tin, like a rock.

    "Let\u2019s go," said Jimmy.

    They made their way back to the car and were soon heading north. They drove for a while and then took a brief, damp rest off the side of the road. Two days later they pulled into a hotel in Chattanooga. Down in the saloon, they heard a familiar voice:

    "There I was, a brute coming at me, on the movie set! Eyes of flame--"

    They compared notes:

    Millicent has been dutifully going through the files she liberated from Joy Grove. The first thing she found out was that the money to pay for Edgar Job\u2019s treatment at Joy Grove had run out by 1933, and he was scheduled to be sent back to California. At the last minute, however, a private individual stepped in to provide the necessary funding: Douglas Henslowe.

    She also found the full transcript of Doug and Edgar\u2019s unmedicated confrontation therapy session. For the most part it conformed with Dr. Keaton\u2019s recounting of the story, except that he left out an interesting detail: after Job started shouting at Henslowe--"You tried to kill me but I\u2019m still here!"--Henslowe very quietly said, "If I wanted you dead, Edgar, you\u2019d be dead already."

    Douglas Henslowe readmitted himself in 1933. His first attempt to do so resulted in an examination by Dr. Keaton that concluded there was no need for further treatment. A few months later, he was re-examined, and this time proved to be a textbook case of paranoid schizophrenia. In fact, looking over his symptoms show that they somewhat suspiciously resemble the standard diagnostic checklist.

    There were interesting fragments of notes from Dr. Keaton showing how he became intrigued by Edgar Job\u2019s case--snatches of things Doug said in therapy, mostly, like, "He killed Vince, how could a little nobody like that kill Vince Stack? Stack killed that bastard Echevarria, blew his head off with a shotgun."

    The prescription schedules for both Job and Henslowe were all in Bethany Mae Hampton\u2019s handwriting. Some of the notations looked like it was Bethany who was making the actual diagnostic decisions, and just getting Dr. Keaton\u2019s initials. Geronimo, who had some medical training in Spain, confirmed that the medication decisions are in keeping with ordinary practice, but a nurse/administrator making those decisions was highly unusual.

    Helen Taylor was committed by her family on the counsel of her faculty advisor, Patricia Evans, who also seeme to have made the recommendation to use Joy Grove. Millicent was slightly acquainted with Miss Evans, who was also the faculty advisor for the Epsilon Sigma sorority; they\u2019d asked her several times to pledge them.

    Helen\u2019s diagnostic file contained a lot of notes on her age and physical condition, including approval to begin testing to see if she was a "potential". Whatever the strange drug they were giving Helen was not recorded in the file.

    "It\u2019s something that makes all the people there want to...you know," said Millicent.

    "No I don\u2019t," said Jimmy.

    "Well, you must have done it..."

    "Eat? Drink? Sleep?" said Dr. Orange.

    "Go to a movie?" said Jimmy.

    "Relax?" said Ruby.

    "Yes, they\u2019re very relaxed," said Millicent, blushing.

    "Oh, it\u2019s probably a depressant then."

    "Not that kind of relaxed. The...other kind of relaxed. Like a person who relaxes all your tension..."

    "Oh, a masseuse. Or a muscle relaxant?"

    "No, the thing the psychiatrists are always talking about."

    "Father issues?" said Ruby.

    "The brain?" said Dr. Orange.

    "Freud?" said Jimmy.

    "But what is the father issue everyone has?" said Millicent, blushing even more.

    "They hit them?" said Ruby.

    "Daddy doesn\u2019t like what I do for a living?" said Dr. Orange.

    "They\u2019re putting more than one person in a cell...to work out their...tension..."

    "I think the young lady is referring to coitus," said Geronimo drily.

    "They had her in a cell alone but she wanted me to come in there and be relaxed with her and then she gave me some to take back to school to relax other people which I really don\u2019t think would be a good idea," said Millicent breathlessly.

    "She gave you some relaxing agent?" said Ruby.

    "Yeah, so maybe we could take a look at it?"

    "Oh, I think we should take a look at it, yes," said Ruby, sitting forward.

    "No, ma\u2019am," said Geronimo.

    "Her family doesn\u2019t know because they didn\u2019t want me reporting back to them, but twenty is too old for the person they are looking for."

    "They\u2019re looking for someone?" said Jimmy sharply.

    "Yeah, but they\u2019re also testing it on other people. She needs to get out of there."

    "I\u2019ll make some calls," said Jimmy.



    A few days later Jimmy\u2019s friend from the Bureau called him back. "We talked to the Atlanta field office and had them pull Miss Hampton\u2019s records. Everything seemed to be in order, but you were gosh-darn so insistent, I ran her prints. That ain\u2019t her name."

    "Color me surprised."
    \t.
    "The name we got for her is Anne Robinson. Graduated Princeton in \u201928 with a M. D. She started a psychiatric residency but never finished it. Then she just drops off the books for a while, until she\u2019s at Joy Grove as Bethany Mae Hampton. Seems she\u2019s from upstate New York originally. I put a call in to Joy Grove, but they said she quit a few days ago."

    "I guess something must have happened at the asylum."

    "Anyway, you owe me a steak."



    Ruby called up some of the society reporters who haunt her steps and put a few blind items out about corruption at a Savannah country-club type mental hospital.

    They gathered together to open the box. The wax peeled and flaked off as Jimmy forced open the box. Inside he found a rock fragment with symbols carved in it, most prominently a three-lobed eye.

    Jimmy gulped.

    "Oh, I know that symbol, it\u2019s from the Axum Empire in ancient Ethiopia. It blocks spying spells and mystical surveillance. My psychic uses it as her doormat pattern," said Ruby.

    [1-pt Occult Spend by RP.]

    Beneath the stone was a note from Doug to Walter Winston:\n
    I have destroyed the notes I took of our investigation, after compiling what I saw and remembered into this notebook. The stone you may recognize from the barn that night; I think it was E\u2019s. I know the Thing watches me. I think it could hurt me if it wanted to. I put our materials in a safety deposit box in the First Bank of Long Beach. The key is here. Use it wisely. I know you will.

    Don\u2019t come for me. I don\u2019t think I have it in anymore me to do the work. I don\u2019t trust myself anymore, except to watch.

    Custudio Custodes

    Doug
    \nAnd beneath that they found a notebook wrapped in plastic. A small safety-deposit key was tucked inside the cover.

    Jimmy flipped open some pages. He immediately found a horrific, lurid image of toothed tentacles tearing bodies to pieces. He slammed the book shut and put it back in the box.

    "Nobody read that book right now," he said.



    Later that night, however, Millicent snuck the box into her hotel bed and read the book beneath the covers. The bizarre, at times incoherent notes--since Doug assumed Walter would read it, he left things out or made shorthanded references to events--slowly painted a picture.

    Winston and his friends were investigating an apocalyptic cult in Los Angeles led by a man named Ramon Echevarria, a local if relatively anonymous big-shot. In late 1925 they became convinced that Echevarria was going to start a ritual that had a chance to destroy the world. They decided to put an end to the cult. Millicent noted that Doug gradually became as convinced as Winston and Dr. Kullman that the threat was real.

    Winston and his circle attacked the cult; Vince Stack killed Echevarria, but then something terrible happened. "The Thing came out of the barn," Doug wrote. "The Thing with the Mouths, the Thing that devours. And it killed so many people. It killed Kathy, it killed the doc, and I ran and I ran and I ran. And days later I found you, Walt. But since then I can\u2019t sleep."

    The book ended with a postscript from Doug: "I couldn\u2019t take it anymore, so I went for a rest. Now I\u2019ve found out they\u2019re moving Edgar Job here permanently, and I knew I had to watch him. So I\u2019m going back into the asylum. Because I know that he\u2019s important, and I know they\u2019re still looking for him. ALWAYS KEEP THIS ROCK NEAR THE BOOK."

    Millicent discovered that she couldn\u2019t sleep either. It sounded like Doug\u2019s paranoid ideation, but...there\u2019s a compelling power to his illustrations, and she couldn\u2019t shake the images. And...the idea that so many intelligent people could become convinced that there was a real threat from a ritual, that somehow magic was involved and could work...

    She shuddered with sudden pain and terror, feeling completely alone.

    [+1 Cthulhu Mythos for reading the book.]



    By the time her call to Vanessa Brady went through it was after midnight in Venice, California. "You know you shouldn\u2019t call me," said Vanessa over the crackling long-distance lines.

    "I found Helen. They were doing things to her that they shouldn\u2019t. But then they said she wasn\u2019t the one they were looking for, and asked me my age. I lied and said I was twenty, and they said I was too old. So I\u2019m thinking maybe I needed to call."

    "Is Jimmy there with you? Good. Listen to me very, very carefully. If anything goes wrong, you go to Jimmy. You don\u2019t tell him anything, but you go to him."

    "Are you okay?"

    "I\u2019ll be fine. I\u2019ll talk to Freddie, I\u2019ll talk to Bradley. We\u2019ll get Helen out."

    \nEpisode I: The Girl From Yesterday (Part 15)

    Los Angeles was rainy and dreary when they returned. Ruby and Geronimo returned her split-level in Beverly hills. Dead leaves drifted listlessly on the surface of the swimming pool. Smog the color of cigarette smoke oppressed the entire neighborhood.

    Dr. Orange went back to Caltech. His friend Max Born seemed more harassed than usual, although of course neither of them could talk about the projects they were working on. Julius buried himself in some cloud traces made by the grad students of his irregularly-taught seminar, to catch himself back up on his theoretical works. He got his monthly letters from Dr. Goddard--enthusiastic--and Dr. von Braun--guarded.

    Geronimo reviewed the reports of the staff--Luz the maid, Francine the cook, William the butler. All seemed in order, but something bothered him. Long experience working against the Fascists in Spain had taught him to trust those feelings.

    A few nights later he knocked on Ruby\u2019s door. Miss Fitzgibbons was wearing a barely-there froth of lace and satin. On the bed behind her a tanned man who probably had a side business posing for Michelangelo covered himself hastily in a sheet.

    "Do you have a moment to talk? I have something very important to tell you," said Geronimo, unperturbed.

    "Only a moment," said Ruby grouchily.

    "Tr\xe8s vite, ma petite chou," said the man as Ruby closed the door.

    "I don\u2019t even know what he says," sighed Ruby. "But isn\u2019t Andr\xe9 gorgeous?"

    "I have observed the same car parked outside the house on multiple occasions, as well as suspicious passers-by. I believe the house is being watched, and not by paparazzi. This is professional, a mob most likely."

    "We have that cabin up by Lake Arrowhead," said Ruby. "We can head up there."

    "We\u2019ll have the groundskeeper drive away from the house, and then cut through the backyard to meet him a few blocks away. That should throw them off our trail."

    "Let me just take a moment to pack my things."

    "We have to leave quickly, and without your usual accoutrements. Don\u2019t tell anyone where we are going."

    "Well, I\u2019ll let Jimmy know we\u2019re leaving on knife related reasons."

    Geronimo shook his head sadly and went to make arrangements.

    Despite Ruby\u2019s rather expansive definition of traveling light (two suitcases, a hatbox, and her large makeup bag), their escape went off without a hitch. However, on the long drive up, Geronimo couldn\u2019t shake the feeling that they were being followed. He could never catch their tail, but he was pretty sure one was there. Whoever it was, they were very, very good.

    [Piggybacking stealthless Ruby caused GP\u2019s Stealth roll to fail, and then a Sense Trouble roll vs. the Stealth modifier of their tail also failed.]



    On a brilliant sunny day--the first in a week--Janet Rogers came by Jimmy\u2019s office. She found Millicent sitting with Jimmy, doing some homework. Stacks of papers, some with official Los Angeles city seals on them, were piled on Jimmy\u2019s desk.

    "Hello Millicent," said Janet. "Well, Jimmy, did you find out anything?"

    "Quite a bit. I don\u2019t know if it\u2019s the kind of story you want to be publishing."

    "Was this Winston fellow up to something? Did you meet Henslowe? Did you meet Job?"

    "I met them. Have you ever met Henslowe before?"

    "Yes," said Janet after a pause. "Once or twice."

    "He wanted to know who was asking about him."

    "That stands to reason..."

    "But I said I was working for a her, and he came to a conclusion about who that was right away. I have this feeling that he thought it was you. Did you contact him about the story?"

    "No. I haven\u2019t had any contact with Henslowe in years."

    "Come on, Janet."

    "No! I didn\u2019t call him about this story. I told you I wanted this all under the table, but now it looks like you\u2019ve involved me."

    Jimmy could tell that Janet was evading him about how she knew Doug Henslowe. He reflected for a moment that she hadn\u2019t resumed her maiden name, Edelmann, after divorcing her husband.

    "If this comes up again, you have to let me know," he said. "This could be dangerous. Very dangerous."

    "You think there was more to it? Was Winston up to something important?"

    "The problem is that most of what we know came from the crazy book Doug wrote," said Millicent.

    "What crazy book?" said Janet.

    "His journal."

    "If Doug is crazy, maybe there\u2019s nothing to this..."

    "He\u2019s not as crazy as people think," said Millicent.

    "It\u2019s crazy in my sidework investigation way," said Jimmy. "Have you heard of a guy named Ramon Echevarria?" He pronounced it the Spanish way, rolling the r\u2019s and stressing the i.

    "That was one of the people who died in that thing in the Valley," said Janet. "Along with all of Walter\u2019s friends, except Doug. Was Walter there?"

    "Doug\u2019s book said he was," said Millicent. "He thought Echevarr'a was doing some ritual--"

    "Careful, now," said Jimmy.

    "Didn\u2019t I hire you to tell me what you know?" demanded Janet.

    "I will. Gently. Not all at once. I worry," said Jimmy. "We\u2019re going to look into this Echevarria and his group."

    "His group?" Janet was taken back. "I have to go think about this. I want you to keep looking into this...I haven\u2019t decided what to write about, yet, if I write about anything. But keep looking."

    Jimmy thought he felt her trembling ever so slightly as he helped her into her coat. But that was the only sign anything had gotten to her.

    "Vince Stack. Dr. Kullman. Katherine Clark," J. J., one of Jimmy\u2019s top operatives said, slapping some photographs down on Jimmy\u2019s desk a few days after the meeting with Janet. "Boss, you picked a winner here. This guy Stack. Well-known New York PI, came out to L. A., paid his respects to the local cops. Might have been private, but not so much an investigator. More a lead pipe to the head, shotgun in the face kind of guy."

    "So like the O\u2019Donnell part of our company."

    "I don\u2019t wanna say nothing against Mr. Frank. Cause he\u2019d kill me. Stack\u2019s probably the one who did Echevarria, he was found near a trench-cleaner from the war. Stack was known to use a gun like that from his time overseas."

    Jimmy grunted and picked up Katherine Clark\u2019s picture.

    "Clark was a photographer, went to Columbia--that\u2019s how she knew Winston, he taught there," continued J. J. "Boss, that one is not so good. She was found with her head removed. Official report is that she was found torn apart by animals. D. A.\u2019s office is giving me the bum\u2019s rush on this, nobody there wants to say nothing about it."

    "Cold shoulder?"

    "Ice cold, boss. This guy Kullman? Taught psychology at Columbia, that\u2019s how he knew Winston. They were good friends. They were supposed to be working on stuff together, an opera or something. Kullman had a major interest in the occult and parapsychology. Anyway, he was found near his wheelchair--he was in a chair most of his life--looks like he was trying to crawl back into the car when he died. Again, attacked by \u2018wild animals\u2019. Stack, though, he was found stabbed, some skel named Edgar Job took the rap on that. Weird case. The sheriff\u2019s pulled up to the place, way out in the valley--it\u2019s all Okies now. Found the barn on fire, bunch of dead bodies. Most were never really identified. Couple of days later, Job comes wandering onto some farm, says he killed a guy and wants to be arrested. State found him too nuts for prison, put him in an asylum. Sheriff\u2019s boys think there were other survivors, they found bloody footprints in the area."

    "Got anything else on Echevarr\xeda?"

    "Not really. Police file assumes he must have been some kind of preacher. Owned a house, some other family lives there now, nothing linking them back. I found one lead--he was buddies with a guy named George Ayers, an egghead from UCLA. But that guy\u2019s been missing since 1926. If it makes you feel better, that\u2019s on a account he went to Ethiopia before all this happened out in the valley and never came back. Officially he\u2019s \u2018missing\u2019. And that\u2019s all we got."



    Millicent spent her last few days in Los Angeles haunting various libraries, hunting up details on Echevarria. He had been a Mexican national, a real-estate mogul with a lot of famous friends but one who somehow had managed to keep himself out of public view. She was able to fix a date for when he died: the night of January 13-14, 1926. The same night as the L. A. blackout, caused by lightening striking a power distribution substation in the Valley.

    Coincidentally, it was near the farm that Echevarria died on.

    Walter Winston was much better represented. He had been fairly well-known for his highbrow and avant-garde music--a concerto for orchestra, a chamber opera, a few eclectic string quartets--but had made his money writing film scores during the silent era, as well as a few popular songs that he ghosted for singers who wanted to look more musical than they were.

    Before immigrating to America, he had studied at a conservatory in Geneva, Switzerland. During this time he had been a fairly ordinary Late Romantic composer--something like an early Arnold Sch\xf6nberg. Right before he left Geneva, however, his musical changed radically, exploring new and unusual harmonies. Many reviewers and musicologists had praised the haunting, disturbing sound his music attained during this period.

    At his death he had still not finished the cello concerto he had been working on for almost thirty years; little about it was known, but someone who had seen the title page claimed that it was dedicated to an "Erich Z."

    [I didn\u2019t make this explicit in session, but yes, this was a reference to Lovecraft\u2019s "The Music of Erich Zann."]

    He had been a widower when he died, having married a woman named Karen Edelmann when he first came to America. He was survived by their only child, a daughter named Janet. Reading between the lines, Millicent concluded that Winston and his daughter weren\u2019t close.

    \nEpisode I: The Girl From Yesterday (Part 17)

    Dr. Orange decided to look into the sample of the drug Millicent found in Joy Grove. His chemistry was a bit rusty, but certainly good enough, he thought, to get some specific gravities and maybe some stains for different chemicals. He grabbed a workstation at the end of the day from a chemist heading home.

    "Here to do some real science, eh Doc?" he said good-naturedly to Julius. "Have a good night."

    The results were fascinating. There was something chaotic about them--the same tests could produce different results even under identical conditions--but at the same time they pointed to some larger pattern, something he could vaguely discern the outlines of even if the details seemed impossibly complex. The drug itself seemed to have more characteristics than he could have expected; each test revealed some further nuance he needed to explore, and each exploration revealed more avenues of investigation.

    He was headed to the x-ray crystallography lab when he noticed some of the chemists arriving for work. He frowned for a moment; it seemed only a few minutes ago that he had looked up at the clock and saw it was midnight. Then he shrugged. It didn\u2019t matter! This chemical might give him insight into the building blocks of life itself!

    [I made this a Hard Driver against the doc\u2019s Thirst for Knowledge drive. The properties of the drug make that drive particularly susceptible...]

    When he came back to his station, Clyde, the chemist, stared at him. "Um, doc? You okay? You haven\u2019t changed. Or shaved."

    "It\u2019s fine, fine. It\u2019s a new look. I still need this station. Go use Henry\u2019s, he\u2019s at a grant thing at UCLA."

    The atomic structure of the molecule was impossible, but yet he had the plates showing it in his hands. Incredible! Amazing! He could tell that he was on the verge of perhaps the most exciting scientific breakthrough of the century! Maybe any century! This would make splitting the atom look like discovering fire!

    The next thing he knew, Clyde was shaking his arm. "Doc? You all right? You\u2019ve been there for four hours. When was the last time you ate?"

    "This morning. I\u2019m fine, I\u2019m fine."

    [TN 4 Health Test for the doc to stay conscious here--he hasn\u2019t eaten in 24 hours at this point, or slept. I was also draining away Stability; by this point he had lost 2 points of Stability studying the drug.]

    Rayon? Nylon? Nothing compared to this! When he was done studying this substance, Dr. Orange would be able to spin silk out of air, and make...transparent aluminum! Why not! This was the chemical breakthrough of an age!

    Clyde shook him by the shoulder again. "Doc? It\u2019s closing time...I\u2019m going to need my station back tomorrow, Henry will be in then. Uh...you do know you\u2019ve used about half our monthly budget of chemical tests, right? I\u2019m going to need to bill the Applied Division..."

    "Fine, fine. Tomorrow."

    He was halfway through another series of fascinating pH tests when Dr. Born arrived, greeting him in German. "Julius, are you all right?"

    "Fine. Who? What?"

    "Dr. Ruthven told me you\u2019d been here since last night...you look terrible."

    "That\u2019s not very nice! Leave me alone."

    "You look like you did when we were sneaking out into Holland. I know what you look like when you haven\u2019t eaten for a couple of days!"

    "I ate an hour ago."

    "Julius, what time is it? Don\u2019t look at the clock, just tell me what you think the time is."

    "Uh...late, but not late late? Early late?"

    "Why don\u2019t we have a drink," said Dr. Born. "Just come over and we\u2019ll have a drink, and then you can go back to work. Just a quick snifter of brandy."

    "Fine," said Dr. Orange. He took a last longing look at the chemistry station and went to Dr. Born\u2019s office, where he gulped down a small glass of cognac...

    He woke up in his apartment the next morning, done in by exhaustion more than the drink. Dr. Born brought him a cup of coffee.

    "Julius," he said, "I\u2019m very worried about you. You worked yourself to the edge of exhaustion. I looked at your notes and they don\u2019t make any sense. The first fifty or sixty pages I could mostly follow...but the next hundred pages are complete nonsense. After that your notes just trail off into an odd scrawl with dots on the page. And what looks like Sanskrit. Whatever you were looking at, I\u2019m not sure you should continue this line of research."

    "But why! Why should I stop! It\u2019s amazing!"

    "I\u2019ll admit I am curious to find out what you were doing. It\u2019s not completely...alien...to some of my own researches. I think you should take the rest of the day off. Is there anyone you\u2019d like to talk to? I can take the rest of the day off myself. We\u2019re doing the static testing for the...I can\u2019t really talk about it."

    "Don\u2019t worry, everything\u2019s fine. I can\u2019t wait to get back to work."

    "Julius, I really don\u2019t think that\u2019s a good idea."

    "But why? Isn\u2019t this what we\u2019re here for?"

    "Well, that\u2019s true...perhaps we should investigate it together. That way we can keep ourselves on track. Get some more rest and I\u2019ll make breakfast."

    [So out of kindness I threw Julius\u2019 Solace at him to get him out of this mess, but awesomely OP convinced Dr. Born to follow him down the rabbit hole...]

    \nEpisode I: The Girl From Yesterday (Part 18)

    The following night, Jimmy\u2019s office transferred a call to his apartment. "Mr. Wright? This is a courtesy call from the Pasadena PD. We got a couple of mad scientist types down here in the drunk tank. Apparently they had to be evicted from the Caltech lab. They were there all night, looks like they broke into a supply closet and tripped an alarm. When we got there they looked kind of out of it, so we threw \u2018em in the tank until we could figure out what to do. One of them had your card, so we gave your office a ring."

    "Is one of them named Julius?"

    "Yeah, Julius Orange."

    "I\u2019ll be right there."

    Betty picked him up at his apartment building. "So when are you going to give me that job, Mr. J?" she asked as they rushed towards Pasadena.

    "You study those books I sent you?"

    "Yup! Well, I mean the new Black Mask magazine came out, so I\u2019m a bit behind..."

    As soon as he got to the police station, some cops led him to the holding cells. They were nervous for cops. It struck Jimmy as strange and even a bit obscene, like a naked judge. Julius and Max were pacing back and forth, gesticulating and speaking to each other in rapid-fire bursts:

    "So the chemical structure--"

    "Yes, yes! On an atomic level--"

    "The ringstrassenuntergegangenheit..."

    "Julius!" said Jimmy.

    "Not now!"

    "Wait, was that you?" asked Dr. Born.

    "I thought it was you!"

    "I think that man was talking to you."

    "Julius," said Jimmy, "you\u2019re in jail."

    "Aren\u2019t we all in jail? It doesn\u2019t matter!" said Dr. Orange.

    "Why did you break into a chemical lab?"

    "We didn\u2019t have the keys, so we used a fire axe," said Julius. "It\u2019s all right, we wrote down everything we took."

    "Wait, did you write it down?" said Max.

    "I thought you did!"

    "It doesn\u2019t matter! When we make our first billion off the chemical, we\u2019ll pay it back. We\u2019ll pay them all back!"

    "I\u2019ll take care of them," said Jimmy to the police. With visible relief, the cops helped herd the two Germans down Jimmy\u2019s car.

    "Are we going back to the lab?" asked Max.

    "We must! We were so close to the breakthrough!" said Julius.

    "I have come to a realization, Julius. This chemical, it must be alive. Call me crazy--"

    "You\u2019re crazy!"

    "Thank you! I think it\u2019s intelligent! A new form of chemical intelligence."

    "Take us up to Ruby\u2019s cabin," said Jimmy to Betty. He opened the door and pushed Dr. Born into the back seat. Max slid over, opened the opposite door, and jumped outside. He started to run in the direction of Caltech.

    Jimmy slid over the hood of the car and pounced on Born. "Run, Julius, run!" shouted the scientist. "Finish our work!"

    Jimmy broke out a set of handcuffs and cuffed Born and Orange together. During the ride up to Arrowhead they both struggled against their restraints in a more and more agitated fashion.

    "I could get back to work! If I only didn\u2019t have this useless hand!" shouted Julius, straining his wrist against the handcuff.

    "Conic sections! Conic sections!" cried Born.

    Fortunately, they both passed out from exhaustion long before they reached Ruby\u2019s cabin. Geronimo helped Jimmy carry the Germans into the house when they got there. Ruby provided some restraints to tie the scientists to their beds, in case they became agitated again. (Jimmy looked askance at Geronimo, who merely rolled his eyes.)

    Geronimo told him that he was worried he and Ruby had been followed up to Lake Arrowhead, so Jimmy grabbed a flashlight and took a turn around the cabin grounds. What he found disturbed him--broken branches here and there, cigarette butts no more than a day or so old, a greasy sandwich wrapper. All the sorry detritus of long hours spent watching and waiting.

    There were a number of locations in the woods, he noticed, where somebody would have an absolute peach of a shot at the cabin. And anyone inside it.



    And let\u2019s leave them all there. I like to think of Jimmy like that--deep in thought, silhouetted against the pink sky of early dawn, that familiar worry already crawling down his stomach. What were you thinking, Jimmy? Was it, it can\u2019t be, or not again?

    And inside the house, poor raving Doc Orange, brain reeling with revelation and trying to swim against an impossible tide, not willing to concede the fight, like a man who will drown because he won\u2019t take off his shoes.

    Look at Geronimo, still tough, used to being hunted but weary of it all, having to deal with Ruby and a couple of mad scientists and worrying just a bit at how much this was going to take out of him.

    And of course darling Ruby, blissfully asleep, afloat on dreams of pleasure and sailing unaffected above all the troubles.

    She had no idea what was coming.

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 1)

    Sunlight streamed into Ruby\u2019s cabin, clean mountain sunlight unfiltered by the fog and filth of Los Angeles. Jimmy closed the curtains. He didn\u2019t want anyone shooting in. And the work they were doing was anything but clean. Nothing that you wanted out in the sunlight.

    In a guest bedroom, Dr. Orange woke up. His arms were tied to the bedposts, leaving him trussed in an uncomfortable position that reminded him of his interrogation training classes. He began to shout.

    "What am I doing here?" he demanded when Jimmy came into the bedroom. "Why am I here? How come I\u2019m tied the bed? Why are these restraints so seductively comfortable? Where\u2019s Max? Is he working on it? Let me go!"

    "Relax," said Jimmy. "You need your rest."

    A disheveled Ruby, in her peignoir, stepped into the room. She threw a glass of water in Julius\u2019 face. "You will calm down. You will not wake up anyone else. You will get back to your work later."

    "I\u2019m wet," sputtered Julius, "and restrained, and I can\u2019t do my work."

    "Julius," said Ruby. "Look at my necklace." She dangled her ruby necklace in the early morning light. It sparkled with the seduction of wealth. "Good\u2026good\u2026calm down."

    [Hypnosis! Use by Ruby. She then tried to implant a post-hypnotic suggestion.]

    Dr. Orange began to breathe easier. Ruby poked through his things and pulled out one of his fountain pens. "Julius," she whispered in his ear, "I need you to forget all about what you were working on. Whenever you feel like you need to return to it, I want you to clutch this pen. All right? Just put it all out of your mind."

    Slowly she brought him out of the trance. "What happened?" said Julius. "Why am I here? What have I been doing? I was working on something\u2026something Max brought me. I got sucked into it, I guess."

    [Oops! RP blew the roll for the post-hypnotic suggestion, so we twisted it to mean that Dr. Orange didn\u2019t develop a compulsion against researching the drug, but just forgot what he was working on completely. This keeps him from getting sucked in again, but on the other hand it didn\u2019t reset the Stability clock\u2014the next time he researches the drug, it\u2019s an automatic 3 point Stability loss\u2026]



    Jimmy and Geronimo had just sat down to coffee when two black cars pulled up in front of Ruby\u2019s cabin. I\u2019ve been saying cabin, but ranch house would be closer, complete with the usual dude accoutrements\u2014a saddle with no horse to ride on, brands burned into the ceiling beams that no cattle had ever worn, rawhide thongs that nobody had ever figured out a use for.

    Two men in black suits, the sour odor of government service practically visible on them, stepped out, accompanied by a pair of MPs in Sam Brownes and puttees. Bringing up the rear was the local constable, a paunchy old-timer wearing a Stetson and a hogleg Colt pistol. He looked old enough to owe Wyatt Earp some money, and tough enough to spit in his eye when he paid it.

    "Secret service," flashed one of the Feds when Geronimo answered the door. "We\u2019re looking for Doctors Born and Orange."

    "\xbfQuien?"

    "I don\u2019t speak Mex."

    "Do you have a warrant? This is a private house."

    "Listen, [racial slur], I don\u2019t need a warrant to get the docs. But we do have a warrant. A warrant for the arrest of James Wright. The constable here is going to serve it."

    Ruby emerged, immaculately dressed in the latest sportswear. She was noticeably not wearing a brassiere. "Gentlemen, is there a problem?"

    "No problem, ma\u2019am," said the agent not wearing a wedding ring. "We\u2019re here for Dr. Born and Orange. We\u2019re not taking them into custody, we\u2019re just taking them back to work. Hush-hush government stuff."

    "Did they not finish their paperwork?"

    "I\u2019m sure they didn\u2019t. You know those kraut types."

    "Well, sit down, I\u2019ll get you some coffee\u2026you look like you\u2019ve been working the night shift\u2026"

    [Flattery (sigh) 1-point spend by RP which kept the Secret Service from grabbing everyone with extreme prejudice; since they were more interested in Born, the spend let Julius stay at the cabin.]

    A pot of coffee later, Max was escorted into the back of a car by the agents, who agreed they didn\u2019t have to take Dr. Orange back with them. Julius walked him out.

    "Hey, doc, a word with you," said one of the agents. He put his back to the cabin as the MPs closed in to screen them from view. His fist smashed into Julius\u2019 stomach. The world seemed to whirl and sit down on Julius\u2019 chest, and he collapsed to the ground coughing. White flashes of pain sparkled in his eyes.

    "You do not mess with Dr. Born, you understand? You screw up his work again, and you\u2019re going back to Germany."

    Julius nodded his head weakly. The Feds got in the car and backed away. One waved at Julius with a smirk as they turned the cars around and drove off. He got into a crouch and was sick behind a bush.



    Jimmy walked Patton, the constable, back to the car. "Good to see you again, Mr. Wright," Patton said. "Sorry about this mixup."

    "Don\u2019t worry. And good luck with the campaign."

    "Thank you, you\u2019ve been very generous. I hope to see you again soon."

    Ruby looked at Jimmy with surprise. "Law enforcement is a very small community," Jimmy said. "Jim Patton and I go way back."

    [JP spent a point of Credit Rating to make the constable a contact. This is the first of many Chandler references in this episode.]

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 2)

    It was another beautiful day in Los Angeles as they drove back down the mountains, by which is generally meant that the smog was only light brown. Jimmy went to his office and cycled through his messages. He planned to call some of his people downtown to see if he could track down the police report from the 1926 massacre.

    His intercom buzzed. "A Mrs. Regan to see you," said his secretary.

    The double doors opened and a woman came in. She was tall and rangy and strong-looking. Her hair was black and wiry and parted in the middle and she had hot black eyes. She had a good mouth and a good chin. There was a sulky droop to her lips and the lower lip was full. She reminded Jimmy of Janet Rogers, somehow.

    "Mr. Wright, I\u2019m Vivian Regan. Vivian Sternwood Regan, I should say."

    "You\u2019re the daughter of General Sternwood," said Jimmy as they sat down on his office couch. "The one with the oil wells."

    "I was hoping you could help me\u2026people have recommended you to me, because you operate in a discreet fashion. It\u2019s my sister, Carmen. She\u2019s always been a wild child, gambles a little, plays around. Nothing we can\u2019t take care of\u2014occasionally someone sends us an IOU and we pay it. She drinks a little too much, sometimes smokes marihuana, cocaine\u2026but lately she\u2019s been taking some new drug, and it scares me."

    "What kind of drug?"

    "I wish I knew. The butler found some empty vials in her room, and lately she\u2019s been wilder than usual\u2026she\u2019s getting herself into situations that are not good for her."

    "Does she go to school anywhere?"

    "She\u2019s gone to most of the finest schools in the country, but none of them for longer than a few months. We sent her to finishing school once, but they told us she was as finished as she was going to get."

    "Harsh words."

    "The Sternwoods are a very wild family, Mr. Wright. It helped the General win his rank and his fortune, but it does not make for a quiet home life."

    "If it helps, I was the black sheep of my family."

    "Then we have that in common. I know several places where Carmen might be right now. If you could talk to Eddie Mars, he might know where she is."

    "Mars? The guy who runs gambling houses on the sly for the syndicate? Your family keeps such interesting company, Mrs. Regan. I\u2019ll look into it. I know something about this drug, I think."

    "It makes her do things, Mr. Wright. I found her one night in an apartment in Santa Monica. There were four other people with her, and they were all naked. Doing things to each other, the men, the women\u2026they didn\u2019t care. I\u2019m worried she\u2019ll get into a place where we won\u2019t be able to help her."

    "All right, Mr. Regan. And say hello to your husband. I enjoyed his whiskey back before Repeal\u2026and I knew some of his fellow soldiers back in Ireland."

    [Chandler fans will have recognized the Sternwoods, who are characters from The Big Sleep. Vivian looks like Janet, of course, because I used Lauren Bacall as the portrait for Janet Rogers, and Ms. Bacall played Vivian in the movie of the book. The description is straight from Chandler, BTW, although for her portrait I used Bugsy era Annette Bening.]




    Ruby and Geronimo drove down to Long Beach to find Doug Henslowe\u2019s safety deposit box, Ruby chattering during the entire two-hour drive. Eventually the derricks and cranes of the port of Long Beach came into sight.

    Like a lot of industrial cities, the Depression had hit hard Long Beach hard. They passed boarded up shops and abandoned homes as they drove downtown. Several buildings showed damage from the 1933 earthquake.

    One of which, naturally enough, was the First Bank of Long Beach. The ceiling of what had once been a stately neo-Georgian building had collapsed thoroughly, leaving only the wrecked shell of a building. A group of men and women who looked harder-used than the bank slouched around the cracked stone steps in front of it.

    "Look intimidating but polite," said Ruby to Geronimo. "Be a presence, but don\u2019t instigate. I\u2019ll do the talking, and the instigating."

    "The box may have already been looted," said Geronimo. He made sure to slip his Colt automatic into his shoulder holster.

    They began a canvass of the people hanging around the street. Most people only knew that the bank had failed back in \u201933, along with most of the businesses in the area. Some pointed out a shabbily dressed man clutching a bottle, who was supposed to have worked for the bank once, but he angrily waved them away and scurried off. Geronimo noticed one woman looking at them. She was maybe in her forties, but had daubed rouge and powder on her face to try and look younger. Her mouth was hard and her shoulders were as slumped as the roof of the bank, but her eyes were hard and predatory, clearly used to finding the main chance. Ruby flashed a five dollar bill, and the woman ambled over. Her skirt was torn and her silk shirt stained, but she walked firmly instead of weaving like most of the men they had talked to.

    [Bargain use by RP.]

    "You\u2019re a pretty fancy dame to be coming around here," she said to Ruby. "Name\u2019s Delores."

    "I\u2019d like to ask you a few questions."

    "Hey, I didn\u2019t see nothing."

    "No, no, it\u2019s just about the bank. What\u2019s your normal rate for an hour?"

    "Fifty cents a dance, a buck for half an hour behind the building. I give discounts, though," she said, eyeing Geronimo.

    "I\u2019d like to pay you your rate for an entire day. Nothing illegal," said Ruby when Delores\u2019 eyes widened. "Just to answer some questions about this area. Have anyone been in or out of this building?"

    "When it collapsed after the earthquake in \u201933, some Feds came down. That, whaddaya call it, FDIC. That Roosevelt thing. Took all the assets up somewhere in L. A."

    "Thanks," said Ruby, peeling off some bills. She and Geronimo drove through town until they found a drugstore with a phone book, and Ruby pulled the address of the Los Angeles Federal building.

    "It will be after five when we get back to Los Angeles," said Geronimo.

    "Have to check them out tomorrow then," said Ruby. "Let\u2019s call James first."



    Jimmy called up Bernie Ohls in the D. A.\u2019s office. "Bernie. You know anything about that massacre up in the Valley in \u201926?"

    "Not on the phone. Meet me in a couple of hours." He rang off before Jimmy could say another word. He spent the rest of the morning going through the day\u2019s paperwork and then drove down to the coffee shop near City Hall where he and Ohls sometimes met.

    "This case is a legend in the office," said Bernie, sliding into the booth next to Jimmy. He was a medium-sized blondish man with stiff white eyebrows, calm eyes and well-kept teeth. He looked like anybody you would pass on the street. Jimmy happened to know he had killed nine men\u2014three of them when he was covered, or somebody thought he was.

    "Everybody who comes through the office ends up looking at this case," continued Ohls. "Not the least because the D. A. never did anything about it. The only guy who had a rap hung on him was a skel named Edgar Job, and that\u2019s only because he confessed to sticking that P. I. Last guy to try and work this case over hard was Phil Marlowe\u2014it\u2019s why he got fired. Kept looking into it after the D. A. told him to lay off."

    "I didn\u2019t know that," said Jimmy.

    "Well, Phil always ranked high on the insubordination scale. That was the straw that broke the camel\u2019s back, I guess. I suppose you could swing by the Cahuenga Building and talk to him about it."

    "Think you could let me look at the files in the office?"

    "You don\u2019t have that kind of pull, Jimmy."

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 3)

    [No excuse for the long delay--the write-up for this episode has long been done. Life, amirite?]

    Dr. Orange headed down to the UCLA campus. As he drove down from Pasadena, he noticed a non-descript late-model car following him. Picked up a tail, he thought to himself. He used his Reichsbanner training to keep his pursuer in sight until they parked at the UCLA campus. He walked quickly towards the campus library, losing his tail in the milling crowds of students.

    "You\u2019re from Caltech," said the student librarian, putting down his copy of Amazing Stories. "You guys are working on rocket ships, right?"

    "Sure are," said Dr. Orange distractedly. "Can you fetch any papers by Dr. George Ayers for me?"

    Ayers turned out to have been interested in ancient religions, and had published some controversial papers on the witch cults of Europe, ancient Egypt\u2026and Ethiopia, where he believed that there was a cult of great antiquity in a remote area called Daillol. The abstracts were vague about the actual practice of the religion, but Dr. Ayers seemed to have believed that some form of it may have survived to the present.

    Intrigued, Julius spent some time chasing down information about Ethiopia, and the strange stone they found in Doug Henslowe\u2019s box. He confirmed that it was from the Axum Empire\u2026and probably from the Daillol region\u2014the hottest, driest region on Earth, according to the Britannica. A veritable hell, in fact.

    He went up to the Cultural Studies Department. He had pulled the number of George Ayer\u2019s off an old directory, but it was presently occupied by Dr. Miles Roman, an owlish young classics professor.

    "Caltech? What brings you us? Need something translated from Latin?"

    "I was actually hoping to talk about a colleague of yours\u2026"

    "Ayers, right? You know he\u2019s still technically a professor here; they never fired him. When I got here I managed to convince the Department to let me take the office. Only took a year, so pretty fast for a university, I guess. All his stuff was dumped into storage. Go talk to Samantha, she\u2019s the Department secretary. There was a lot of strange stuff here, buddy, stuff I never recognized."

    Samantha Burnish was one of the grey vestals of learning every well-running academic institution keeps around. She had short, curly, iron-colored hair and wore a turtleneck under her severe suit. "Dr. Ayers\u2019 belongings?" she said, lowering her reading glasses and letting them dangle at the end of the chain around her neck. "I don\u2019t want to gossip\u2026"

    "Of course not."

    "He was a strange man. He hung around with a lot of odd people, not academics. Actors, real estate developers, some Mexican men. One time I had to take some papers to his house and they were having a really wild party. People half-clothed, running around and chanting and just carrying on. I got out of there as soon as I could, I can tell you\u2014Mr. Burnish wouldn\u2019t want me getting involved in anything like that\u2026 I made the arrangements for Dr. Ayers\u2019 trip. He went to Eritrea, I guess it\u2019s called. The Italians took it over, you know. His belongings are in storage, but if Dr. MacDunn says it\u2019s okay, I\u2019m sure you could look them over."

    Dr. MacDunn was an avuncular white-haired man with a close-cropped beard. "It wasn\u2019t really his dig, you know. He was visiting another archaeologist\u2019s find\u2014some European professor, I can\u2019t recall the name. For a while we got some regular reports, and then they just\u2026stopped. Maybe he took sabbatical, but you\u2019d have to ask Administration about that. No objections if you want to look through his office belongings, I suppose."

    Finally a custodian took Dr. Orange into the basement. A small storage space was crammed full of dusty boxes, more than he could hope to go through quickly.

    He called Jimmy\u2019s office. "Mr. Wright is out on a case," the secretary told him, "but I\u2019ll give him your message."

    Julius decided to head over to the Physics Department, where several of his colleagues greeted him warmly. He dropped into a seat in the department lounge and gratefully drank a cup of coffee. Stuart Kitchener, Edgar Job\u2019s advisor, sat with him for a while. He was paunchy and friendly, with thick horn-rimmed glasses and a hip flask he used to freshen up Julius\u2019 coffee.

    "Heard you\u2019re doing aerodynamics now," he said. "Too bad you and Max can\u2019t continue your theoretical work\u2026Edgar Job? Smart kid, maybe not a first-class mind, but had a future. Probably would have made a good theoretical physicist, one of those guys who work down in the lab, running the cloud chamber. The kind of guy you need. That was until \u201925."

    "What happened?"

    "He stopped coming regularly to class, and when I did see him he seemed drunk or something. Began hanging out with a weird crowd, and his papers\u2026he was in a seminar I was teaching, and he was looking at stuff I didn\u2019t think was important. Multi-dimensional geometry of spacetime. It was a quantum mechanics seminar! Why did he bring me Riemannian manifolds? I couldn\u2019t read them. Brought them to a couple of the relativistics guys, and they said it was nonsense, too many shortcuts."

    "Did he hang out with Dr. Ayers?"

    "The creepy guy from Cultural Studies? Yeah, him and his oddball crowd. That was before he went to Ethiopia and got shot or went native or whatever."

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 4)

    When Geronimo and Ruby arrived home, they discovered that Luz, the cook, had quit suddenly while they were up in Arrowhead.

    "That\u2019s what you get for hiring Mexicans, Miss Fitzgibbons," said Althea, the maid. "She said the house was hainted."

    "Were there any prowlers?"

    "Some men came to read the gas meter, they were our only visitors."

    "Well. I guess there\u2019s only one thing to do. Geronimo! Get my s\xe9ance kit!"

    Just at that moment the phone rang. "Salutations," said Ruby when Althea handed her the phone.

    "You left a message with my office," said Jimmy.

    "Yes. I have wonderful news, and I need two favors. The first is inconsequential. I need you to speak with the Federal Reserve Building and tell them we\u2019ll be visiting them tomorrow to see a safety deposit box from the First Bank of Long Beach. The second is, what are you doing tomorrow night, and the answer had better be that you\u2019re coming here."

    Jimmy pressed his intercom button. "Cancel my evening appointments for tomorrow," he told his secretary.

    "Yes, Mr. Wright. I guess the mayor will be disappointed."

    Jimmy winced. "All right, I\u2019ll be there," he said to Ruby.

    "Bring Herr Doktor, you know, Dr. Orange, and one other person. We must conduct a s\xe9ance."

    "Can you reschedule those appointments?" Jimmy called out to his secretary.

    "My cook has just left us, and I think this is connected to the more ethereal and macabre elements of the mystery we are investigating," said Ruby, unperturbed.

    "I see no good news yet."

    "Oh, the wonderful news you mean? My house may be haunted! That\u2019s a clue, James! Six o\u2019clock, we\u2019ll have dinner and cocktails."

    "It was lovely talking to you," said Jimmy, and rang off. He called UCLA and eventually was connected to Dr. Orange in the Physics Department.

    "Jimmy, I have a room full of crap I need sorting out! I\u2019m completely out of my element! Can you help me?"

    "Tonight\u2026? Let me send Betty down to you, this is just the kind of thing she wants to do. Good chance to get her feet wet."



    When she arrived, Betty turned out to be a thorough and diligent searcher. She found two small books\u2014Ayers\u2019 address book, and his appointment book.

    "He sure seemed to spend a lot of time with this Echevarria guy," she said, looking over the books.

    Julius flipped through the address book. "You can use that to confirm if he knew any of your suspects," said Betty helpfully. "That is, when you have any."

    On his own, Dr. Orange turned up the source material that first attracted Dr. Ayers\u2019 attention\u2014an article about an expedition by a Dr. Bartolo Acu\xf1a, a professor at a university in Spain.

    With Betty\u2019s help he managed to sneak several boxes of notebooks and other papers out of the storage closet. Together they went over them that night in Julius\u2019 bungalow in Pasadena.

    Many of Dr. Ayers\u2019 notes spoke of some sort of\u2026entity involved in the dig in Ethiopia, Dr. Orange discovered. An entity he was obsessed with, some kind of ancient god named Gol-Goroth, the "Fisher From Beyond."

    At the end of the notebook, he found a cryptic note from Ayers. "Gol-Goroth is a buffoon," it said. "How can he be the One I look for?"

    [1-point Library Use spend by the Doc.]

    His reverie was interrupted by Betty, who unrolled an old movie poster showing a beautiful young woman in the kind of dress Hollywood thought was ancient Egyptian. "Isn\u2019t this that Olivia Clarendon?" asked Betty. "This must be pretty old. I guess it was before she got famous."

    The poster was signed in a flowing, feminine script: "Dear George: Thanks for everything! Love, Olivia."

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 5)

    Jimmy picked up Janet that evening and took her down to the Cypress Club, Eddie Mars\u2019 joint in Santa Monica. It was at the far end of the town, a rambling frame mansion that had once been the summer residence of a rich man named De Cazens, and later had been a hotel. It was now a big dark outwardly shabby place in a thick grove of wind-twisted Monterey cypresses, which gave it its name. It had enormous scrolled porches, turrets all over the place, stained-glass trims around the big windows, big empty stables at the back, and a general air of nostalgic decay. Eddie Mars had left the outside much as he had found it, instead of making it over to look like an MGM set.

    A tired Mexican band was playing waltzes as they found a booth in the corner. Jimmy handed his card to a waiter. "Tell Mr. Mars I want to talk to him," he said, and ordered drinks.

    "I don\u2019t think you\u2019ve ever told me why you were interested in Winston in the first place," said Jimmy to Janet when they were alone.

    "Well, he just died, of course, and I\u2019m doing a story on his life."

    "An investigative report."

    "It\u2019s clear he was into something strange."

    "You know what is even stranger? During all my investigations your maiden name came up\u2014Edelmann, right?"

    "I\u2019m of German descent."

    "Winston married someone named Karen Edelmann."

    "Yes\u2026"

    "We\u2019ve been friends for a long time, haven\u2019t we? Long enough for me to know when you\u2019re trying to sneak one by me."

    "What do you want me to say, Jimmy?"

    "Just be honest."

    "Do you want me to tell you how Dad was a bastard, and we never got on, that he treated us like strangers for years after he got back from L. A.? That he never told us anything about what had happened, but was different, hollow? He was a ghost for ten years. As for my name\u2026I didn\u2019t want anyone to know I was related to him when I started out. Walter was famous, and I wanted to prove I was a writer. So I took an alias, like your friend, Jackson Elias. Although I hope to come to a different end than her. A life cut tragically short."

    Jimmy sputtered a bit as he took a drink. "A lot of things happened, yes," he managed to gasp out. "But I like to think I\u2019m not just anyone."

    "If I had come to you and said I wanted you to look into my father, you would have just shrugged it off. Some kind of stupid frippery. I needed you to know there was an actual case here."

    "I wouldn\u2019t have!"

    "Then I misjudged you. I guess I owe you a drink."

    "How about it cancels out? I owe you a drink for that story."

    A man stuffed inelegantly into a tuxedo came up to the table. He looked like he could give Joe Louis a couple of tough rounds when he was out of his fancy dress. "Mr. Mars will see you now, Mr. Wright."

    Jimmy followed the gorilla to Mars\u2019 office. This was a square room with a deep old bay window and a stone fireplace in which a fire of juniper logs burned lazily. It was wainscoted in walnut and had a frieze of faded damask above the paneling. The ceiling was high and remote. There was a smell of cold sea.

    Eddie Mars' dark sheenless desk didn't belong in the room, but neither did anything made after 1900. His carpet had a Florida suntan. There was a bartop radio in the corner and a S\xe9vres china tea set on a copper tray beside a samovar. There was a door in the corner that had a time lock on it.

    Eddie Mars grinned at Jimmy sociably and shook hands and moved his chin at the vault. "I'm a pushover for a heist mob here except for that thing," he said cheerfully. "The local johns drop in every morning and watch me open it. I have an arrangement with them. Now what brings a private dick down to my place? Everything that happens in this club is strictly confidential. We don\u2019t need anyone causing trouble."

    "I\u2019m not here looking for trouble."

    "I know you\u2019re not. I know your reputation, that\u2019s why we\u2019re talking. I know you keep things quiet when they need to be quiet, and you work with the cops but aren\u2019t in bed with them. What can I help you with? I figure if I do you a favor, maybe you can do me a favor one day."

    "It\u2019s what makes the world go round," said Jimmy. "I had a curious visit today. One that left me curious myself. About Carmen Sternwood."

    "Viv sent you, didn\u2019t she? Look, I let her and Carmen gamble here\u2014Rusty\u2019s a friend. But I don\u2019t have any control over that little psycho. If you want to talk to her, though, you\u2019re in luck--she\u2019s playing roulette right now."

    "Lead the way."

    "Just be aware," said Mars, not getting up. His expression and his voice didn\u2019t change, but there was a sudden menace in the room. "If there\u2019s any trouble, don\u2019t even bother to take it outside. Trouble is going to settle in only one place, my friend, and that\u2019s in your lap."

    "Good thing I got a good lap."

    "Jimmy\u2014can I call you Jimmy?"

    "Everyone does."

    [RP: I don\u2019t.]

    "Carmen makes a lot of money for the club. She brings in the clientele. If you need to talk to her, take her out of here. I just don\u2019t want to hear anything about anyone getting dragged out of my place or kidnapped to Mexico."
