    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 6)

    There was a crowd gathered around the roulette table when the gorilla led Jimmy to it, laughing and shouting. In the middle was a young woman. She was twenty or so, small and delicately put together, but she looked durable. She wore a low-cut evening gown covered in sequins, and she wore it well. She looked as if she were floating. Her hair was a fine tawny wave cut much shorter than the current fashion of pageboy tresses curled in at the bottom. Her eyes were slate-gray, and had almost no expression when they looked at him. As Jimmy got closer she smiled with her mouth and she had little sharp predatory teeth, as white as fresh orange pith and as shiny as porcelain. They glistened between her thin too taut lips. Her face lacked color and didn't look too healthy.

    She was betting money like water, and losing a lot.

    Janet grabbed Jimmy. "Are you here for Carmen Sternwood? Good luck, Jimmy\u2014I\u2019m going to call it an early night."

    She kissed his cheek and sauntered off. Jimmy watched her go. She had a nice walk. Then he crowded in among the crowd around the table until he was next to Carmen. "Nice bet," he said.

    She turned to face him, wobbling. Her eyes, the pupils huge and round and black, rolled around the room like ball bearings dropped in a bathtub. Eventually they stopped moving and locked on his face. "You\u2019re cute," she slurred.

    [Me: She\u2019s at least drunk.]

    "You\u2019re possibly the first person to ever call me that."

    "Let\u2019s go to a playground and play."

    "Sure, I know a place with great swings."

    "I do too. Let\u2019s go to your place," she said. Jimmy pushed her back before she could crawl into his coat. A flashbulb popped nearby.

    "Reporters," he muttered. He threw his overcoat across her shoulders and managed to guide her to his car with somewhat less struggle than it took to dig the Panama Canal.

    As he drove up Santa Monica Boulevard, Carmen began to slip out of her dress.

    "No!" said Jimmy, holding her down with one hand and snatching his hand off the wheel from time to time to try and fasten her dress. It wasn\u2019t too hard, no worse than juggling wineglasses in a hurricane. His car veered across lanes, but he managed to keep it on the road the majority of the time. He swung off the Boulevard and headed for Ruby\u2019s house, the closest place he could think of where it would be safe to stash Carmen.

    [I gave JP a choice: make a Driving test and keep Carmen clothed, or avoid the test but have her wind up naked.]

    Ruby met him at the door wearing flowing Indian silk robes and a scarlet turban. "I\u2019m trying out my s\xe9ance outfits," she said.

    Jimmy stumbled inside, tie askew, dragging Carmen behind him. "Ruby!" she drawled.

    "Carmen. How pleasant to see you again," she said, in a voice Lucrezia Borgia could have bottled and used to do in the entire College of Cardinals.

    "I\u2019m holding," Carmen whispered in her ear.

    "Do come in. I\u2019ll make us some drinks."

    "Oh, I\u2019ll take care of that," said Carmen.

    Ruby waited for Carmen to head into the parlor. "Why did you bring her?" she demanded.

    "She was stripping in my car! I had nowhere else to go!"

    "Well you\u2019re sitting next to her at the s\xe9ance!"

    Geronimo came up the hall in a white shirt and slacks. "What\u2019s going on?" he asked crossly. "Mr. Wright, the s\xe9ance is supposed to be tomorrow. Why is there all this noise?"

    "I had to bring Carmen Sternwood over," said Jimmy.

    "Ah. The one Miss Fitzgibbons calls that tramp. Where is she?"

    "In the parlor," said Ruby.

    "You left her alone?" said Geronimo. He walked to the parlor, sweeping Jimmy and Ruby into his wake.

    On the coffee table were three Manhattans in cut glass tumblers, elegantly finished with maraschino cherries. Next to them stood Carmen Sternwood, completely naked. It was a good look on her, although would have pulled it off better had she been able to pull off standing up without swaying. Her shredded clothes were in a messy pile on one of the sofas. There was a heavy, cloying perfume in the air, and some other odor, something mossy and exotic.

    "Miss Carmen," said Geronimo implacably.

    "Jerry!"

    "Geronimo, actually."

    "Harry, then. I\u2019ll make you a drink."

    "Why Carmen," said Ruby, "you never told me you had your appendix out." She took the drink Carmen offered her and tossed it over her shoulder when nobody was looking.

    Jimmy reached for a drink. Carmen smiled at him, and then shoved him in his chest. Jimmy fell back onto the carpet and Carmen swooped down on him like a condor on roadkill. She ripped open his shirt and began to kiss and lick anything she could touch, her eyes wide and her face flushed.

    Jimmy rolled and threw Carmen off of him like she was a grenade. Geronimo reached down and pulled her up. She turned and tried to climb onto Geronimo, who caught her, staggering back with the effort. Carmen snaked her legs around his and hugged his neck with one arm. She ripped open his shirt with the other and then stuck it in the waistband of his slacks and began to reach down.

    Ruby came up behind Carmen and pulled her off of Geronimo. Carmen spun, pulled open Ruby\u2019s robe, and began to grab and suck and bite Ruby\u2019s flailing arms. She collapsed onto Carmen and they both fell down on the floor, sprawled out. With Ruby\u2019s turban and billowing silk, they would have made a fair print for a twopenny knockoff of the Kama Sutra.

    Jimmy and Geronimo closed in, circling like wrestlers and trying to do as little harm. "All of us at once!" screamed Carmen orgasmically.

    "Fetch the chloroform," gasped Ruby. Geronimo ran out of the room and came back with a brown glass bottle. Jimmy snatched it, poured some liquid into his handkerchief, and came up behind Carmen. Ruby was still making a valiant if not altogether convincing defense as Carmen continued to press herself on top of her. Jimmy clasped the handkerchief over Carmen\u2019s face and held it there until she collapsed, unconscious, to the floor.

    "I\u2019d ask why you have chloroform, but\u2026" said Jimmy with a shrug.

    "This is just like my last birthday," said Ruby, getting slowly to her feet.

    She saw a small open vial on the sidebar.

    She put her body between it and the rest of the room and sniffed it. The smell was mossy\u2026but intriguing. Enticing. It reminded her of new lust and old sex, of afterglow and yearning at the same time. Her fingers reached out for it without her even noticing, caressing the sides of the bottle.

    If this was what Carmen had taken, Ruby could see that it had practical applications. She capped the vial and slipped it into a pocket of her robe.

    [I randomly rolled who ended up nearest to the vial, and unfortunately for Ruby it was her. Ruby\u2019s drive is Adventure, and we know that she has experimented with drugs and is sexually\u2026um\u2026adventurous. So I felt that this would be a Hard Driver vs. Adventure.]

    Geronimo and Jimmy took Carmen down to Luz\u2019s former room and put her to bed. A wooden crucifix looked down over Carmen from the wall, and there were still some clothes visible in the half open closet. Luz had left in a hurry.
    \n

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 7)

    An hour later, Andr\xe9 arrived at the house and was hastened up to Ruby\u2019s bedroom. "I am not to be disturbed for the night," she called out, slamming the door behind her. The poison is in the dose, she thought. Carmen always overdid it.

    "Qu\u2019est-que c\u2019est?" asked Andr\xe9 as she gave them each a drop of liquid. "C\u2019est pour l\u2019amour?"

    "I think it\u2019s an aphrodisiac," said Ruby, not listening. She waited for something to happen.

    For a long breath, nothing did. Then suddenly she felt warmth spreading through her, beginning in her groin and radiating outward. Every nerve in her body grew taut as wire, and just as electric. Pleasure surged through her body, and she almost fell into an orgasm just standing there. Andre\u2019s eyes were dark and wide as he writhed in similar pleasure.

    They came together like a thunderclap, entwining each other in their limbs. Nothing seemed able to satiate their lust and desire, and for two hours they fell into the most delirious, ecstatic lovemaking of either of their lives.

    Some tiny part of her mind screamed in frustration. It turned me on like a light switch! I have no control! What is happening to me!



    Geronimo lay in his bed, smoking. He turned on the radio to drown out the sound of Ruby and Andre upstairs. He listened to the tail end of an evangelical program:

    "God wants you to be happy. God wants you to have joy. Joy! The mouth of God shall speak and ye shall be healed and joyful. Come and worship God at the Temple of Joy. And send away for water blessed by God, 35 cents cash on delivery. This is the Reverend Doctor Goodman Black reminding you to be joyful, for God will drown you in his love and draw you forth again."

    He dozed with the radio still on, the low drone of the announce blending with his dreams. In them he heard a voice, whispering words he couldn\u2019t understand, but urging him to awake, to rage, to run in the moonlight like the predator he was, to slash and tear and kill all those who had wronged him. To tear down the house. To kill everyone in it.

    He awoke with a start. Piano music was coming from the radio, something Classical, Chopin maybe. A voice was whispering. Strange words that he could not understand, almost in time to the music, but making a harsh contrast with the melody.

    "Soy un soldado de la Rep\xfablica Espa\xf1ola," he gasped. "My duty is to protect, not kill." He stared at the plain brown wood of the headboard, shuddering at the hissing sibilant sounds coming from behind it. Something had to be there, making that noise, but he held back for a long moment. Finally he stood up, and dragged the bed away from the wall.

    There was a mouth.

    It was ugly, almost lipless, a slash against the surface of the wall like a wound. Jagged, horrible teeth jutted from it, animal teeth, teeth of something terrible and unnatural. A tongue flicked in and out of the mouth, glistening with slime and far too long for the size of the mouth. It was both appalling and faintly lascivious, and for a brief incredulous second it reminded Geronimo of Carmen when she had attacked him.

    As he stared, the mouth began to fade, seeming to slide back into the wall. He thought he saw it moving slightly up towards the corner where the wall met the ceiling. Then it was gone.

    He sank to his knees and pulled out his rosary, praying for hours.

    [So! It turns out Luz was right, the house is haunted. The mechanics of this were that the mouth had an ability to incite a person to animalistic urges. This called for a Stability test that Geronimo passed. Pulling back the bed was a Hard Driver against his drive of Duty, so he got back two points, but then lost three. (I\u2019m using a fixed cost Stability loss chart rather than calling for Stability tests, at least for the moment.) Finally, GP used Geronimo\u2019s Symbol, the rosary, to gain back a couple of points of Stability.]



    Ruby woke up slowly, aching with both strain and remembered pleasure. The early morning sun caught the brown glass of the vial of Carmen\u2019s drug on her nightstand.

    She seized it and tried to lick out the inside. Unfortunately there wasn\u2019t any. She had a vague memory of doing the same thing during the night.

    When Geronimo came in he found her holding her grandmother\u2019s brooch. "She was an adventurer too, you know," said Ruby. "Always pushing back the frontiers\u2026"

    Geronimo surveyed the literal wreckage of the room. Andre was tangled in with some sheets and the remains of a Louis XIV chair in one corner. "Anything unusual happen last night?" he asked.

    "No\u2026nothing special." Ruby looked back down at her brooch. The need for the drug suddenly seized her again. For a moment the room seemed to go grey. I could get dressed, she thought. But if I had some more of that drug, I could\u2026do more.

    "Tea," she said. "Tea with honey, Geronimo, if you don\u2019t mind. As much honey as you can put in."

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 8)

    Dr. Orange not only had his notes organized by the time Jimmy got to Pasadena, he had mercifully put on a pot of coffee.

    "Crazy night," said Jimmy, grabbing a second cup. "I had to talk with Buchwald, my accountant on the way out. Kind of a strange guy, but good accountants can be as strange as they want in my business. Let\u2019s see what you found out." He flipped through Julius\u2019 notes. "Wait a minute. Olivia Clarendon? The movie star?"

    "You know her?"

    "A little bit, from around the studios. Maybe we ought to go see her."

    "A big shot like her? What are you going to do, call the head of the studio?"

    Jimmy smiled and used Dr. Orange\u2019s phone to call his office. "Get me Jack Warner," he told his secretary while waving to Julius to put on another pot of coffee. "Jack! How are you? You think I could have a couple of minutes of Olivia Clarendon\u2019s time today?"

    "She\u2019s shooting that William Tell thing today. How long you need her for?"

    "Just a few minutes, something came up in one of my investigations."

    "All right, fine. I\u2019ll have her people call your office. By the way, I may need your help. Rumor is that I have an animation division, but I don\u2019t know anything about it!"

    Jimmy glanced at Betty, who was reading a Porky Pig comic book. "I\u2019ll look into it."

    [2-point Credit Rating spend to get to Olivia Clarendon; seemed natural that he\u2019d know Jack Warner from around Hollywood. There is indeed a story that one reason the WB animation team was able to be so anarchic and satirical is that Warner literally did not realize he even had an animation division.]



    Olivia Clarendon\u2019s secretary met them outside a large soundstage in the shadow of the famous water tower of Warner Studios. "Miss Clarendon can give you fifteen minutes, no more. She\u2019s on set right now and can be called back at any instant, so don\u2019t try to hold her any longer or you\u2019ll have to deal with Mr. Curtiz."

    "No problem," said Jimmy. He knew from experience that most of making a movie was sitting around and waiting.

    [It\u2019s pretty obvious from the text that Olivia Clarendon is a thinly-disguised Olivia de Havilland (I even used the fantastic and still-living Ms. De Havilland as the portrait for Olivia Clarendon.) So I decided to have some fun with that\u2014the big movie in 1938 for Olivia de Havilland was The Adventures of Robin Hood, so I figured a William Tell movie would make sense for our not-Olivia. Michael Curtiz however gets to be the director of both.]

    They stepped out of the brilliant January sunshine into the darkness of the soundstage. Ahead of them they could see a set laid out like an Alpine meadow, with a half-timbered house in the foreground. The bright stage lights made everything washed out and flat looking. A couple of extras in doublets and hose walked by, carrying plywood crossbows.

    As they came closer to the set, they saw a black-haired woman sitting in a folding chair. On the back was a star and "Miss Clarendon" in a florid script. She saw them walking towards her and stood up.

    Close up, she was quite attractive, even with the heavy stage makeup and her ridiculous Swiss peasant costume. She had intense black eyes with just a hint of naughty good humor lurking in them. She shook hands with Jimmy\u2014a firm grip, quite American but with an air of British politeness.

    "You\u2019re taller in the movies," said Dr. Orange, who didn\u2019t know what else to say.

    "And even shorter without these on," said Olivia. She indicated the platform shoes she was wearing. She had an English accent that was beginning to fray into something more Trans-Atlantic. "Poor Allan quite towers over me without them. Jimmy. How nice to see you again."

    "Good to see you too, Olivia. So you\u2019re working with Allan Swann? I hear you have to be careful around him."

    "Well, it\u2019s best to shoot the romantic scenes early in the morning, before he can really tie one on," she said. "Nothing ruins a tender moment more than getting half a distillery in your face every time the leading man breathes. That\u2019s showbiz, I guess."

    [Allan Swann is the thinly-disguised Errol Flynn character from My Favorite Year.]

    "This is Dr. Orange. Don\u2019t worry, he\u2019s a physicist, not a medical doctor. Could we talk to you alone?"

    "Let\u2019s go to my dressing room." They took a short walk behind the backdrops to a small private room. Various gowns designed to solve the near impossible problem of making Olivia look tall, Swiss, and from the 15th century were littered around on chairs or hung up behind the door. She sat in a rickety chair in front of a well-lit mirror and motioned them to sit down.

    Dr. Orange quite deliberately locked the door behind him as he came in.



    "What\u2019s going on?" said Olivia sharply. "I assure you that studio security will not take this sort of thing lightly. Did my sister send you?"

    [Olivia de Havilland and her sister, Joan Fontaine, are the only sisters to win Best Actress. They weren\u2019t close, including an infamous snub of Olivia by Joan at the 1942 Oscars.]

    "No. Echevarr\xeda called," said Jimmy.

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 9)

    "Wh--who?"

    "Look in the mirror. Would you believe that face?"

    "He couldn\u2019t have called. He\u2019s dead."

    "But you were in the cult."

    "I\u2019m not in any cult! Well, the Screen Actors Guild. And I was hardly the only actor trying to get ahead back then by hanging around Ramon Echevarria."

    "How do you know George Ayers?" asked Dr. Orange.

    "That\u2019s how I met Ramon. I was doing some research for a part\u2014"

    "Research on a part?"

    "Yes. It was the Twenties. D. W. Griffith used to build Babylonian cities in the desert in those days, for goodness sake! I had just arrived in this country, I didn\u2019t know anyone, so I was looking for anything to give me an advantage. If my research could sell me with Mr. De Mille, then it would be worth it! Not that I worked with anyone so important back then. It was before the Hays Code. We did films that were racier than you can do today. I met Ayers at UCLA, and he invited me to some of Ramon\u2019s parties. I took a fellow I used to know back then, a man named Richard Spend."

    "And what took place at these parties?" said Dr. Orange.

    "They were\u2026adult entertainments of a very Continental nature."

    Jimmy and Julius stared at her.

    "People did\u2026things to one another. Strange things, things that\u2026aren\u2019t the ordinary way people go about that sort of\u2026thing. I don\u2019t think Ramon ever filmed it, thank God, though he may have taken pictures. Lord knows it would have made for a hell of a magazine. Nothing you could send in the mails of course."

    She put a cigarette in her mouth but her hands shook too much to work the lighter. Jimmy lit it for her and she turned away from them, her words coming out in shaky bursts.

    "The sex\u2026well, I was just off the boat, but not born yesterday if you understand me. When you\u2019re a woman in this business, you have to sometimes do some unsavory things. And to hear Clark talk about it, not always just the women. They were sex parties, all right? They used to drink this cocktail called Nectar. I tried it a few times; it certainly went straight to my head! Like a highball made with ether."

    She buried her head in her hands for a moment. Jimmy waited. They always talked when they were like this, if you waited them out.

    "Is it true," she said slowly, "that sometimes you look into cases that\u2026don\u2019t have any rational explanation?"

    "Somebody has to," said Jimmy.

    "I\u2019ve never told anyone this, and if you tell anyone about it I\u2019ll deny it and never speak to you again. One night\u2026I could have sworn I saw a mouth form on the back of a davenport I was sitting on with some other people. And\u2026I could swear that the mouth was doing things with them. Well, after that, I stopped going. Ramon died not long after. And then a few years went by and I got my break."

    "Were they all at Echevarr\xeda\u2019s house?"

    "Yes, almost always. And that\u2019s all I can really tell you, James."

    "Thanks. It was helpful."

    "I just wish poor Ricky had gotten out when I did," she said wistfully.

    "Richard Spend?"

    "Yes. I mean, he died so horribly, with Echevarria and his people up in the Valley."

    "Do you know much about him?"

    "Not much. I think he was Texan originally. Had a Southern accent at least. He wasn\u2019t much of an actor, but he was very pretty. I\u2019m sure he could have gotten a break sometime."


    Jimmy drove up towards Hollywood. "This is an interesting car, Jimmy," said Dr. Orange. "The windows are so\u2026thick."

    "Bulletproof glass."

    "Bulletproof glass?"

    "I had some incidents earlier in my career. The doors and floor are armored too."

    "What in God\u2019s name did you used to do?"

    "One time I tried to take out an apartment building with a car."

    "What happened?"

    "The building won. Got shot for my trouble too. Was just able to drive to a hospital in the 17th Arrondissment. Still send the nurses there flowers every year."

    They pulled to a stop in front of the Cahuenga Building. It was reasonably shabby building put up around the time the all tile bathroom had become the basis of civilization. The lobby was empty except for a shoeshine stand. An automatic elevator had been put in so that the landlord didn\u2019t have to pay for an operator.

    They rode up a few floors. The carpet in the hallway was faded and worn, and the light dim. Dust coated the corners and the doorsills of unoccupied offices. They came to one door with pebbled glass and "Phillip Marlowe, Private Investigator" painted on it in peeling letters.

    Jimmy opened the door and a buzzer sounded. Inside was a small waiting room, with another door with a pebbled glass window opposite them. The door opened and Phil Marlowe came out.

    He was about six foot one, strongly built, with the kind of face that could be handsome when he wanted it to be. He had a broken nose and a sarcastic twist to his lips.

    "Jimmy Wright."

    "Hey, Phil."

    "Well what brings you down to my place? Am I supposed to genuflect?"

    "Why would you?"

    "The great James Wright comes to visit Phillip Marlowe, P. I. This about the thing in the Valley, right? Come on in."

    Marlowe\u2019s office had the usual desk with the usual pen and blotter set. A set of mostly empty file cases were up against one wall. The window was open and the smell of frying grease came from the coffee shop across the alley.

    Marlowe sat behind his desk, opened up a drawer, and threw a file on the desk. "Everyone who comes through the D. A.\u2019s office tries to do something with that case. They\u2019d have trouble pulling the file right now, however. I neglected to return it when I got canned."

    Jimmy picked up the file and thumbed through the police report. The official story was that a bunch of heroin users died in an orgy out in the Valley. Jimmy carefully wrote down the lot numbers\u2014back in 1926, there hadn\u2019t been an address since the land had only recently been incorporated into Los Angeles County.

    Reading over the file, Jimmy realized that this story should have been much bigger than it actually was, especially since it was so close to the Blackout of \u201926. He guessed that some of the victims had relatives with enough pull to bury the story.

    The medical examiner\u2019s report showed that almost all the victims were horribly mutilated, although the cause of death is listed as "wild animals." Some investigator had added a sarcastic note to that description. Jimmy agreed; the only animal he could think of that could make wounds like that was a dinosaur.

    Many of the bodies were found in flagrante delicto.

    Echevarr\xeda\u2019s body was identified by his servants. Richard Spend\u2019s body was identified only by the wallet he had on him. In fact, most bodies were identified only by going over the street clothes, wallets and purses found scattered over the area\u2014the victims were wearing robes, or nothing.

    The bodies of the Winston Circle were all noted in the report; they had been fully clothed. Blood trails suggested that at least a couple of people managed to escape.

    Notations throughout the files showed that several investigators had tried to reopen the case only to be shot down by multiple district attorneys. One angry note said, "This happened five years ago out in the middle of nowhere. Everyone\u2019s dead. Nobody cares."

    There was a notable lack of evidence of heroin found at the scene, considering that it was supposed to have been a drug-fueled orgy.

    "You won\u2019t make anything out of this, Jimmy," said Phil. "People want this story to stay dead."

    "Lots of people want lots of stories to stay dead. That\u2019s why we\u2019re here."

    "Hey, you\u2019re the Pope of Private Investigation, if you say you can do it, who am I to say anything."

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 10)

    Ruby waited by the car for Geronimo to driver her down to the Federal Building. Carmen staggered out of the house and leaned on the car next to her.

    "We have a cab coming for you," said Ruby. "They\u2019ll take you home."

    "You know," whispered Carmen confidentially, "I know where we can find more of that stuff."

    Inside the house, Geronimo heard a car engine start. He ran outside to see Ruby tearing down the street in her car like the Condor Legion was after her, with Carmen in the front seat.

    [So! Welcome to addict land, Ruby. An obvious chance to take the drug called Nectar provokes a TN 5 Stability Test, which RP failed, causing her to take off with Carmen.]

    Cursing, Geronimo jumped into Ruby\u2019s coupe and drove off after them. They drove for a while through neighborhoods that changed in character from haute bourgeois to Latino working-class.

    "This one!" Carmen shouted to Ruby. Their car screeched to a halt in front of a shabby single-family house. A couple of men in zoot suits were standing on a lawn that was more dirt and crab grass than anything else.

    "Mira las blancas," said one to the other. "You want something, girls?"

    "We\u2019re here for the stuff," said Carmen.

    "Go right in. Tell them El Cap\xedtan sent you."

    Carmen practically jumped over the car door in her hurry to get in, followed closely by Ruby. Geronimo pulled up just in time to see her vanish inside the house.

    "What are you here for?" said one of the zoot suiters in Spanish.

    "I\u2019m with the young ladies."

    "Oho! Looks like we have an educated man, eh Profether?" said the other zoot suiter, mocking Geronimo\u2019s Castilian accent. "You should go away. We don\u2019t need you here."

    Geronimo opened the door very deliberately and walked around the hood of the car. He didn\u2019t look that frightening. No worse to tangle with than, say, a grizzly. "That young lady is my responsibility," he said, fixing his calm gaze on the tough.

    "Your rethponthibility," said the zoot suiter, but he was clearly shaken by Geronimo\u2019s determined air of menace. "Go right in. We\u2019ll watch your car and make sure it\u2019s okay."

    As Geronimo walked in the door, he saw one of the thugs making a beeline for a pay phone.

    [Sense Trouble by GP.]

    Inside, Carmen and Ruby found a card table with a man sitting behind it. He had an open crate filled with packing straw behind him, and a cigar box full of cash on the table in front of him. He seemed bored with the routine, but also had the self-satisfied smirk of any dealer.

    "What do you need?" he said to them.

    "Let\u2019s see," said Carmen, counting on her fingers. "Let\u2019s say\u2026ten. You want any, Ruby?"

    Ruby pulled out a wad of cash and dropped it into the cigar box. He handed over a set of glass vials. "There\u2019s a room in the back," he said. Carmen was already walking into it.

    Ruby held the vials with a trembling hand. She tried to stuff them in her purse...but found herself licking out the inside of one of the vials.

    One of the zoot suiters carried her into the back room.



    "You here to work for us, or are you buying?" asked the man behind the table in Spanish when Geronimo entered the house.

    "Where did those ladies go?"

    "They\u2019re in the playroom."

    Geronimo started towards it. "Whoa," said the man. "If you want to go in the playroom, you got to play."

    Geronimo tossed down a few bills and resumed his walk towards the room. "Hey!" shouted the man. He heard footsteps behind him as he yanked open the door.

    The floor of the playroom was a writhing mass of limbs and naked flesh. Moans and gasped escaped from it, and it undulated like a wave with shocks of pleasure. He recognized an ankle tattoo and pulled on the leg. Ruby slid out, glistening with sweat and other fluids.

    "Geronimo," she drawled. "Are you here too? Come join us."

    "Miss Fitzgibbons, we have to go."

    "But we just got here\u2026"

    "Come. I will take you home. We will call Mr. Andr\xe9."

    With difficulty he pulled her upright. He found the remnants of her dress near the door and pulled it over her, then draped his overcoat over her shoulders and pushed her through the door.

    Several tough looking men were waiting for him there. "Hold on," said the man who had been behind the card table. "You just wait here. The Captain\u2019s coming down to talk to you."

    "What does he have to do with anything?"

    "You don\u2019t just pull our clients out."

    "She paid, didn\u2019t she? Now I\u2019m taking her home."

    "Look, your choice. You wait here and make this right with the Captain, or we take you down in the basement and shoot you both."

    In response, Geronimo lit a cigarette. He held on tightly to Ruby, who was swaying next to him. After several uncomfortable minutes, the front door opened and a man came in.

    He wasn\u2019t tall, but he managed to be intimidating all out of proportion to his size. Maybe it was his face, pock-marked and rough, with vicious, active black eyes that gleamed from under his heavy brow. He had a thin pencil moustache, and wore a zoot suit of dark color and impeccable tailoring.

    "I\u2019m Captain Walker," he said in a gravelly voice. "Why are you taking one of my clients out of here?"

    [I\u2019m using El Pachuco era Edward James Olmos for Walker\u2019s portrait.]

    "She is my employer, and I am taking her home."

    "You understand that your employer will now have need of our services."

    "Yes, but she can partake of them at home."

    "I haven\u2019t met you. I should have met you before. You\u2019re not Mexican."

    "No."

    "But you are Spanish. That\u2019s better than nothing."

    "I\u2019m not robbing you of a client, if that\u2019s what you\u2019re worried about."

    "That is not in your power in any case. She is now our client--forever. But you understand my problem. You came to my house, you pulled her out of the place, you showed me no respect. I don\u2019t need someone screwing up our relationships with the cops, or with the nice people who do business with us."

    "No disrespect meant. But I will protect my employer. And your client. There is nothing else to say."

    Walker took a drag on his cigarette. "Very well, Se\xf1or. We know many things about you, Mr. Cuevas. Understand that you are being watched, you have been watched, and you will continue to be watched."

    Geronimo managed to keep Ruby from assaulting him or the controls of the car long enough to get back to their house. He secured her to the bed with her restraints, and sat downstairs smoking while Ruby shrieked in frustration.

    After a couple of hours she fell unconscious.

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 11)

    Jimmy pulled up to Ruby\u2019s house along with Dr. Orange. "Shouldn\u2019t take long," he said to Julius over his shoulder. "Just need to talk to Carmen for a minute."

    Althea met him at the door. "Mr. Jimmy, we are having a horrible day here today. Miss Ruby is out of her mind again. She was just like this last night too. I don\u2019t know what we\u2019re going to do!"

    "What was she like?"

    "Not my place to talk, Mr. Wright! I just think I should find a new situation for myself. You need a cleaning lady, Mr. Wright?"

    "Was she acting like that lady I brought over last night?"

    "Miss Carmen? Oh, yes. I saw her talking to Miss Ruby earlier today, and they both drove away in a hurry. Mr. Cuevas had to go chase after them. When he brought her back she was out of her mind."

    They found Geronimo inside, sitting on the stairs in the hall, taking out the last cigarette in his pack. "She drank the vial, didn\u2019t she?" Jimmy said.

    "Yes," said Geronimo, lighting his cigarette. "She is lost to us now."

    "I brought Herr Doktor with me, so we should keep him away from the vial."

    "Miss Fitzgibbons purchased several more this afternoon."

    Jimmy sighed. "Let me guess, Carmen is gone too."

    "Yes. Also, we are being watched by the drug gang."



    While Jimmy and Geronimo were talking, Ruby slowly came back to her senses. Once again, the world seemed strangely grey. There was a roaring in her head like the ocean. She could almost make out words in the rush of white noise. Her body ached and she arched her back in frustration.

    There were more vials in her purse, she realized.

    "Althea," she croaked.

    "Oh my!" said Althea, coming into the bedroom. "You okay, Miss Ruby?"

    "Could I have some water? Oh, and hand me my purse."

    Althea brought Ruby a glass of water and her purse. She helped undo Ruby\u2019s restraints.

    "Thank you, that will be all," said Ruby with a beatific smile.

    Sixty-one seconds later she came bounding down the stairs. She slid into Jimmy and wrapped her legs around him gently, like a giant squid embracing a sperm whale. "Oh, James," she said.

    "Not again!"

    "Who let her get this stuff!" shouted Geronimo, trying to pry Ruby off of Jimmy. Ruby managed to twist free and began crawling toward Dr. Orange. "Oh come on," she said to Julius as Geronimo grabbed her ankle. "I know you\u2019re not a monk of science!"

    Jimmy grabbed Ruby and wrapped an arm around her neck in the way Francis O\u2019Donnell had once showed him. He pulled back and let his joints compress her carotid artery until Ruby slumped forward, unconscious.

    [I let JP make a 2-point Scuffling spend to apply a sleeper hold.]

    "Help me get her upstairs!" Jimmy grunted.



    Jimmy almost sent an associate to check out the house in East L. A., but then thought better of sending people around to a place where the most addictive drug he had ever heard of was being sold.

    Ruby woke up after an hour. "I think I\u2019ve had a very bad day," she said to Geronimo when he came into the room. She knew what would make the day better, but her purse was nowhere to be seen.

    "Carmen always overdoes things," she said to Jimmy when he came upstairs. "I figured that I would know how to handle it."

    Jimmy sat by the bed trying to console Ruby, but she was much too agitated to listen to him.

    [JP wanted to do Psychological Triage, but had to make the roll naked because Jimmy only has a couple of Psychoanalysis points. JP rolled a 2, so that failed.]

    Geronimo sighed. "There\u2019s only one man who can lift her spirits when she\u2019s like this."

    "Who\u2019s that?" said Jimmy.

    "Captain Murphy," said Geronimo, making it sound like being sent to a firing squad. Althea shook her head as she picked up the room and muttered something evil-sounding under her breath.

    "I don\u2019t get it," said Jimmy.

    "Wait a while. You\u2019ll find out," said Geronimo. He left to make a phone call to the harbor.

    [Good call here by RP to use Ruby\u2019s Solace to bump up her Stability\u2014she was down to 1 point of Stability.]

    \n Episode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 12)

    Jimmy was making a bunch of sandwiches, an omelet, and a can of soup for Ruby and the rest of them, the limit of his culinary abilities. Dr. Orange was making notes.

    "You know, I could probably synthesize a compound like this Nectar," he mused. "I would need to study it some more\u2026"

    "Let\u2019s not worry about that now," said Jimmy quickly.

    [Me: You want to make a Nectar methadone? (I just checked\u2014methadone was actually invented in Germany in 1937!)]

    "It must be an interesting chemical, though. Deserving of study\u2026"

    [Me: tell me about Captain Murphy!
    RP: He\u2019s like the lead in one of those black-and-white adventure movies. He loves Ruby, but not as much as his freedom. He admires Ruby\u2019s adventurousness, but he\u2019d prefer that in a man. Basically, he\u2019s a fun alpha-male guy for a while\u2014and then he goes too far and Ruby chucks him out.
    Me: Excellent. I know just how to play him.

    (I used my best rapid-fire 1930s male lead voice for Captain Murphy\u2014something between Walter Winchell and Robert Armstrong.)]

    The doorbell rang, and soon Captain Murphy was bounding into the entry hall. He was tall and dark, with slicked back black hair and a pencil moustache. He was wearing a khaki shirt with a silk scarf folded around his neck and tucked into the collar, duck slacks and boat shoes.

    "Where\u2019s Ruby?" he said, tossing a yacht captain\u2019s hat onto a chair. "She said she needed to talk to me, and I have tonight free. We don\u2019t sail to Borneo until tomorrow morning. Jerry, how are you doing?"

    "I am fine. Miss Fitzgibbons is in her bedchamber. I must warn you, she is very ill."

    "What\u2019s she got? The D. T.s? The flu?"

    "No, she has been addicted to a new drug."

    "Well, Ruby\u2019s a great gal but she\u2019s got a frail constitution, you know, and a weak mind. But other than that she\u2019s a capital lady. Who the hell are you guys?"

    "Jimmy Wright."

    "Dr. Orange."

    "Oh, a Kraut? Well that\u2019s okay. They\u2019re really turning things around there now, I hear."

    Julius punched him in the nose.

    It wasn\u2019t a hard punch\u2014street brawling wasn\u2019t in his Reichsbanner portfolio\u2014but it caught Murphy by surprise.

    "Better men than you have tried that!" shouted Murphy. "Why don\u2019t you step outside with me, you damn Kraut! Come on, put up your dukes and fight like a man!"

    Jimmy stepped in between them. "I think you should be helping Ruby," he said.

    "How can we trust this guy? He\u2019s one of them Huns! He cold-cocked me!"

    "I\u2019m pretty sure that if he cold-cocked you, it\u2019s because you insulted him."

    "You talk pretty tough, Jimmy."

    "I apologize for the doctor," said Geronimo smoothly. "But we need you to see Ruby."

    Few things could give Captain Murphy pause, but the sight of Ruby tied to the bedposts apparently was one of them. "Well Ruby, I didn\u2019t know it was going to be one those housecalls," he said.

    "Oh Murphy, you bastard," said Ruby, smiling.

    "That\u2019s magnificent bastard to you."

    "You are a magnificent bastard. Now shut up and kiss me. Use your lips right for once!"

    "So what\u2019s your poison, Ruby? What happened to you?"

    "Carmen Sternwood. She hooked me. She hooked me bad."

    "So what are you chasing? The China dragon? Brazilian marching powder? That Mary-juwanna?"

    "You know I don\u2019t do the hard stuff anymore!"



    The evening concluded with the ceremonial pitching out of Murphy by Geronimo, who used a new throwing motion to put an extra twist on the Captain as he sailed out over the porch steps. He came back to the kitchen. Jimmy shoved a container of fried rice at him\u2014he\u2019d made a quick run for some Chinese food.

    A large map of Los Angeles County was spread out on the table. Jimmy pointed to a spot in the San Fernando Valley with a chopstick. "That\u2019s the place where it happened," he said.

They call him the \u2018Fisher from the Outside\u2019 and he\u2019s supposed to live on the moon. The theosophists say he was worshipped in Mu and Lemuria, but they\u2019re full of it. There\u2019s not a great description of him, but usually the words toad like and hooved come up."

    "And that scares you?"

    "No. What scares me is that Ayers wasn\u2019t sure it was him. Which means it could be something much, much worse." He got up from the table.

    "Where are you going to?" asked Geronimo.

    "I\u2019ve had a long day. I\u2019m going home. Just let me call the office."

    From the extension in the entry hall he dialed up Janet Rogers.

    "Yes, Jimmy?"

    "You busy tonight?"

    "No, Jimmy."

    "I\u2019ll be over in fifteen minutes." He paused. "Don\u2019t bother dressing to go out."

    \nEpisode II: Prisoners of Our Own Device (Part 13)

    Ruby woke up to another grey dawn. The cup of tea Althea brought her had more than enough honey but no Nectar. She understood vaguely that there would probably never be enough Nectar for her.

    "We destroyed the other vials," said Geronimo.

    "Good," said Ruby with all the cheer of a condemned man ordering his last meal.

    "Mr. Wright called. He said he talked to the people in the Federal building. Going there would have been a waste of time\u2014the safety deposit boxes are all in a warehouse in Long Beach."

    "I think a day trip would be very healthy for me."

    "Good. Jimmy will be here in a few minutes."

    All four of them rode down in Jimmy\u2019s large sedan. Jimmy kept up a light and bright patter, paying close attention to Ruby during the trip. She seemed much better without the temptation of nearby Nectar.

    [JP succeeded in Psychological Triage and restored some points of Stability to Ruby.]



    They spent the middle part of the day waiting for the bowels of the Federal bureaucracy to digest their request for the safety deposit box, but eventually a bored clerk brought it out to them. They drove down the coast a little bit and got rooms at a pleasant seaside motel.

    Inside the box, they found a great deal of photographs of people having sex, maddened, raving, passionate, insane sex. It was obvious that they were under the influence of Nectar. The photos were mostly taken in opulently decorated houses, and judging by the jewelry the women wore (they wore nothing else), the people involved were all well to do.

    One man recurred in most of the photographs\u2014a darkly handsome, well-built Latino man, almost certainly Ramon Echevarr\xeda.

    One blurry photo was of a man, still clothed, with a chubby, handsome face and curly blond hair. A note on the back indicated that it was of Richard Spend.

    "So that\u2019s what he looked like," said Jimmy. "All his movies were destroyed when the studios went out of business."

    Under the photos was a ledger book covering the years 1919-1926. It was clear they were accounts of some kind, but the entries are in code. On the inside of the cover is a nameplate indicating that they were prepared by an Abram Buchwald.

    "Isn\u2019t that your accountant?" Dr. Orange asked Jimmy, who shook his head in disbelief.

    They gave Ruby the account book to decode, to keep her mind busy. By evening she had gotten far enough to give them the name of another cult member: Samson Trammel. Jimmy called his office and put some of his operatives on tracking the distribution of Nectar. "Just don\u2019t take it. Don\u2019t look at it. Don\u2019t even smell it."

    "What is it, like heroin?" asked Eccleston, one of his better operatives.

    "Much worse. Take J. J. and Walsh with you."



    Betty drove Jimmy back to his apartment after dropping off Dr. Orange at Ruby\u2019s house. "Late night, Mr. J," she said. "Almost midnight."

    They pulled into the underground garage and Betty parked the car near the elevator bank. As Jimmy stepped out, he heard a shot go off, very nearby.

    From the shadows stepped Bethany Mae Hampton, holding a small but deadly-looking automatic pistol.

    "Why, hello Jimmy!" she said brightly. "How are tricks?"

    "Fine on my end. You?"

    "Just fine. But you need to stop what you\u2019re doing. It\u2019s not going to help anything. And just so that message comes through clear\u2014"

    She waved at the shadows with the hand not holding the gun. Three tough-looking men came running out. They had shaved heads and angry expressions. They looked like they were from Southeast Asia. They ran towards Jimmy almost on all fours.

    "Get down, Boss!" shouted Betty, bracing a shotgun on the roof of the car. She fired off both barrels as Jimmy flattened himself onto the pavement. Bethany screamed, and the toughs pulled up short.

    Jimmy rolled up to his feet clutching a crowbar he had snatched from the ground. He swung hard at the closest thug and connected solidly with the side of his head. The other two men threw open-hand strikes at him. These guys know what they\u2019re doing, he thought as they struck him. Probably know some kind of kung fu. He noticed an odd tattoo on the neck of the man he had clubbed.

    "Get in the car," he screamed at Betty. He swung his crowbar in a wide arc to create some distance between him and the men, and then jumped up on the running board. Betty peeled out, slamming the driver\u2019s door shut as they crested the ramp to the street.

    At a stoplight Jimmy pulled open the front door and slid into the passenger seat. "Did I do good, boss?" asked Betty. "It\u2019s in the handbook, the part Mr. O\u2019Donnell wrote: when transporting Firm executives, drivers will always keep a loaded shotgun in the car."

    "Glad you read all those books," said Jimmy. "Better head back to the office."

    Once he was back at his desk, he made a drink and looked through some of the books he kept in a locked cabinet. Finally he found the symbol he had seen tattooed on the man\u2019s neck. It was associated with an esoteric branch of Siamese Buddhism.

    "Let\u2019s take stock," said Ruby the next morning. Jimmy poured himself a cup of coffee as he sat down next to Dr. Orange. Geronimo pulled the curtains shut and quietly told Althea to leave them alone for a few hours.

    "What are our leads?" Ruby asked.

    "Samson Trammell," said Jimmy.

    "The Valley," said Dr. Orange.

    "We should go to the scene of the crime," said Geronimo.

    "I should contact Doug," said Jimmy. "And find out more about Anne Robinson." He rubbed his jaw where one of the thugs had hit him.

    "Then let\u2019s head out to the Valley today," said Ruby. She left to change into her visiting-a-farm outfit.

    Jimmy put in a long-distance call to Joy Grove. "You need to talk to who?" said Dr. Keaton.

    "Doug Henslowe."

    "Well, all right, if you boys up in Washington need us to help you\u2026"

    After a long wait, Doug came on. "You find it?"

    "Found it, and more."

    "It\u2019s still going on, isn\u2019t it."

    "Sure looks like it."

    "You going out to the Valley?"

    "Our next stop. I think I ticked Bethany off last night."

    "It\u2019s much easier to watch Edgar with her gone. You talk to Janet?"

    "I did. We had a nice conversation about her family."

    "Listen. We only dealt with the L. A. part. We had suspicions that they were into much bigger things."

    "Ethiopia?"

    "Maybe. Maybe the Far East as well. Be careful. And let me know what\u2019s going on."



    "It\u2019s a beautiful day," said Ruby as they drove out to the San Fernando Valley. "You know what would make it better?"

    "Forget it, Miss Fitzgibbons," said Geronimo.

    Jimmy handed a pistol to Dr. Orange and, after a moment, another one to Ruby. "Just in case," he said.

    He and Geronimo checked their own sidearms. "My office got back to me before we left," said Jimmy. "Richard Spend had a sister, she works as cleaning lady. Maybe we should check her out."

    They drove through some orange groves and pulled up onto the abandoned farm that had been the site of the 1926 massacre. They walked for a while until they came upon the burnt-out ruin of the farmhouse.

    "Anyone else notice that?" said Jimmy.

    "Something\u2019s off," said Dr. Orange. "It\u2019s\u2026eerie. I don\u2019t like the way things feel here."

    Nearby they could see a construction crew digging foundations on the next door lot. A man ambled over and waved his hand in greeting.

    "Can I help you?" he said in a broad Ozark accent. "You supposed to be on this property?"

    "Excuse me," said Ruby regally, "I just bought this property yesterday."

    "Well, you bought a hell of a property. I think it\u2019s kind of a pig in a poke, myself."

    "What are you guys doing?" asked Jimmy.

    "Putting in a new subdivision. Seems folks want to live all the way out here. Even fixing up the old power distribution station over there."

    "You know about this lot?"

    "Yeah, I know about this lot," said the man, rubbing his forehead and looking away.

    "You seem to know a lot about it," said Ruby. "I love a macabre story."

    [Assess Honesty use by RP indicated the worker was holding back.]

    "Well\u2026there\u2019s something wrong with this place. A couple of workers got bit by things\u2014snakes, a rabid dog. I have stay out here some nights. Pitched my tent here one night. I ain\u2019t Daniel, don\u2019t put much stock in dreams, but I ain\u2019t never want to have dreams like those again. And I haven\u2019t, cause I don\u2019t pitch my tent here no more."

    "I\u2019ve heard sometimes land can become cursed," said Ruby.

    A big man with a heavy potbelly rolled over to them. It cost him a lot of effort. He was wheezing like a steam tractor by the time he arrived. "All right, break it up you lazy bastard. Get back to work. And you! You got a reason to be out here? We got all our permits. It ain\u2019t safe for you to be out here."

    Jimmy noticed the foreman casing his car, almost as if he was trying to memorize his license plate number.

    "Let\u2019s take a walk," said Jimmy, leading the foreman away from the rest of them. "See that man?" he said, pointing at Geronimo. "I can barely keep him on his leash. Maybe it\u2019s time to take him off the leash, understand?"

    "Tall, curly hair. Kinda tough, but not tough tough. Read Jewish to me somehow."

    "Give me his number," said Jimmy, slipping the guy a twenty. "You never saw us."

    They spent some time walking around the lot. Dr. Orange took some samples of ash from the farmhouse. Suddenly Ruby screamed in pain.

    "That cat bit me!" she wailed.

    "We need to grab it for a rabies test," said Geronimo, chasing after the cat. He cornered it under a bush. The cat hissed at him. Its teeth were odd, jagged and longer than they should have been. He swept it up in his coat and carried it back to the others.

    [1-point Outdoorsman spend to catch the cat.]

    "Look at the mouth!" said Ruby. "It must be rabies! It\u2019s mutating!"

    "I heard a story about a mouth like that," said Jimmy. "Something about a mouth like that appearing during one of Echevarr\xeda\u2019s orgies."

    "Did it move? Did it speak?" said Geronimo, in a strained voice.

    "No. It appeared on the couch. And\u2026they said that the mouth was joining in the, uh, activities. It had a long tongue."

    "The couch joined in the orgy," said Ruby skeptically. "James, I thought I was the one with the problem."

    "Story I heard," said Jimmy.

    "Why are you interested, Geronimo?" asked Ruby.

    "Nothing. Just a ridiculous story."

    Jimmy pointed towards the ground. "Looks like some kind of cabling got run out here, a long time ago," he said. "From the power distributor they\u2019re fixing."

    The rabies test on the cat was negative. But everyone who saw the cat at the hospital was disturbed by its horrid, ragged teeth, and its sticky, far too long tongue.



    The next day Ruby called the number Jimmy had gotten from the foreman. The rest of them watched her from the living room couch. The phone rang once, and then a voice came on.

    "Trinity 6661," it said.

    "Yes, I\u2019m looking for a private investigator by the name of Jack," said Ruby, snuffling.

    "Who gave you this number?"

    "A man I met at a bar last night said I could find a good P. I. at this number."

    "Okay, lady, calm down."

    "I think he\u2019s cheating on me!"

    "Fine, lady. Tell you what. Meet me at the Santa Monica Pier. 5:30 tonight. Come alone. I see you with a tail, you ain\u2019t gonna find anyone. What\u2019s your name?"

    "Norma Jean."

    The phone rang off.

    "We\u2019re not letting you make the meet alone," said Jimmy after Ruby explained everything.

    "He\u2019ll never meet us if he sees a tail."

    "Leave it to us," said Geronimo.



    Ruby reached the Santa Monica pier at 5:30 pm exactly. As she made her way to the end of the pier, she had to fight back the urge to just run away and find some Nectar.

    "Steady old girl," she muttered, stopping near the railing by the side of the pier. "Keep it together."

    The sunset was especially beautiful that night. She watched the clouds and the sea for a long time, waiting. A young Mexican boy walked up to her and handed her a note.

    "What\u2014" she said, but the boy had already run off. Ruby studied it. It indicated a path behind some of the sheds and buildings at the very end of the pier. She flourished the note in the air and walked out to make her rendezvous.

    She squeezed through a narrow alley between two fish fry shacks and down a set of narrow stairs. She was on a landing a little below the level of the rest of the pier. Another flight of rickety stairs led down to a boat tie-up below. The tide was in, and waves crashed and foamed around the pilings of the pier.

    "Hold it right there," said a rough voice from behind her. "Don\u2019t move. Don\u2019t turn around. I\u2019m going to frisk you."

    She was patted down quickly and professionally. Whoever was behind her grabbed her handbag and rummaged through it. He laughed. "Hi, Ruby," he said. "Turn around."

    Ruby turned and saw a man standing in the shadows. He stepped forward slightly and the last light of sunset caught him in the face. He was tall, with curly hair, and a hang-dog face. He needed a shave. His heavy-lidded eyes were fixed on her. He had a mouth that was twisted by long habit into a smirk. He held a small snub-nosed revolver in his hand. At the moment it wasn\u2019t pointed at anything important to her, but she stayed very still.

    "How\u2019d you get that number?" he said.

    "That foreman you paid off gave it to me."

    "You can\u2019t keep anybody bought in this town. Ten bucks used to get you something." He put the pistol in his belt and lit a cigarette, never taking his eyes off of her. "Listen, you need to lay off this. You don\u2019t need to find out anything more about this. Keep this up, and you\u2019ll call the forces of hell down on you. I ain\u2019t working alone."

    "Look, I\u2019m not trying to start too much trouble, but some of our friends have been hurt by what\u2019s going on. We\u2019re just trying to make sure they\u2019re all right."

    "Lay off it already. You ever hear of Jimmy Wright?"

    Ruby boggled. "The name sounds familiar."

    "You screw with us, you\u2019re screwing with Jimmy Wright. You just keep that in mind. Now turn around."



    From his perch on top of the Hippodrome, Dr. Orange watched Ruby with binoculars. He saw her turn away from his line of sight. A tall man in an ill-fitting suit climbed up to the Pier and walked briskly towards the main drag. The man pulled his hat down and did his best to fit into the crowd.

    "Hello, my little friend," whispered Julius. "So you\u2019re the one who followed me to UCLA."

    He waved a handkerchief as the man passed a couple of fishermen standing next to the railing. Jimmy nodded, knowing Dr. Orange had him in sight, and started packing up the fishing rods while Geronimo slipped after the man.

    After a short walk, Geronimo\u2019s quarry got into a small black car and drove away from the pier. Geronimo jumped into Ruby\u2019s coupe and swung out after him, quickly catching up to him. He faded back, keeping a few cars ahead of him as he tailed the other man.

    They drove into the deepening twilight. The bright lights of Santa Monica faded behind them. The car pulled off into El Segundo. He followed it through an industrial neighborhood of rundown, almost identical warehouses.

    The other car parked in front of one of the warehouses. The driver got out, walked to a door in the side of the building and pressed a button next to it. He waited a moment, and then pulled the door open and stepped inside.



    "I have questions, Mr. Wright," said Ruby.

    "It\u2019s not James anymore?"

    "No. We need to have a conversation. A man held a gun to my face and told me I shouldn\u2019t get involved in this case because you would come down on me for it. That messing with him was messing with Jimmy Wright."

    "I have absolutely no idea what that means."

    "James, who are you working for?"

    "A dear friend of mine."

    "A man held a gun to my face. I\u2019m a little uneasy and out of Nectar. So I may not be responsible for my actions."

    "Tell me what he looked like." He waited for Ruby to finish embellishing the story of her encounter with him. "Sounds like I guy I looked into hiring once, a P. I. named Jack Pizner. I ended up deciding he was too rough for my crew. Why he\u2019s peddling my name around town I don\u2019t know."

    Ruby was about to say something cutting when Geronimo pulled up in her car. "Follow me," he said. "I found out where he works."

    Night had fallen by the time Jimmy, Ruby, Geronimo and Dr. Orange arrived at the warehouse. Jimmy raised his hand to the buzzer, paused for a long moment, and then stabbed at the button.

    There was a buzzing sound, and he heard the door unlatch.

    Inside was a dirty staircase ascending to another door, painted dull grey and with no sign on it. Jimmy pulled it open and saw a small entry way a beat-up steel desk was beside it, facing the door he had come through. Behind the desk was a man in a security guard\u2019s uniform, and behind him was a pair of double doors.

    "I\u2019m here to see Jack," said Jimmy.

    "He know you\u2019re coming?"

    "Just tell him Jimmy Wright is here."

    "Oh! I\u2019m sorry Mr. Wright, I didn\u2019t recognize you. Sure, come on in!" The guard got up and unlocked the doors and held them open as they passed through them.

    Jimmy blinked.

    Behind the door was an office reception area. The furniture was new and modern, all glass surfaces and chrome tubing. Sunken lights in the ceiling gave the area a warm glow. Behind a receptionist\u2019s desk sat a pretty young woman in rimless glasses. In back of her he saw an open space with several rows of desks, and doors that probably led to small offices ringing the area. There didn\u2019t seem to be any windows.

    Painted on the wall over the receptionist\u2019s desk was "Wright-O\u2019Donnell Investigations" in the curling script of his own logo. Beneath it, in small capitals, was printed "SPECIAL BRANCH".

    "We\u2019re here to see Jack," said Jimmy. The receptionist pointed him toward an office in the back. "Excuse me," she said as Ruby, Geronimo, and Dr. Orange walked past her. "Who are you people?"

    "We\u2019re with him," said Ruby imperiously.

    "What\u2019s going on?" Geronimo asked Jimmy.

    "I don\u2019t know\u2026unless it was Francis. My partner," he said. "The O\u2019Donnell part of the firm."

    Jimmy knocked on Pizner\u2019s door, and then strode in. The office was small and had no window. The carpet was new but dirty. A sweat-soaked shirt was tossed over a file cabinet, and papers were piled up on the straight-backed chair near the wall.

    "Whaddaya want?" barked Pizner. His feet were up on his desk and a bottle of whisky was parked near his phone. He practically folded in half when he recognized Jimmy. "Mr. Wright! I never thought I\u2019d have the honor of\u2026hey\u2026wait a minute! Ruby! What gives?"

    "He\u2019s escorting me," said Ruby, unable to suppress a smirk.

    "Well, I\u2019m confused," said Pizner, reflexively reaching for his bottle.

    "You\u2019re not the only one," said Jimmy, snatching it away. "What is this place?"

    "Huh? It\u2019s your office, Mr. Wright. We all work for you. This is Special Branch. We handle the tough cases, the stuff that needs to be hush-hush."

    "Did O\u2019Donnell hire you?"

    "I\u2019ve never met Mr. O\u2019Donnell."

    "Did I hire you?"

    "No, no you did not. You met with me, said that you\u2019d think about hiring me. Then I got a call. Some lady told me to come down to this place. They gave me a bunch of tests, and then they hired me."

    "What lady?"

    "Didn\u2019t get her name. Thought she was one of the receptionists."

    "The receptionists?"

    "I don\u2019t know any more than that!"

    "How come you know Ruby?"

    "I got orders to follow her, to follow the doc, and to stay away from the big guy because he was tough."

    "Who gave you the orders?"

    "I thought you did. I got them the normal way\u2014memo in my inbox, subject Ruby Fitzgibbons, subject Julius Orange. Standard operating. I\u2026I need to go make a phone call." He hopped out of his chair and tried to push his way to the door. Ruby stuck out her leg and tripped him.

    "Okay, okay," said Pizner after Jimmy pulled him off the floor. "I know why you\u2019re here, Mr. Wright. You have to understand, it started with me just doing favors for the guy. But then it got serious, and I had no way out! I had to keep giving him information."

    "Who are you working for!"

    "You! And, well, I work with a rough crowd. You need to have contacts when you do that. Feelers in the criminal network, like you wrote about in the FBI newsletter last month! I made contact with this guy in East L. A., up and coming gangster type."

    "Was his name Captain Walker?" asked Ruby.

    Pizner went pale. "You\u2019re sent by him," he said, eyes wild. "Tell him I didn\u2019t do anything wrong!"

    "What exactly did you do?" said Jimmy.

    "I would tell him what I was working on, and he\u2019d slip me some dough. If I had to bring in some skel, he\u2019d help out. He had a standing order that I should tell him if anyone looked into that farm or the police report about the massacre. Couple of days ago I got put on Ruby, so I told him. He seemed interested."

    "Mr. Wright," Geronimo whispered in Jimmy\u2019s ear, "I saw the receptionist call someone as soon as we left her desk. You should be alert."

    "Why are you using the name of Wright and O\u2019Donnell?" demand Jimmy.

    "I\u2014we work for you!"

    "You work for me by tailing my own friends?"

    "I didn\u2019t know they were with you! It\u2019s probably some kind of bureaucratic cockup," said Pizner, sweating.

    "I want a written report from you by tomorrow. On my desk," said Jimmy.

    "Your desk here, or in the other office?"

    "The other office\u2014I have a desk here?"

    Dr. Orange had spent the time watching the door to Pizner\u2019s office. He noticed that a steady stream of receptionists and typists were heading toward the back of the bullpen. He ducked his head out. The only people left on the floor were male Special Branch investigators.

    "Trouble," he said to his friends. "We should check the back door."

    Past the bullpen they found a narrow corridor that led to a locked door labeled "Maintenance". Ruby put her ear to it. "Betty, you destroy the last batch of files," said someone behind the door. She had a commanding tone. "Last one out, pull the fire alarm. We\u2019ll all meet downtown."

    "They\u2019re destroying files!" shouted Ruby.

    Jimmy and Geronimo kicked the door open. A bunch of women were tossing bundles of files into the incinerator chute. They took off as soon as they saw the men burst into the room.

    Ruby tackled one of the women, but the rest fled down the back stairs and scattered into the dark streets.

    "They had everything prepared for destruction," said Dr. Orange. "That\u2019s the kind of things we did in the Reichsbanner. That\u2019s real tradecraft! Counter-espionage protocols!"

    They dragged their prisoner with them to an office labeled "James Wright, Esq." The interior was extremely comfortable\u2014a clean, walnut desk, positioned beneath a skylight, with an elegant leather chair behind it.

    There was a sideboard and small bar. Jimmy noticed it was stocked with his favorite brand of whiskey.

    "Give me the room," said Dr. Orange grimly. He locked the door behind them, leaving him alone with the woman.

    "My name is Lucy Miller. I work for James Wright. My social security number is\u2014"

    "I never knew where it came from, and I don\u2019t have any now. I don\u2019t know where Ramon came from, how he made his money\u2014back in Mexico, I guess. One day at the end of 1925 I came to him. Told him I had the books done, but he didn\u2019t care. Abram, he says, in a few weeks we won\u2019t need to ever pay taxes again. I thought maybe we\u2019re going to move offshore. No, he tells me. Abram, you know I worship this god, Gol-Goroth. He\u2019s not really a god, but an intelligence from outer space beyond our puny capabilities."

    "He said that?" asked Dr. Orange.

    "He used to talk like that. There were all these people in the cult. God forgive me, I used to do what they did. I even took Nectar."

    "How did you get over it?" asked Jimmy.

    "It\u2019s not easy. Every day, I have to force myself not to go look for it. But I know that if I do, Esther will leave me. I\u2019ll never see my girls again, and since I\u2019m paying enough for their college I should be able to see them, yes? And my grandchildren, when I have them God willing\u2014"

    "Geronimo," said Ruby, "I think I need to marry a Jewish girl."

    "Anyway," said Buchwald, giving Ruby a disapproving look, "one day some men came around. Said they were cops, but me, I was not too sure. They acted more like\u2014well, more like how you act, Mr. Wright. There was a tall guy. German. You can always tell. And some big macher from New York, talked all tough. Ricky told me at a party, he saw them too. Echevarr\xeda didn\u2019t care. He told me that by the middle of January none of it would matter. Abram, he told me, those who follow me in the way of Gol-Goroth are deceived. None of them understand my real work. Prepare yourself. Prepare yourself for the end."

    "What do you think he meant?" asked Jimmy.

    "I didn\u2019t know. But I wrote him a nice letter of resignation, and never saw him again. And of course he died a few days later, in the middle of January. Such a shande."

    Silence fell heavily on all of them.

    "Do you have children, Mr. Wright?" Buchwald asked finally.

    "No. But I have a niece and nephew."

    "Watch over them well. Whatever Ramon was up to, it\u2019s not over yet. I know that at least one person from the old cult is up to something, that meshuggah Samson Trammell. Real estate guy, bought up a lot of land after Ramon died. Except. I did not know him well in those days, met him once or twice. One of my businesses is in the real estate line. At a closing, I met Samson Trammell. But it was not the man I knew as Samson Trammell."

    "Who was it?"

    "I don\u2019t know. He had all the paperwork to say he was Samson Trammell. What do I care, a name is as good as another. That\u2019s not what scares me. What scared me was later. I put on the radio, and I hear the voice of the man who said he was Samson Trammell, that same stupid Texas accent. Except he called himself Goodman Black."

    "I\u2019ve heard that name," said Jimmy.

    "Yes, Mr. Wright, I bet you have. He has his own radio program. A religious program. And from what I hear, he has a lot of people who worship with him now."
    \n

    \n So! Still waaay behind on the writeups, but Episode III is ready to start posting. In the campaign itself, we're through the sixth episode and things are probably about to take a left hand turn into the weird.

    Without further ado, Episode III, wherein we visit the Temple of Joy, Millicent learns a shocking truth about herself, and we get a glimpse of what makes all that Nectar...

    \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Prologue)

    Scientists tell me that most human emotions are caused by various chemicals. "It\u2019s all hormones," they\u2019ll say, or neurological feedback mechanisms, or imprinting. Corner a Freudian and they\u2019ll blubber something about dreams and mothers and maybe even make you think they actually believe all that. But bottom line, it\u2019s all a biological process. Things click when they come in range, or they don\u2019t.

    But you just try telling people about that. I mean, they just won\u2019t believe you. Sure, I can see the ones who have something at stake\u2014it would about put half of Hollywood out of business, not to mention all those dime store novels you can pick up. Somebody\u2019s writing and printing those, though it\u2019s my guess that they\u2019re a lot more clear-headed about the whole operation than those who watch or read that stuff. But most people? They\u2019ll either babble on about free will, or about having been fated to meet someone (who just happened to live in the same town, and come from a pretty similar family, and know a lot of the same people; honey, I know about fate, and that\u2019s not what it looks like.) That those two positions are really incompatible doesn\u2019t faze them at all. But that\u2019s human beings for you; never let the pesky details get in the way of a good story.

    Maybe that\u2019s why Ruby and company were so scared of Nectar. I mean, when you get down to it, what harm was it doing? It just made you want to do the thing everybody says they enjoy doing more than anything else. Everyone\u2019s happy while you\u2019re on it. You have a good time. And if you feel bad after, well, just take some more. And it\u2019s the exact same excuses about how love can\u2019t be chemicals\u2014free will, fate, blah blah blah. Even after you\u2019ve pretty much conclusively demonstrated that it really is just chemicals.

    People! You got to love them, am I right? Either that or run around with an ice pick.

    \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 1)

    Millicent was having breakfast in the House refectory. It was the first day of the new term, and several of her friends were buzzing excitedly about taking Archaeology that morning.

    "What\u2019s so great about that class?" she asked. It was her first class that day.

    "You\u2019ll see," said an upperclassman with a smirk.

    And she did, a half hour later, when the door to the lecture hall opened and a handsome man in his mid-forties stepped in front of the blackboard. He was tall, black-haired except for a distinguished touch of grey at his temples. "Good morning," he said in a French accent that probably revved the engines of most of the girls like a race car. "My name is Dr. Luc Fauche. Now, who here knows anything about ancient Ethiopia?"

    Millicent shot her hand up. "There was something called the Axum Empire there."

    "Very good! Excellent!" Dr. Fauche looked quite impressed.

    After class, he beckoned her over. "Every year I take a student as an assistant. I would like you to be my aide this year, if you can."

    "Thank you, yes!"

    "Bon. This is Marie Forgeron, my graduate assistant," he said, indicating a young woman in her mid-twenties.

    "Bon jour," she said diffidently. Millicent thought her accent sounded colonial\u2014maybe R\xe9union or one of the African colonies.

    [1-point Languages spend by MP to recognize the accent. Forgeron is a little allusion to the last campaign\u2014she\u2019s the daughter of Francis O\u2019Donnell\u2019s friend, Guy.]

    "Ah, and Miss Lowell? We\u2019re doing a little exhibition of Egyptian artifacts at the library. Perhaps you could assist?"

    "It would be my pleasure," said Millicent. She had to fight herself to keep from floating out the door.\n

    \n

    \n


    "Miss, I need you to turn around carefully," said a man behind Millicent.

    She turned slowly. She was wearing her nightgown. Behind her, a concerned security guard was holding a flashlight on her.

    She was standing in the middle of the ancient Egyptian exhibit in the school library.

    Her hands were bloody.

    "What am I doing in the library?" she said.

    "You tell me," said the guard. "But looks like you smashed open a pane in the door with your hands there."

    The room spun and went black.

    She came to in a bed in the school infirmary. Her advisor was sitting by the bed. "Millicent, why did you break into the library?" she said.

    "I don't know!"

    "Is there a history of somnambulism in your family?"

    "I...don't know."

    "Well, under the circumstances, maybe it would be better if you went back to Los Angeles for a while."

    "But what about Dr. Fauche! I promised to be his assistant!"

    "I'm sure he'll understand."

    "Maybe I can have Senator Grey write him for me."

    The older woman stiffened. "Actually, I believe Dr. Fauche is on his way to Los Angeles in a few weeks. I'm sure he'll be happy to bring you back to school. Don't worry about anything."
    \n

    \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 2)

    They day after they talked to Buchwald, Jimmy nervously made his way into the office. He tried not to cringe when the receptionists offered him coffee. In his office he found Ruby reading one of the recruitment pamphlets he liked to hand out to detectives who looked like they wanted some extra work.

    "James," she said, "How long does it take to become a private eye? Can I do it in an afternoon? I already have a hat, does that help? Also\u2026it might keep my mind off of certain other obsessions of mine."

    Jimmy tossed her one of the Junior Detective badges he kept around to hand out to schoolkids. "Here you go. You\u2019re an honorary PI."

    Jack Pizner slouched into the room, looking as guilty as a hanged man and about as lively. "I got that report you asked me to write," he told Jimmy.

    "I shouldn\u2019t have asked you to come here," said Jimmy. "Now you\u2019re blown. Let me see what you\u2019ve got."

    The list was interesting. It seemed that his clandestine branch had solved several cases that he hadn\u2019t been able to crack. It also was obvious that Pizner had been giving Walker information for several years.

    "None of the receptionists showed up at the other office today," said Pizner. "Weird, yeah?"

    "Yeah. Keep in touch, okay?"\n

    \n

    \n


    Dr. Orange went down to the Los Angeles FBI office. The agents tried to give him the bum\u2019s rush, but Top Secret clearances go a long way with the Feds. He played his into a long look at everything the Bureau had on Goodman Black/Samson Trammell. It wasn\u2019t much, mostly adding up to "harmless crackpot," although there was some poking around in his real estate affairs. The connection with Captain Walker was noted, along with the belief that Walker was fleecing Black\u2019s richer clientele for security payments.

    One thing that stuck out was the large building Black owned in Echo Park called the "Temple of Joy." He was able to pull some architectural plans for the Temple building, and made copies of whatever Hoover\u2019s boys left unattended.

    [2-point Bureaucracy spend by OP; I ended up giving him a pool of points to use vs. Samson Trammell.]\n

    \n

    \n


    "Boss, we trailed those skels you put us on out to Echo Park, believe it or not," said J.J.\u2019s voice over the phone. "Ecclestone's gonna check out some addresses and Walsh and I will tail them further."

    "Remember keep your distance," said Jimmy. "Oh, and when you get back, I need you to check into a sorority for me."

    "Sure...though boss, why don't you put one of the girls on it?"

    "They're busy," said Jimmy quickly, and rang off.\n

    \n

    \n


    Dr. Orange arrived at Jimmy's office to find the familiar feeling of a siege. Amateurs, he thought, remembering his days running from the Nazis. He quickly briefed the others on what he had found out from the FBI.

    "Wait, did you say Echo Park?" said Jimmy. "I've got my guys tracking nectar shipments to there."

    "I may not be a private investigator--" said Julius.

    "I am," said Ruby.

    "--but I think there's a connection there."

    As if on cue, the phone rang.

    "Boss, boss!" shouted Walsh on the other end. "Boss, they got J.J.!"

    "Where are you?"

    "I...oh God, they're here!"

    Jimmy heard the phone drop and dangle against the side of the phone booth. From somewhere near the receiver came the sound of a shot. He heard slow footsteps approach the phone, and then it was quietly hung up.

    "Let's go," said Jimmy. He led them on the run to the garage. Betty was leaning against the car, reading a Porky Pig comic.

    "Boss?" she said.

    Jimmy popped open the trunk of the car and took out a couple of shotguns. He handed them to Geronimo and Dr. Orange. "Echo Park," he said, jumping into the back seat.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
    \n
