    \n
    \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 3)

    Betty pulled up next a car that had crashed into a telephone pole. The driver's side window had a huge hole in it.

    "Shotgun blast," said Jimmy. He pointed at the bloody body slumped over the steering wheel. "That was J.J."

    A cop was directing traffic away from the crash site. Geronimo spoke quickly with him.

    "Probably a gang hit," said the cop. "Somebody blasted him as he was going along the street. There's reports of gunshots a couple of blocks over, in the park."

    Geronimo slipped him a fiver. "I'm going to take a look. Guy was a colleague."

    Inside the car he found a scribbled map, covered in blood, at J.J.'s feet. He gave it to Jimmy, and then they headed out toward the park.

    "Blood," muttered Jimmy as they entered the park, pointing at streaks of red near the path.

    There was a gang of zoot-suited men a couple of hundred feet inside the park. Ruby strode up to them, her best getting-to-know-you grin plastered on her face. "Oh dear, did you hear the shots?" she said to them.

    "We heard the shots," said one of the men. "This is a dangerous place for you to be, lady. Not safe."

    "Oh, my goodness. Well, I'm glad you're here to watch out for trouble," she said as disingenuously as possible.

    "Yeah, you should stay here. Or maybe go to a cafe. You like cerveza? we could get a beer..."

    [Flattery use by RP.]

    Dr. Orange skulked around the crowd and managed to scramble up onto a bench. He saw a body at the center of the crowd. As he watched, one of its hands moved a little.
    Captain Walker and large men generously wrapped in gabardine arrived and stopped in front of Jimmy.

    "Mr. Wright," said Walker.

    "I want my man," said Jimmy.

    "And what should induce me to do you this favor, considering that we have already taken care of one of your investigators."

    "You mess with one of mine, and I'll mess with you."

    "I am messing with you, Mr. Wright. But I can understand wanting your man back. I will be happy to give him back. But you will stop your investigation of me, or there will be consequences. And I don't make threats, sir. I make promises. Vamanos," said Walker, gathering his troops around him.

    As soon as they left, Jimmy and Dr. Orange rushed in and carried the badly wounded Walsh back to the car. Betty floored it and they sped towards the nearest hospital.
    \n
    \n
    \n

    \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 4)

    Much to her surprise, Millicent found Ruby behind Jimmy's desk when she arrived at the office. Geronimo lounged nearby, smoking.

    "Hello?" said Ruby into the phone, waving Millicent towards the couch. "No, we can't do that. Well, he's probably cheating on you, that's why. Honey, go down to the salon, get yourself made up, and find a man to make the same mistake he did. Oh, and tell your husband I voted for him."

    "You're manning the office, Miss Fitzgibbons?" asked Millicent.

    "James and I are now partners."

    "Oh, that's good news, isn't it?"

    "Yes. He made that noise he makes when he's pleased."

    "The one he made around the studio?"

    "That's the one. What are you doing back in LA, dear?"

    "I seemed to have sleepwalked...sleptwalked...in any case, I broke into the library. But before that I was trying to find out about that sorority. Oh, and I'm working for a really dreamy Frenchman, he's our archaeology teacher. I'm his assistant..."

    Professor--French--Dreamy, wrote Ruby on a pad. "There's something very strange afoot. Did you do anything unusual? Take any drugs? Read anything with strange writing on it?"
    "Just hieroglyphics."

    "There's a web, Geronimo," said Ruby. "A web."

    "I haven't heard anything inexplicable," said Geronimo.

    "I know! I'll hypnotize her! Then we can find out what happened!"\n

    \n

    \n


    At the hospital, a surgeon found Jimmy. "I'm sorry, Mr. Wright, the damage was too severe. We've made him comfortable."

    "I understand," said Jimmy.

    [OP: He got shot in the plot!]

    Jimmy sat down next to Walsh's bed.

    "I'm sorry," croaked Walsh. "It's the temple, Boss. That's where the drugs are coming from."

    "I saw the files," said Jimmy. "We're going to get them where it hurts."

    Walsh nodded, and closed his eyes. After a moment longer, he stopped breathing.\n

    \n

    \n


    As he stepped off the elevator, several of Jimmy's receptionists mobbed him, shoving phone messages at him:

    WHO'S ANSWERING THE PHONE FOR YOU?

    WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON?

    WHO'S RUBY?

    Jimmy hurried into his office. The blinds were drawn and the room was dim. He saw Ruby waving a watch in front of Millicent's eyes. "You are getting sleepy...sleepy..." said Ruby. "You will recall all the events of the night you broke into the library."

    Slowly, haltingly, Millicent described waking up suddenly and feeling like something was moving her limbs...something compelling her, almost against her will, forcing her to walk out of her dormitory and break into the library.

    As the full horror of what had happened hit her, she screamed, jolting out of the trance.

    [4 point Stability loss for remembering what happened. And at this point, I charged Jimmy a point of Stability and Doc Orange and Geronimo a point each, to cover Walsh's death.]

    Ruby poured Millicent a drink. Jimmy shrugged and poured himself one. He sat staring glassy-eyed as Millicent explained about her research on the Epsilon Sigma and why she had been sent back early from school.
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
  • \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
    \n
    \n\nMay 2015 \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n
    \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 5)

    "What station does this Goodman Black broadcast on?" asked Ruby.

    "KLAX," said Jimmy.

    "Oh, good. I know the owner." She picked up the phone and quickly dialed a number. "Max? Ruby."

    "Haven't heard from you in forever! You having one of those charming garden parties? With the bowl of cocaine?"

    "Not until the weather gets better. Listen, darling, I've found myself lately quite taken with radio. Do you think I could drop by the station and see how things are done?"

    "Of course. When were you thinking?"

    "I have a late lunch, so...around six PM."

    "Uh...that might not work that well. Why don't you come the day after--"

    "Max, I understand, and for you--anything. I'll move my lunch and come a little earlier."

    "Actually, it's really not such--"

    "What? Geronimo? Sorry, I have to go, Max."

    [Credit Rating spend by RP to create a useful contact.]

    Geronimo looked up from his crossword puzzle long enough to shake his head sadly. As soon as Ruby put the phone back in its cradle it rang again. Jimmy scooped it up. "I answer the phones in this office, all right?" he said, glaring at Ruby. "Jimmy Wright."

    "Mr. Wright, this is Lt. Lou Escobar of the LAPD. I just found a dead man on Route 1. Had your card in his wallet. Fellow by the name of Pizner. Maybe we should talk about it."

    "Howabout lunch?"

    "Howabout you meet me at the station."\n

    \n

    \n


    An hour later Jimmy found himself sitting in an interrogation room faced by Escobar. He was a tough cop; Jimmy recognized the type immediately, the kind that had gotten his start in the back alleys and tough streets of East LA and Chinatown. He had the sadness honest cops get when they\u2019ve been on those beats for too long, the resignation of a man who is corrupt and can no longer even want to be something other than he is, but still remembers the kind of man he wanted to be. Sitting on a stool in the corner was a big uniformed cop named O'Malley. He had a pleasant, open face, and hands that had been broken in fist fights many times.

    [Escobar is the same character from Chinatown.]

    "So tell me what this guy was doing for you," said Escobar.

    "What do private eyes do?"

    "Tell me what he was doing today."

    "He was helping me investigate the relative of a client."

    "And that got him killed?"

    "Sometimes things go deeper than we expect."

    "Seems a lot of people are dying around you lately, Mr. Wright. A couple of your guys got shot up in Echo Park yesterday. Scared a lot of nice people." Escobar slammed a fist on the table. "Tell me what they were working on! I want names!"

    "There's a new drug in town. It's horrible. One try and you're hooked. I had them looking into it."

    "I didn't notice you getting posted to the Vice Squad. What was this skel Pizner looking into, and what were Walsh and Jackson up to?"

    "Walsh and Jackson were following leads, nothing else."

    "I'm sorry," said Escobar. "I have to turn my back now."

    O'Malley stepped up to the table. "Sorry about this, Jimmy." He smashed a meaty fist into Jimmy's face, knocking him out of his chair.

    Jimmy struggled back into his seat. His jaw slowly moved back into its normal place. It hurt a little less than falling off a cliff. "The drug is what did it. Following it got them hurt."

    "That's not your concern. You know you're supposed to bring this to us."

    "How much do you know about these zoot suiters," said Jimmy.

    "Oh, them. I better go clear this with my Captain." Escobar opened the door, paused for a moment, and then nodded at O'Malley as he left.

    "I have a lot of respect for you, Mr. Wright," said O'Malley, rolling up his sleeves. "But now I gotta hurt you."

    It was a professional beating; Jimmy never blacked out. After twenty minutes they tossed him into a holding cell to think things over.

    Eternal Lies: Masks of the Liar [Trail of Cthulhu]

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 6)

      Ruby, Dr. Orange, and Geronimo pulled up to the studios of KLAX. A large bus was parked out front, slathered with images of the Reverend Doctor Goodman Black. Max met them in the green room.

      "This is really not a good time, Ruby," he said. "Dr. Black doesn't like to be disturbed during broadcasts." He nodded at the door to the studio. Two large men stood by it, looking uncomfortable because their jackets only reached their thighs. They were clearly Walker\u2019s men.

      "Is that a chorus I hear?" said Ruby, cocking an ear at the monitor speaker.

      "Yeah, the Doctor likes to bring them down as backing," said Max.

      Dr. Orange listened to the hymn. He was reasonably familiar with most Christian hymns. This song, with its repeated references to "The Mouth of God" didn't sound like any hymn he knew.

      [Theology use by OP.]

      "Excuse me," he said. "I need to get some coffee."

      After another fifteen minutes, the door to the studio opened and a tall, gaunt man in a black suit, surrounded by a coterie of secretaries and what Ruby guessed were lay ministers, emerged.

      "All right, all right, all right," Dr. Black said. "Good show tonight, everyone."\n

      \n

      \n


      Dr. Orange made his way downstairs to a coffee shop next door to KLAX. He ordered a cup of coffee, picked up the sugar shaker, and then dropped it in his coat pocket when the waitress turned around.

      He slipped outside and nonchalantly leaned against the side of the bus. He unscrewed the gas cap and poured the entire contents of the shaker into the gas tank.\n

      \n

      \n


      "Here you go, my dear," said Goodman Black, passing an autographed flyer to Ruby. She glanced at it:

      REVIVAL MEETING! THIS SATURDAY AT THE TEMPLE OF JOY!

      They followed Black and his disciples downstairs and watched them board the bus. It drove slowly up the avenue. After several blocks it slowed down and stopped by the curb. The driver stepped out and opened the hood of the bus. He rubbed his head with a puzzled expression on his face.

      Right on time, thought Dr. Orange, stepping off the curb and holding his paper cup of coffee. "Can I be of assistance?"

      "You know anything about engines, Mac?"

      "Of course! You can't be an engineer without knowing engines! Although I mostly deal with quantum mechanics."

      The driver looked at him, puzzled.

      "I make a little joke. Let me have a look."

      "Can you do anything? The boss wants to get out of here as soon as possible."

      Dr. Orange poked around for a few minutes. "Looks like you got some bad gas," he said.

      Goodman Black and two of his security guards were waiting by the door of the bus. "Any chance we can get this thing moving? I need to get back to the temple."

      "The temple?"

      "Yes. I'm a reverend. Dr. Goodman Black."

      "Ah! I'm Dr. Orange!"

      "How providential. Well, I have many talents, but I guess I can't resurrect this vehicle if you can't. My people can take public transport...I guess I'll have to hire a car."

      "My friends are coming along, they can drive you back."

      "If it's not any trouble. And I'd have to bring my men..."

      "Oh, it's a big car."

      They walked back to the studio and found Ruby and Geronimo leaning against their car. "Y'all were up in the studio," said Black.

      "I was visiting my friend Max," said Ruby.

      "Ah, he's a good man. I just wish he'd hear the call. Still, he lets me get out the good word."\n

      \n

      \n



      Escobar dropped in on Jimmy's holding cell. He stood watching him for a long moment, smoking down a cigarette. "You know, you make a big deal out of how you're Jimmy Wright, an honest man. But the first little sign of trouble and what do you do? Lean on your friends. I don't need this kind of trouble. They don't pay me enough."

      He unlocked the cell. "Go home, Mr. Wright."

      "No handshake?"

      "Get the hell out of my station."

      Jimmy sauntered out of the front door of the police station and walked briskly for a few blocks before almost collapsing against the wall of an apartment building. He hailed a cab, wincing as he raised his arm, and took it back to the office.

      He found Millicent asleep on a couch. He was pulling up a blanket over her when she opened her eyes. "Mr. Wright! You're safe!"

      "Yeah. I think maybe because of you."

      "So I was right to call the station and tell them Senator Grey was expecting you tomorrow?"

      "It got me out. Where's Ruby and Geronimo?"

      "They went with Dr. Orange to the radio station."\n

      \n

      \n


      Geronimo drove into Echo Park. The Temple of Joy was on a hill, with several acres of grounds hidden behind a brick wall. Two tough-looking men were standing next to the front gate.

      They drove up to the Temple itself. It was a large building with a silver-plated dome on top. Dr. Black stepped out of the car. "Well, thank you for the drive--"

      "Oh, couldn't we stop in for a drink of water?" asked Ruby, smiling her most seductive grin.

      "I...of course. We'll go in the servant's entrance," said Black, non-plussed. He opened a door on one wing of the building and led them into a large lounge. A bar took up most of one wall. Fresco paintings of saints and biblical scenes dominated the walls. For some reason, Ruby was unnerved by them--there was something wrong about their mouths, though she couldn't quite figure out what. There was also a faint--not odor, but presence of Nectar.

      A great empty space loomed to one side--the sanctuary, dimly lit.

      "Dr. Black," said Geronimo. "I admire your work here. As a man of God myself, I appreciate your difficulties. Our friend Dr. Orange is very interested in learning about your denomination. Do you think he might join your congregation?"

      "Well, we recommend that people listen to the radio program or attend some services."

      "He was hoping to come to the revival meeting."

      "That's really supposed to be for our more...dedicated members."

      "Dr. Black," said Ruby, "every year my family makes a donation to a charity. Perhaps your church could be the beneficiary this year?"

      "I see. Let me get you our recommendation donation list," said Goodman Black.

      Ruby paled slightly as she looked over the sheet Black handed her. "Well. A good thing I brought my checkbook."

      [Two point Credit Rating spend by RP.]

      When she had finished filling out the check and handed it--with some reluctance--to Black, he turned and put a hand on Dr. Orange's shoulder. "Now, I can't fully initiate you into our church in one night. This is a process that takes a great deal of time; one must make a vigil for an entire night, and it all must be approached in a spirit of absolute dedication and faith. But perhaps, if you wished to stay, I could perform a baptism on you tonight, and instruct you in a few of our rites."

      "Yes," said Julius, nervously. "I'm sure my faith will carry me through."

      "I'm sure it will," said Dr. Black, not at all ominously. "You can pick up your friend in the morning."

      [I kinda botched this sequence a bit--and I've since notified everyone that I will be using the "Getting captured nets you information and a refresh" rules from Night's Black Agents. However, I was painted a bit in a corner here--the obvious thing to do would be to either shoot Dr. Orange and toss him in the basement, or give him Nectar and hook him on the drug. I did charge OP a point of Flattery to keep the first option off the table.

      Still, it would have been better to go a bit more with the flow here than I did.]

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 7)

      "So I think the plan is to lay in ambush near the Temple of Joy and then bust out the doctor," said Ruby.

      "Do you think that's necessary?" said Geronimo. "Maybe we should just find a hotel to lay low in."

      "Let's call James," said Ruby, pulling over in front of a coffee shop. She ran inside, sat down in the phone booth, composed herself, and then dialed the number.

      "Mr. Wright's office," said Millicent on the other end.

      "I need to speak to James."

      "He's a bit under the weather after his conversation with the LAPD."

      "He's definitely going to want to hear this. We left Dr. Orange with possibly a cult."

      Millicent repeated it back slowly. There was a spluttering noise in the back ground, and the sound of the receiver being snatched up.

      "James, are you well?" asked Ruby.

      "No. Yes. No. Where are you?"

      "Near Echo Park. We met with Dr. Black and created a plan on the fly to have the professor stay overnight to be baptized."

      "By himself?"

      "Yes, and it cost me a great deal to get even that. We can talk about my expense account later."

      "You are not breaking in there," said Jimmy.

      "Well, that was my suggestion. But why don't you meet us here, we can have a little bit of dinner, and decide what to do."

      "You left him without a weapon--tools--any way of calling for help...don't move. I'll be there in ten minutes."\n

      \n

      \n


      "Follow me, doc," said Goodman Black. He took Julius across the vast, shadowy vault of the sanctuary.

      "Where are your Bibles?" asked Dr. Orange.

      "We don't leave them out. It's a neatness thing." Black led them into a vestibule, and beyond that into a large office. Bookcases full of old books dominated an entire wall. There was an expensive teak desk at the far end of the room, and beyond that a glass door leading into a conservatory area. There didn't seem to be many plants in it.

      "This is my office," said Black. "We'll do the baptism here. I need you to put on this white robe--but you need to be wearing only this robe. Can't have any contamination from the outside world. It's symbolic of your transformation into a new being."

      Black seemed to be without modesty; he quickly stripped off all his clothes and threw on a robe identical to the one he had given Julius except for a red oval-shaped symbol over the chest.

      "Where's the water?" asked Dr. Orange.

      "We use the holy water of God. I don't need much for this. You might say I'm a bit of a fundamentalist like that." He ducked around a bookshelf and came back with two small vials of a honey-colored liquid. A strong mossy smell came from them, something that reminded Julius of something that he couldn't quite place.

      "You might say this is a variation on the Eucharist and baptism in the same rite," said Black. "We will both drink of the holy water of God, and then be together in God."

      "This all seems very Catholic!" said Dr. Orange.

      "I assure you, this has nothing to do with Rome. Now, are you in or out? They said you were a man of God."

      Julius looked down, abashed.

      "Do you feel you're not ready to make this choice yet?" said Dr. Black. He threw an arm compassionately over Julius' shoulders.

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 8)

      "I don't see why we couldn't finish dinner," said Ruby as Jimmy's armored sedan sped toward the Temple of Joy.

      "We have to get the doctor. Take that turn, Betty."

      The car sped up a slight ridge and stopped. From this vantage point they could see the entire Temple grounds--and the flashlights of the patrols walking along the walls.

      "Damnit," said Jimmy, fishing around for binoculars. "Wish I could see what they were armed with."

      They sat for a long time, watching the house. "James," said Ruby, "I've been paying attention to the pattern here and I think I know when the best time to try and make our way to the Temple."

      "Really?"

      "Observation is part of this job, isn't it?"

      [Shadowing test by RP.]\n

      \n

      \n


      "I think I need some time to mull this over," said Julius. "I know your rite says that private meditation in the Sanctuary helps bring you closer to God."

      Black took a long look at the vials, and then capped them. "I suppose we can give God fifteen minutes."

      As they walked back into the Sanctuary, Dr. Orange could hear the faint sounds of people moving around in the floor above Black's office.

      [OP made a spend from his 3-point "Stuff about the Temple of Joy" pool he got with his earlier Bureaucracy spend.]\n

      \n

      \n


      Jimmy, Ruby, Millicent, and Geronimo ran up the hill towards the Temple. "Down!" hissed Jimmy, and the flashlight beams of a patrol swept just over their heads as they crouched on the ground.

      "They're watching the gate more than anything else. Let's head for the conservatory," said Jimmy.

      [Sense Trouble test by JP to find the best route. They made a Stealth test to get up the hill, rolled by GP with MP helping out--Jimmy and Ruby don't have any Stealth.]

      They quickly forced the conservatory door and made their way into Black's office. Ruby's nose crinkled as the smell of Nectar hit her.

      Jimmy looked around. "Oh boy. It's never good when they have this many books."

      "I wonder what they're about?" whispered Millicent.

      "You are not reading those, young lady."

      Ruby gulped as Geronimo capped the vials and put them in the desk. "No, Miss Fitzgibbons."

      [So, TN 5 Stability test to resist Nectar for RP, but then I kicked back a point of Stability because Ruby is clearly following her Adventure drive. At this point I hit Dr. Orange with a Soft Driver to try and get a better look at the books, but OP paid that off quickly.]

      "Aren't those Dr. Orange's clothes?" said Jimmy.

      "I think Dr. Black was wearing that suit," said Millicent, pointing at a different pile of clothes.

      "We better get him," said Jimmy.

      "Could I just grab something to read--" said Ruby.

      "No!" hissed Jimmy and Geronimo at the same time.

      They made their way to edge of the Sanctuary. Geronimo and Millicent crept into the shadows, slinking against opposite walls of the large room. Jimmy and Ruby stepped out into the middle of the room.

      Goodman Black looked up. "What are you doing here?" He began edging towards one wall. Millicent could see a small handle on it, like a fire alarm.

      Ruby jumped in his way. There was a flurry of hands, and then she had Black in an arm lock.

      "Aaagh! Help, help!" shouted Black. Jimmy tried to clap a hand over his face, but the Reverend bit him.

      Dr. Orange could hear the pounding of feet on stairs, coming up from some hidden basement. He sprinted toward the office.

      Black punched Jimmy in the face and snapped out of Ruby's armlock. He and Jimmy spun around as two men in zoot suits carrying Thompsons burst out of doors on either side of the choir platform.

      Millicent slid away from the wall, came up behind Black, and cracked him over the back of the head with her tennis racket. He stumbled but darted for a door on the side of the Sanctuary, disappearing from view.

      Jimmy heard the distinctive sound of a Thompson being cocked. He and Ruby dropped to the ground as bullets smashed into the floor around them.

      Geronimo stepped away from the wall, his big Russian 9mm barking as he shot at one of the thugs, who fell back behind the a pillar. Jimmy fired off a burst from his Army Colt, but the zoot suiter was too well-covered.

      Ruby pulled her little pistol from her bag and fired some desperate shots off to try and cover Jimmy and Geronimo. Behind her the front doors opened. She cast a nervous glance back there to see Captain Walker and two of his guards step inside the Temple.

      Walker calmly considered the scene in front of him. "Matalos," he said. His men leveled their Thompsons and fired several bursts into the room. Jimmy and Millicent found cover near the vestibule door, but were pinned down by the crossfire.

      [Jimmy and Millicent both took some damage here, but not enough to go negative.]

      Geronimo pulled something out of his pocket and skimmed it across the floor. "Viva la Revolucion," he said, running across the room, as the grenade rolled to a stop near Walker's feet.

      [Preparedness roll by GP to have a grenade; the roll was a 6, which wasn't the TN, but then I realized it would be pretty cool for Geronimo to be carrying around a dud--after all, nobody else knows it doesn't work!]

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 9)

      The Captain and his two thugs ran for the front door. Millicent dragged Jimmy, who had caught a bullet in the last fusillade, into Black's office. Geronimo fired a snapshot over his shoulder at one of the remaining zoot suiters. He slammed the door behind him just as one of them said, "It's a dud!"

      After a moment there was a roar of automatic fire, and bullets ripped through the door to the office. "Up!" said Jimmy, pointing at a small circular wrought-iron staircase. Ruby, Millicent, and Geronimo clattered up it.

      "Aren't you coming?" asked Geronimo.

      "I'm getting our escape route!" said Jimmy, dashing out the conservatory door followed by Millicent. There were some bursts of gunfire from outside.

      The remaining three found themselves in a sitting room. It had expensive but ill-treated furniture, mostly armchairs. On the floor were three or four couples, writhing in sexual heat.

      "Strip!" said Ruby. "We have to blend in!"

      They tore off their clothes. Ruby pulled Dr. Orange and Geronimo to her. "Make out with me!" she whispered to Geronimo.

      Two gunmen and Walker came up the staircase. "We have the boss," said Walker in Spanish. "The intruders must have gone around. Find them!"

      He turned to go. "These people disgust me. One of you stay here. I have to take care of the boss. He's hysterical."\n

      \n

      \n


      "Holy shit, Mr. J!" said Betty as Jimmy and Millicent limped up to the car. Jimmy pulled open the door and shoved Betty over while Millicent slipped into the back. Without a word, Jimmy yanked the car into gear and drove down the ridge.

      "What are we doing, boss?" whispered Betty as he pulled the car in front of the gates to the Temple and stopped. One of the guards began to move toward the car, fishing into his coat.

      Jimmy threw the car into reverse and backed down the street quickly. He jabbed at the clutch and the car burned rubber as it shot squealing toward the gates.

      He was doing 40 when the car hit the gates, smashing them open. He hit 50 on the driveway as bullets rained down on the car, starring the windows. He grimaced as he pulled the emergency brake and fishtailed to a stop in front of the Temple.

      [3 points of damage to Jimmy on the way up, which put him negative, but JP spent a point of health to, as I put it, make a Humphrey Bogart grimace while staying conscious.]

      "That's our ride!" said Dr. Orange. As the man guarding them ran to the window to see what was happening outside, Geronimo stood up and gave him a sharp push through the open window.

      Dr. Orange picked up their clothes. Ruby slipped up to a closed door on one side of the sitting room and opened it a crack. Inside was some kind of bedroom. The floor was undulating.

      She looked closer. It was carpeted with writhing human bodies, engaged in every form of sexual congress imaginable. The heady scent of Nectar hit her like a physical blow.

      "Come on!" hissed Geronimo. With a shudder, she slammed the door shut and dashed down the stairs.

      As soon as Ruby and company were in the car, Betty clambered over Jimmy and sped down the driveway. Bullets rained down on all sides, but the armor held. They burst through the wrecked gates and quickly disappeared into the California night.

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 10)

      They pulled into a garage in an out of the way part of Culver City.

      "Arturo!" said Jimmy as he limped out of the car.

      A short, heavily-mustachioed man came out of the office adjacent to the garage. "Mr. Wright! What happened to you...oh, my God! My baby, what you do to her?"

      "On the plus side, she performed beautifully," said Jimmy. "I'm going to need another car."

      Arturo tossed him a set of keys. "Take the white one. I said it would be ready on Thursday, so bring it back by Thursday."

      They drove down to Malibu. "I know a place where folks go to dry out," said Jimmy from the back seat. "One of those rest homes."

      "Palm Cove?" asked Ruby.

      "Yeah."

      "That's one of the better ones. I've always enjoyed my stays there."\n

      \n

      \n


      Palm Cove was a rather anonymous little place near the beach. The paint was fading, and the furniture in the rooms was at least ten years out of fashion. It had an air not of lost hope, but exhausted hope; the desperation of the soon-to-be-relapsed. Still, they had an examining room that was clean enough for Geronimo to cut the bullet out of Jimmy's shoulder, and the place was out of the way enough for them to lay low and heal up.

      Dr. Orange, who had managed to escape the mansion unscathed, spent most of his days sitting and watching the waves roll in, trying to make sense of his experiences in the Temple, the strangely familiar and enticing odor of Nectar that he couldn\u2019t seem to get out of his nose. He watched the waves roll in and thought of oscillation patterns, of the subtle gravitic ballet between the Moon, the Earth, and the water.

      Ruby called Captain Murphy.

      "I hear this place doesn't have any booze," he said when he arrived. "So have some pills."

      "What are they?" asked Ruby.

      "Damned if I know!"

      Millicent spent some time going through the books they had rescued from the Temple of Joy. She'd already read the Malleus Maleficorum, of course, but the Pnakoptic Manuscripts was very interesting. And then she found a diagram of the Los Angeles County water system. With access points circled.

      "Mr. Wright!" she said, running into Jimmy's room.

      [Various Stability refresh scenes, and Millicent picked up +1 Cthulhu Mythos.]

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 11)

      After a couple of days, Jimmy called his office. Among the long list of messages his secretary read to him were several from Dr. Goodman Black. Jimmy wasted no time calling him.

      "You want to speak to me?" he said when Black picked up.

      "I do. Shall we say neutral ground? Union Station."

      "Tomorrow. Two o'clock." Jimmy hung up and rang Senator Grey's office.

      "What can I do for you, Jimmy? Another schoolgirl in a hospital?"

      "I may have found a plot to contaminate the city water supply with an extremely powerful drug."

      "What is this, a dime novel?"

      "Just giving you a heads up."

      "Do you have any evidence?"

      "When have I ever worked with evidence?"

      "Bring me something solid, and I'll talk to the governor. But not before. And thanks for making my day more complicated--I've never regretted that first time I hired you," said Grey right before hanging up.\n

      \n

      \n


      "Lot of cops," said Jimmy as he, Dr. Orange, and Geronimo arrived at Union Station. The police had cordoned off a section with Goodman Black standing in the middle of it.

      "I have to say," said Black as they came up, "it was a little rude, coming to my place under false pretenses and planting your little monkey there."

      "The doctor wasn't my idea," said Jimmy.

      "I've been completely honest with you," said Black. "All I want to do is bring the love of God to the world."

      "The wrong god, I think."

      "Oh no, this is the right god. I am absolutely sure. I've talked to him. You can too."

      "I decided a while ago I don't want to talk to a god who talks back."

      "But he's real, Jimmy! He wants to talk to you. Especially you. But I want to invite all of you to come speak to him."

      "Does he have a name?"

      "He does, but I'm not sure I should say it in public. As you know, my real name is Samson Trammel," said Black smoothly.

      Jimmy grunted.

      "I took this name when I became a preacher. Because I work for the good Black Man."

      "Funny. I still have his card."

      "You should call him then. Now, I want you to know that I don't have any hard feelings about what you did, although it was unkind. And I will leave you alone, if you let me alone. But come at me again--well, where I'm from? Texas? We can forgive a mistake like this once. The second time we gotta put you in the ground."

      "Your boss can talk to me whether I want to or not."

      "He's good at talking."

      "Hasn't he always been?"

      "I don't know what he was like before," said Black philosophically. "I only know what he's like now. Doc, the offer still is open to come get baptized."

      "I saw what that means," said Dr. Orange.

      "I can show you incontrovertible proof of intelligences greater than our own."

      "I...can't trust you."

      "Shame. That's the kind of thing you get Nobels for. Mr. Cuevas, it was a brother, wasn't it? It's trivial for my Lord to bring him back to you. You could talk to him again."

      "I talk to my brother whenever I want to," said Geronimo.

      "Yes, but this time he could talk back."

      "I know what he would say, especially about this."

      "It's so sad. You're all going to your deaths because you won't open your eyes to see, and open your mouths to praise him."

      Back at Palm Cove, Ruby had a drink and flipped through the folder with Jimmy's case notes. "Who could this Black fellow be?" she mused. "Somebody from the South. Or could it be Echevarria, brought back to life?"

      She picked up the picture of Richard Spend and stared at it for a long time. "He was from Texas..." she said.

      She looked at the picture of Goodman Black she'd gotten at KLAX.

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 13)

      Later that night, the much-reduced band paid a visit to Laura Spend, Richard Spend's sister. She was working as a maid in an expensive house in Beverly Hills.

      Her room was simple--a cross nailed to one wall, a calendar, and a very expensive cabinet radio.

      "Who are you all?" she asked as Ruby, Geronimo and Dr. Orange came in the door. Her voice had a heavy Texas accent.

      "We're private investigators," said Ruby.

      "I already told the police that I didn't steal those spoons at my last job. It was a miscarriage of justice."

      "What are you listening to?" asked Dr. Orange.

      "Music, and during the day when I can I listen to my stories."

      "We're looking into an old case," said Ruby.

      "Oh, like those fellas who came looking for Ricky all them years ago? They said they was cops but they were PIs. I don't like PIs."

      "Well, that's just it. We're looking in to them, and we were hoping you could shed some light on what they were asking about, and maybe why they were interested in your brother."

      "Ricky's dead," Laura said quickly. "And you're as nosy as they were! Especially that Georgian son of a bitch."

      Doug, thought Ruby. Laura described the other man who had visited her ten years ago, and Ruby recognized the description of Vince Stack.

      "Ricky," said Laura, shaking her head. "He was always getting in trouble. We came from nothing out in West Texas. Ricky did a bunch of things, roughnecking, worked a Gulf fishing boat. He was always pretty, though. Everyone always said he got all the looks in the family."

      "We both know that's not true," purred Ruby.

      [Flattery use by RP.]

      "Sugar just won't melt in your mouth," said Laura. "Come about 1920 we were in California picking fruit. Ricky met one of them producer fellas and he got hired to be an actor. Of course, a lot of them weren't hardly Christian pictures--Ricky had a face for that kind of work. That's probably what got him into that other crowd and that damn Mexican. Looked high-class but he was slimy inside. Ricky tried to bring me to those parties but I wouldn't go, they used drugs like mary-juwanna."

      "Anyone try to contact you since your brother died?"

      "Just the cops."

      "Did he leave you anything? Books?"

      "Nope. He didn't even have no money, and no friends left."

      "This is an excellent radio," said Dr. Orange, fiddling with the console.

      "Don't mess that up," said Laura. "I listen to a Gospel program at six. Probably not your religion, I'm sure you wouldn't be interested."

      "Oh, that must be that Goodman Black," said Ruby. "I happened to meet him a month ago."

      "I ain't had the pleasure. Though I sure would like to."

      "Oh, I have his picture here. He signed it."

      Laura took the picture with trembling hands. A look of tenderness crept briefly over her face. "Sure is a handsome man," she whispered.

      "You know," said Ruby deliberately, "I find myself with a vacancy on my staff. Would you be interested in a position? I could make it worth your while." She whispered a number in Laura's ear.

      "That much? Well I suppose I could give notice...tonight."

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 14)

      "I think we should go to Long Beach or San Pedro," said Vanessa. "Then we can negotiate passage on an ocean-going freighter."

      "But I've got a job in Pasadena, working for Dr. Orange," said Millicent, struggling to keep up.

      "You can't go back to a job! Or school!"

      "But Professor Fauche is expecting me to be his assistant--"

      "Well, you can forget about that!"

      They hailed a cab. "Let's go to Orange County," suggested Millicent.

      "Good idea! We can work our way down to Mexico! People vanish for years in Mexico."

      They stopped for the night in Huntington Beach, at a fleabag hotel near the beach. The sound of oil derricks droned through the night, and noxious oil fumes rolled in with the fog. Millicent waited for Vanessa to fall asleep (it didn't take long--she was clearly in a state of nervous exhaustion) and then called Erica Carlyle Grey.

      "Wait, why are you with Vanessa?" she said over the phone.

      "She decided the thing to do was to run to Mexico--"

      "Oh, Christ, not again. I'll call some of Bradley's men."

      "She's fine, she's just had a shock."

      Not long after, a car pulled up with a couple of burly orderlies and a psychiatric nurse. By the time they dragged Vanessa out of the room, she was screaming, but they quickly sedated her.

      "For your trip back," said one of the orderlies, handing Millicent a sawback. "And you didn't see nothing."\n

      \n

      \n


      "Home sweet home," said Ruby as they pulled up to her Beverly Hills house.

      It was evening, and smog was roiling through the heavy air. Dr. Orange felt nervous. There was a foreboding feeling looming over the house. "Something's not right," he said, remembering ambushes in Berlin. "It feels like nobody's here."

      They took a walk around the grounds. The guest cottage was empty, as they expected. But they found a basement window that had been smashed in.

      "This is my house," snarled Ruby, pulling her gun out of her purse. "Let's find out what's going on."

      They came in through the front door and began searching the house. Nobody was home, not even Althea the maid. They swept the first floor and then went into the basement.

      It was clear that somebody had come in through the broken window. They checked each of the servant's rooms. Luz's room contained only the stench of Carmen's perfume. Althea's room showed signs that her belongings had been hastily packed.

      In Geronimo's room they found a man, unconscious and curled up on the bed.

      "Why do bums always chose my room?" grumbled Geronimo.

      Ruby prodded him awake with her gun.

      "Ah! Whaddaya doing, lady?" the man said, rolling over.

      "Excuse me, you're in my home!"

      "I'm sorry, lady, I didn't know. I just came her for the stuff."

      "The what?"

      "You know, the stuff."

      "Do you mean the Renoir? You can have that beastly thing."

      "What's a Renoir?"

      Suddenly Ruby became aware of a familiar mossy smell. She slowly turned around.

      Mouths erupted all along the walls. Horrible, lipless mouths with lolling tongues and jagged teeth. And from each dripped thick, gooey, disgusting, enticing, tempting Nectar.

      Ruby shuddered and then emptied her clip a the mouths.

      Geronimo rushed Ruby and pushed her out of the room. Dr. Orange grabbed the stranger and pulled him out of the room. Geronimo kicked the door shut.

      "I'm having a bad day," said Ruby, slumping against the wall.\n

      \n

      \n


      The interrogated the bum in the guest cottage.

      "Not as good as the real stuff," sighed the man.

      "Do you know how this happened to my wall?" asked Ruby.

      "Nope, just glad it did. Anyway, posh neighborhood like this you're bound to find somebody with Nectar. Just lucky I found your place. But it's not like the Bangkok Nectar. What a kick! You took it and felt so alive. You just had to go in there and tear somebody's head off! Hand to hand. Nothing like it."

      Ruby noticed for the first time that the man's hands were knobby and calloused. His nose looked like it had been broken several times, and he limped when he walked.

      "Lee Dempson," the man said, holding out his hand.

      "Ruby."

      "Right, this is your place. Sorry about your window."

      "Charmed," said Ruby. "How long have you been scavenging like this?"

      "I buy it when I have money, from those zoot suit guys. And...the parties up at the Temple. They're only supposed to allow in a fancy crowd. But truth is, if you look like you don't have any place to go, his men might bring you up there. And if you're lucky, they give you the stuff. Of course, you gotta do some pretty crazy things, but while you're on Nectar you don't care any."

      "Where'd you go in Bangkok?"

      "There's a honey store. The Fragrant Honey Store. You tell them, I've come for the exhibition. And they'll take you down to an arena, give you the stuff, and you'd go fight some people."

      "I've taken Nectar," said Ruby. "It never made me want to hurt people."

      "The LA stuff is weak. The real stuff makes you strong."

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 15)

      Millicent took a car back to Jimmy's office. She set herself to the job of reorganizing the files Ruby had misplaced. If she decided to also look up some of Jimmy's files on Egypt, well, nobody would need to know, and they weren't locked in any serious way. Well, the safe was kind of hard, but she\u2019d broken more difficult setups before.

      About Egypt, she only found some summaries--Jimmy had never been there. But she found references, mostly from a Freddie Blakely, to Omar Shakhti--some sort of sorcerer--and a woman named Hypatia.

      There was also a box labeled Jack Brady. With trembling hands she opened it and began to flip through the contents.

      There was a letter, with the name Mirabelle written on it. Millicent opened it and a single sheet of paper and a photograph fell out.\n

      \n

      \n

      To my Darling Mirabelle on her 16th Birthday

      Dearest, nothing I can write here can possibly make up for all the years I missed. I wish I could explain to you why I had to leave you like this. I guess it's just that I made a lot of mistakes in my life and I had to take any chance I could get to put some of them right.

      I wish I could see the beautiful woman you've grown up to be. I know you've been taking good care of your mom, and Jimmy and Freddie promised to help her out.

      I don't have anything to give you as a present except my necklace. It's saved my life many times even thought I never really understood it. My mother gave it to me a long time ago. Maybe if we ever knew how to use it, our family forgot over time. Still, it's why they used to call me "Brass" -- well, one reason at least.

      I will warn you about the necklace. It has a terrible and dreadful purpose, and using it can make you empty. Perhaps there's a safe way to use it. Or maybe you have to be the right kind of person. I don't know.

      But somehow I know you'll master it.

      I'm enclosing my favorite photo of us, from your birthday when I gave you that doll carriage. I hope you took it with you.

      It looks like we're going to start now. Francis wants me in the boat with him and we have a long way to go into darkness. Know that my last thoughts will be of you and Vanessa. Tell her that she will always be the only woman I ever loved.

      Forever Yours

      Jack Oriel Brady
      SSGT, USMC. AEF 1918.

      December 12, 1886 -- January 14, 1926.\n

      \n

      \n

      Millicent looked at the photo that was in the envelope. It showed a picture of a skinny, wiry man in a peaked cap and a pudgy girl in pigtails standing next to a doll carriage.

      She remembered the doll carriage. She even, vaguely, remembered that day in Singapore, one of the few times Uncle Jack had stayed with them all night.

      That is not what made her cry, what caused the room to spin until mercifully she fell back to the floor and into darkness.

      The face of the little girl was not her face. Not her face.

      \n I'm way behind on writeups, I know--we just put Session 7 in the books, although I should have the Episode IV writeup ready shortly. However, I'm still basking in the glow of managing to pull off a baffling and somewhat creepy encounter with a post-Lovecraftian deity

      Yeah, Post-Lovecraftian. I think that's basically the genre of my games...I'm not sure if it's a portmanteau of post-modern and Lovecraftian, or if I mean literally "Mythos fiction after Lovecraft." What I think I'm getting at is a style of Mythos horror that tries to go beyond the "scary disgusting unknowable other" to a more "existential freakout" style of scary. But I'll let you be the judge of whether that's worth doing

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 16)

      Sitting around the kitchen table in the guest cottage, Ruby, Dr. Orange, and Geronimo began to formulate a plan.

      "We should blow up the temple," said Julius. "I can rig up a bomb. Unless you have a general who owes you a favor."

      "I know some people wouldn't mind a bombing run on Echo Park," mused Ruby.

      "I can get myself inside," said Geronimo. "I'll pretend to be a vagrant, and make trouble."

      "They have a groundskeeping crew," said Dr. Orange. "My research with at the FBI office must have their name. A little pressure and I can get in on their crew and I can bring a bomb in that way. A big bomb. It's amazing what's legal in America, in Germany..."

      "Yes, yes," said Ruby. "And I have a plane. Not the Lockheed. My biplane."

      "Are you joking?" said Geronimo.

      "No. And I know a guy with some fireworks. I guess Julius had the right idea."

      They made plans for the next day. Geronimo decided to go and have another Mass said in his brother's memory. Dr. Orange called up Dr. Born for a round of golf. Ruby spent a long time staring at her grandmother's cameo.

      [More Stability refresh scenes!]\n

      \n

      \n


      Ruby dropped by Jimmy's office the next afternoon. She found Millicent sitting on the floor, surrounded by open folders and sheets of paper. An open safe behind her had the distinct appearance of something that should be closed.

      "My brain hurts," said Millicent.

      "What--" said Ruby, stunned.

      "I was looking for clues," said Millicent miserably.

      "There there, dear," said Ruby, guiding Millicent to the couch. "Have a drink. What's the matter?"

      "I don't know!" said Millicent, sobbing into Ruby's blouse. She cried for a long time but somehow found Ruby's presence comforting.

      [Psychological triage by RP!]\n

      \n

      \n



      Geronimo went to a corner Lee had recommended. After a long wait, a panel truck pulled up and a man in a zoot suit jumped out the back.

      "I need five," he said. "You. You two. You. And...you."

      Geronimo shuffled up into the back of the truck. "You got a sandwich?" he said to the main in the zoot suit.

      "You'll get everything you need when we get to the place," said the man with smirk as he slammed the rear doors shut.

      One rather forlorn man slumped down in a corner and shook his head. "You boys are really in for a bad time," he said. "and a good time too. I guess you can see I have mixed feelings about this. Man, I wish my university hadn't gone under in the Crash."

      "What will happen when we get there?" asked Geronimo.

      "They'll pen us up for a while, waiting for the party to really get started. Then they'll give us this drug. After that, you'll probably do some debauchery with some rich white ladies. Ladies if you're lucky, that is. Or they'll take you down to the basement."

      "What's there?"

      "There's one room for recreation, so they like to keep people there. But there's another room. I ain't never gone in there. Lucky. Nobody who goes in there comes back out. At least, not sane."\n

      \n

      \n


      They reached the Temple of Joy. At least, Geronimo thought it was the Temple--they herded everyone quickly across the lawn and down into the basement. Some of Walker's men made them strip and then hosed them down with frigid water. They gave them soup and bread to eat.

      "They don't want you to be hungry," said the talkative man. "You might try and eat an ear or something. Don't worry, this isn't that room in the basement. We're next to the wine cellar. Guys come down sometimes to fetch bottles."

      They settle down to wait. Geronimo fell into a relaxed tension. Right before he sensed the basement door open, he sprinted for the wine cellar, jimmied the door, and slipped inside.

      Through the door he heard the angry barks of Walker's men as they herded the vagrants upstairs. He sighed and relaxed for a moment.

      The door to the wine closet opened and a waiter came in. "God, who drinks so much merlot?" he muttered, before stopping dead in his tracks. He stared at the angry, naked, heavily scarred man in front of him.

      Geronimo grabbed a bottle of wine and began to swing.

      "Not the Lafitte!" said the man.

      Geronimo shrugged, grabbed another bottle, and decked the waiter.

      As he was shrugging into the other man's clothes, Geronimo heard a faint sound of music coming from behind one of the wine racks. He poked around until he found a small latch.

      The rack swung away from the wall. There was a room beyond it.

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 17)

      Dr. Orange opened the conservatory door a crack and slipped through. He hefted his large truck spanner--the same one he had used to disable the groundskeeper's truck--and made his way silently into Goodman Black's office.

      He sighed as he walked past the bookshelves full of exotic volumes. And then he flattened himself against the wall.

      Somebody was standing near the doorway.\n

      \n

      \n


      The music was louder now that the wine rack had opened. It was strange. It sounded vaguely Mexican, but with Indian themes worked in, combined with harsh atonal dissonances. A low backing track that sounded like it could be played by a mariachi combo added it's own discordant tones. Over it was a low chanting, a woman's voice.

      The smell of Nectar hit him like a physical blow and he almost staggered from it. As his gaze dropped, he saw a writhing mass of human bodies, more debauched than anything he had ever seen Nectar addicts doing. They almost pulsed, in some alien motion. As he watched, a gigantic tongue rose from the center of the floor. It was longer than an elephant's trunk and thicker than a man's leg. It arced over and began licking the bodies close to it. Hands reached for it. Arms embraced it. Mouths closed on it in horrid kisses.

      And from it dripped vast amounts of orange, gooey Nectar.

      [Bang! That was a 6-point Stability loss for Geronimo. That's worse than coming across a battlefield.]

      Geronimo tossed the naked waiter into the room, and slammed shut the wine rack.\n

      \n

      \n


      There was an enormous crowd of the faithful gathered in the Sanctuary. In his waiter disguise, Geronimo had no problem making his way across the floor and into the vestibule outside Goodman Black's office.

      Behind him, in the Sanctuary, he heard Black's voice rising. "Tonight is the night, brothers and sisters!"

      Geronimo took out a pocket knife he'd found in the waiter's pocket and jimmied the door. Behind it was a zoot suited guard with a Thompson.

      "What the hell?" said the guard.

      "Oh, Joe the cook sent me--"

      "The cook's name isn't Joe! I have to call this in--"

      Geronimo swung his tray at the guard's face.

      The man stumbled back. He cocked his gun--

      Dr. Orange smacked him the back of the head with his spanner.

      [OP: I want to hit him from behind.
      Me: Okay, sure, you can attack.
      OP: Do I need to even roll? He doesn\u2019t know I\u2019m there\u2026
      Me: You know what, you\u2019re right\u2014just do your damage.

      (Probably I could have charged a nominal cost\u2014a point of Weapons, maybe\u2014and I might do that in the future. Thought I\u2019d include this here as an example of applying *World decision making to other games.]

      The guard reeled forward and swung the butt of the Thompson at Geronimo, who managed to parry the attack. He swung the tray again, edge first, into the guard's throat. Something cracked and the guard dropped to the ground.

      "Come on, Doctor. Let's search this place."

      "How are we going to get the books out of here? I won't be able to get the truck running if I'm searching."

      "We made arrangements."

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 18)

      "Now bring forth the catechumens," said Goodman Black.

      Geronimo crept up to the door to the Sanctuary and peered out. The crowd had fallen eerily silent, and a procession of young boys and girls were filing into the middle of the room. The boys wore handsome white suits, and the girls pretty white pinafores. Both had crowns of flowers on their heads.

      Geronimo looked at the floor in the center of the Sanctuary. He thought for a moment. The pit in the basement was directly beneath it.

      There were hinges mounted in the floor.

      He raised the Thompson he had taken from the guard. With an angry growl, he pulled the trigger and hosed fire at Samson Trammel. People shrieked and fell to the floor, crawling away from the noise. Bullets smacked into Trammel's chest. He jerked back and fell to the floor, bleeding heavily, and crawled towards the back of the room.

      [This was a hard driver against Geronimo's Duty drive.]\n

      \n

      \n


      Suddenly there were bursts of white light from outside. Firework starburst shells were raining down onto the lawn.

      Dr. Orange paused in his search of Trammel's desk. "Ruby's here!" he said. He jammed a crowbar in a drawer and pulled it open.

      At the bottom of it, wrapped in a dirty white rag, he found a roughly bound book, caked and stained with organic fluids. He opened the cover and found a handwritten title page:

      The Testament of Dripping Mouthes Emanates

      by Samson Trammel, DD, Savior of Mankind
      and chosen one of the True God

      Inside the book were bizarre and cryptic notes, poems, fragments of musical notation, and sketches. There were several full-color paintings done in different styles, depicting various female figures. Dr. Orange suspected they were intended as allegories of goddesses.\n

      \n

      \n

      "Drop another one!" said Ruby to Millicent as she circled the plane around for another pass.

      As she swung over the gate, she saw a panel truck smash into the gate. "Murphy's here!" shouted Millicent.

      "Ten minutes late," said Ruby. "That's practically on time for him!"

      As the truck roared up the drive, Millicent could see Captain Walker and several of his men rushing towards the front door of the Temple. She flung another fireworks shell out of the plane, aiming for the center of the group of men. It hit the ground with a shriek and a shower of stars, and two of the men fell down.

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 19)

      The doors to the Temple burst open and several men rushed in. Geronimo turned to run as bursts of gunfire smashed into the walls around him. He felt a stinging pain in his leg and then something slammed into his back, knocking him down. For a moment the room dimmed, but he was able to crawl forward towards the vestibule. He left a trail of blood behind him.

      "This ends tonight," shouted Walker. "I'm not going to let you kill all these kids! This has gone too far!"

      He turned to his men. "Get the kids out of here. Kill the rest."

      Dr. Orange pulled Geronimo into the office, and slung him over his shoulders in an awkward fireman's carry. He stumbled out onto the lawn just as a panel truck pulled up to the house. Captain Murphy and several of his crewmembers jumped out of the truck.

      "Ruby sent us to grab the books!" barked Murphy. "Looks like it's going to be a fight! Charlie, Raekwon, get in there with your rifles! The rest of you start fetching books."\n

      \n

      \n


      Inside the sanctuary, there was a terrific rattle of gunfire as Walker's men began gunning down the congregation. Charlie, a gigantic man with a Maori tattoo covering half his face, was gently rounding up the children and herding them through Trammel's office and outside. Murphy helped lift them up into the back of the truck.

      "Getting a bit hot here, doc!" he said to Julius. "Should we stay or go? You got any business left?"

      "Damnit, there's a woman! Janet might be there!"

      "I respect that, Doc!"

      Dr. Orange ran inside the office, holding Geronimo's Thompson gun. He heard a grinding noise from the Sanctuary, and hazarded a look into it for a second. The floor was collapsing, and congregants and Walker's men alike were sliding into a pit.

      He ran up the iron staircase and into Trammel's sitting room. "Janet! Janet!" he shouted. He tried to push around some of the bodies, but he didn't see her anywhere. The building began to shake.

      He half-ran, half-slid down the staircase into the office. The interior walls between the office and the Sanctuary were beginning to collapse.

      He saw a gigantic tongue rise up out of the pit in the center of the room. He shrieked and fired off the rest of the clip from his gun before running in utter terror to Murphy's truck.\n

      \n

      \n


      Millicent lobbed a starburst shell into the cupola on top of the dome. She looked down and saw some children running from the Temple.

      "Drop the rest of your shells!" said Ruby.

      "But there are kids down there!"

      Ruby glanced down. "They seem to be all out of there."

      "How can you know that for sure! I'm not throwing anymore of these things!"

      Ruby shrugged and put the plane into an aileron roll. The last shells tumbled out of the plane as Millicent watched helplessly.\n

      \n

      \n


      Murphy's truck raced through the gate just as the sound of sirens could be heard. Murphy himself was leaning out of the back of the truck, checking for pursuers.

      "Too bad about Frankie and Fez," he said to Charlie. The huge man grunted and continued wiping off his kukri.

      "How's Jerry?" he asked Dr. Orange. "Does he need a sickbay? Or a vet?"

      Geronimo groaned.

      "Just take us back to that clinic," said Dr. Orange, slumping down next to a crate. It was jammed full of books from Trammel's office.

      \nEpisode III: What Kind Of Love Have You Got? (Part 20)

      They managed to wake up the doctor who signed all the prescriptions at Palm Cove. Somehow he managed to pull the bullets out of Geronimo's chest and leg without killing the Spaniard. They found an out of the way bungalow to hide him in while he recuperated.

      Ruby began the long process of sorting through the captured books. She spent several days going over the Testament in particular.

      And then she spent several days trying to shake off the effects. Eventually she was recovered enough to report back to the others.

      [Even with clawing back some Stability for following her drive--dropping bombs from a plane and reading this book are both Adventurous--Ruby still got blasted by the 5 points of Stability she lost reading the book and so her Sanity went down by one.]

      The book was filled with Kabbalistic imagery, especially of the Tree of Life--the arrangement of the ten Sephiroth familiar to most occultists. Disturbingly, however, most of the references were Qliphothic--the inverses of the Sephiroth, the dark demons of matter and fear.

      One painting in the book was called The Allegorical Marriage of Sophia and was filled with references to the Sephiroth and the Tree of Life. It showed a man and a beautiful woman kissing, but Ruby couldn't puzzle much more out.

      "The Cult back in 1926 thought that they were worshiping Gol-Goroth. Echevarria, however, didn't," said Ruby in between sips of a massive tropical cocktail. "Our friend Richard Spend wasn't in the inner circle back then, but he's pieced a lot together, mostly by buying Echevarria's library."

      "And now we have it," said Dr. Orange.

      "Precisely. Trammel, as it turns out, thinks that the creature that Echevarria worshiped is called Nyarlathotep. Also known as the Black Pharoah. Some say he was identified with the vulture-headed god Thoth. Supposedly he gave the evil queen Nitocris her dark power. Also, he may be the Black Man that the witch cults of Europe made compacts with."

      Everyone stared at Ruby.

      "I didn't recognize the name, so I looked it up in some of the other books we got. Very interesting stuff."

      [The Testament, strangely enough, doesn't grant any points in Cthulhu Mythos. (As MP put it, it's basically a giant core clue.) I offered RP a point of CM provided Ruby spent time correlating material in the other books.]

      "Anyway, they say he's the God With a Thousand Masks. All sorts of forms and traditions of worship--there are African forms, Chinese forms...and others."

      Millicent gulped. That reminded her of some of the files she had found in Jimmy's safe, including a few that were barely coherent and seemed to involve something he had personally witnessed.

      "There's also several letters to an 'SS' who were debating the nature of the being they worshiped. She--it seems likely she's female, and her writing reminds me of some of the things Andre said in English, so she probably knows French. But given that the letters are from Bangkok, she's probably not French. She's invited 'Goodman Black' to come and visit her to 'fight in our rites in Bangkok.' It matches what that bum told us about the fights."

      Ruby showed some copies of the other letters she'd found. "This is from 'Montgomery Donovan' in Malta, about increasing the yield of the Mouth. Black tried all sorts of different things, but Donovan said that a proper sacrifice could do the trick. Black was skeptical...but then he was going to kill all those kids. Donovan said that his production went waaay up a couple of months ago."

      "That can't work. Ridiculous. No basis," said Dr. Orange. "It's not science. Magic."

      "There's something from Luz Discos in Mexico City, talking about ways to use the 'song of the Mouth.' Some stuff from a 'JB' about our next recording and the results it will obtain. For what it's worth, Trammel doesn't seem to think much of him. JB is also interested in figuring out who they're worshiping. He tends to talk about your god and our god when he writes Trammel. So, we've got three people and two of them think Trammel is wrong."

      "It doesn't matter," said Millicent. "It's not real. They've got some kind of chemical lab. Right, doctor?"

      "Ja, labs," said Julius, staring into space.

      "Anything in the papers about our little events?" asked Ruby.

      "Just that there was a fire, probably caused by a fireworks show that was interrupted by a a gangland attack," said Gernoimo. "Hundreds dead. But not the Reverand Doctor, it seems. He's recovering nicely at Mt. Sinai Hospital.

      "We should pay him a visit," said Dr. Orange.

      \nEpisode IV: Why Do We Give Our Love to the Past (Part 1)

      [Editorial note: this will be a bit shorter than other episodes, mostly because we started the Mexico City section at the end of the session; I'm moving that part to the Episode V writeup, where it will be more logical.]

      Jimmy wasted no time trying to pick up Janet\u2019s trail. Her friends at the Mirror told him that she had been tipped off about Senator Clark, one of LA's fine representatives to the state legislature, being on the take. She'd headed up to Sacramento, and then out to Monterey where the Senator kept a beach home.

      The sleepy streets of Monterey, bathed in fog at dawn and dusk, were a sharp contrast to the shadows and filth of LA, but they contained their own secrets. Jimmy slammed into the local underworld, paying when he could, cracking heads when he couldn't. He found out that Mrs. Senator Clark was a Nectar addict, currently drying out in Nevada. It didn't take too much deduction to figure out that the Senator was probably on the honey train himself--and that maybe Janet had been sent into a trap by Walker.

      One night, while he was polishing off the rest of a bottle of rye in his dive of a hotel, he got a call from a woman with a thick Southern accent.

      "Hello, Bethany," he said.

      "You want to go to Sausalito. 23 Half Moon Street."

      "Why are you telling me this?"

      "Because we look after women like her. And because our goals are not directly opposed in this instance."

      "Here's to staying on the same track as long as possible."

      He drove up to Sausalito the next morning, taking the ferry over to the town. The almost-finished Golden Gate Bridge loomed above him in the fog as the ferry passed by the channel. 23 Half Moon Street turned out to be a run-down two story clapboard house badly in need of paint. Two tough looking Mexicans were sitting on the porch, eyeing everyone who came down the road.

      That night he put in a call to Geronimo, while he settled in to watch the house.

      [JP made a Shadowing check here to get a 2-point "messing up their stuff" pool.]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Back in LA, Millicent sent Samson Trammel some flowers "from Senator Grey." She got a nice note back inviting the Senator to show up whenever he wanted. Or his personal secretary, she thought, and picked out her least-threatening outfit.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "Let's try to sneak up on them and knock them out," said Jimmy. He, Dr. Orange, and Geronimo were watching the two Mexican guards, who were standing near the gate of the picket fence that surrounded the house.

      "This will be easy," said Dr. Orange. "Even if we screw up we'll still murder them."

      "Let's try to avoid that," sighed Jimmy.

      Dr. Orange shrugged into the beat up overcoat he had bought from a bum that morning, and swung out into Half Moon Street. He lurched up to the two guards.

      "Yeeegutta annythin' tdrnk?" he slurred. One of the guards burst out laughing, but stopped when his companion glared at him. Out of the corner of his eye, Dr. Orange could see Jimmy and Geronimo creeping up from opposite directions.

      The laughing guard turned around just in time to see Geronimo raise his blackjack. He stepped back, slipping on brass knuckles, and threw a punch at Geronimo. The Spaniard blocked the blow at the last second and smashed a knee into the other man's stomach.

      The other guard spun around and saw Jimmy swinging a cop's nightstick at his head. The blow connected hard and the guard went down like Joe Louis against Max Schmeling.

      Dr. Orange swung at the man fighting Geronimo, but he dodged out of the way at the last minute--right into the butt of Geronimo's gun. There was a cracking noise and blood spurted from his nose as he fell to the ground, stunned.

      Jimmy rushed up the porch and kicked the door open, followed by Dr. Orange, guns out. Geronimo swung around the back of the house to force the kitchen door.

      From the back of the house came a man in a zoot suit, pushing Janet Rogers in front of him. He had an ugly looking .45 pressed to her head. "All right, se\xf1ores, nobody move and the pretty lady doesn't have to die."

      Dr. Orange shot him in the head.

      "Goddamnit!" said Jimmy.

      "It wasn't like he'd get a shot off," said Dr. Orange.

      Janet, her face covered with blood and brains, fainted and began to fall back--into the arms of Geronimo, who was coming in from the kitchen.

      "Don't do that ever again!" said Jimmy.

      "We should make our departure," said Geronimo. "The police will soon be here."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Millicent arrived at Mt. Sinai Hospital. There were a couple of uniformed policemen standing at the door of Trammel's room that everyone was supposed to notice, and several men in suits that she pegged as plainclothes detectives. She showed the note Trammel had sent her and was ushered in.

      Trammel was braced up in his bed, tubes attached to several parts of his body. He looked even more emaciated than the last time she'd seen him. "Mr. Trammel?"

      "You from the Greys? What can I do for you, Miss?"

      "I just wanted to pass on their hope that you get better."

      "I'm trying, with God's help."

      "I heard your radio program last week. I've been going through some tough times and kind of needed it."

      "God loves all of us, although sometimes in different ways. I'm alive because of God's graciousness."

      "You really think that? God kept you alive?"

      "That's what He told me."

      "You mean that literally?"

      "Like I said, that's what he told me."

      "What...what does he say to you?"

      "He tells me the future, and the past, what people are doing."

      "You could make a fortune on races or the stock market."

      "He doesn't care about things like that."

      "What does he want?"

      "When he speaks to me through the Mouths of God, He wants everyone to be happy."

      "Some people aren't happy unless bad things are happening to other people."

      "No, it doesn't have to be that way. We can all be happy and share God's great love."

      "I won't lie, I don't have your strong faith. But I respect it."

      "You have it, I'm sure. I'm sorry, Miss. I'm very tired. Is there anything else?"

      "Just get better, Mr. Trammel."

      "It's strange," said Trammel as Millicent opened the door, "It's almost as if I can't see you sometimes."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      They stashed Janet in a bungalow Jimmy had on file. He brought in some nurses to help her recover. She told them that she had been snatched--the story she'd been following was clearly a plant--and then interrogated for a few days, mostly about Jimmy and what he was up to.

      "We have to assume they know everything I told Janet," said Jimmy. "She didn't mean to, but everybody talks with enough time."

      Dr. Orange and Geronimo agreed silently.

      "Why do they want to know so much about you, Jimmy?" asked Geronimo.

      "I know the mayor. I'm famous. I have a reputation for working against people like this."

      "That's the only reason?"

      "Only one I want to discuss."

      \nEpisode IV: Why Do We Give Our Love to the Past (Part 2)

      Geronimo knelt, running his fingers over his rosary again. Ave Maria, gratia plena, Dominus tecum... he silently intoned. It was his favorite time to be in a church: just after the Mass was over, when the superficially devout had already shuffled outside into the empty pleasures of a California afternoon. The smell of incense lingered, rich, calling up memories of the dusty mountain village in Aragon he had grown up in.

      He sat back on the pew, nodding as someone sat down next to him. Then he shot the man a sharp glance.

      It was Captain Walker.

      "I want to talk to you," he said. "Perhaps not here. Someplace away from a house of God."

      "Anything you want to say to me you can say in front of God," said Geronimo gruffly.

      "I assure you, God has nothing to do with what I have done."

      "God has everything to do with it. It is all His will."

      "Trammel is a very sick man. I wanted to stop his madness but preserve his way of making money. For as you know, in America, money is everything. I started out in the barrio. I had nothing, nothing but the respect of the people around me because they knew I could fight. And I knew even then that I must have money, that money was the only way to make your way in this country. Especially if you don't speak English so well, or you aren't the right color. Trammel's business is an ugly business, but they are all ugly businesses. The drug business is taking money from the weak. That is how Wall Street works, that is how this business works."

      "You profit from the failings of others."

      "So do you. You profit from Ruby's weakness. If she could protect herself, she would not need you."

      "I assure you my employment is more than just monetary compensation."

      "That is neither here nor there. I have made a terrible mistake."

      "Yes, you involved yourself with a man like Trammel."

      "Trammel is inconsequential. He is a stupid, fast-talking white man. There are many of those in Los Angeles. They can be useful. Whatever it was he was worshiping, it is not a god. I think it is the Devil. It will destroy us. It will destroy you. It will destroy everything in the world."

      "I believe you."

      "Se\xf1or, you must stop this. As for me, I am lost. I desire only death."

      For the first time Geronimo heard a faint noise, like a whisper...or mastication. It was coming from somewhere on Walker's arm.

      "If you wish to be saved," said Geronimo, "I advise you to talk to Father. Your salvation may be at risk."

      "I am damned."

      "Why do you say so?"

      "Satan has placed his mark on me."

      "Then God shall wash it clean."

      "God has nothing to do with this, senor."

      [Me: I'm just going to pull out the Stability chart, no reason...]

      "Tell me what I can do to help you."

      "You must destroy the thing that makes this Nectar. This is not the only place in the world it comes from. I only know this one, though. The followers have gone mad...its power is growing. It will destroy us all. Drown the world in this substance until we are all slaves."

      Geronimo nodded, and got up. He had just passed the doors in the back of the sanctuary when he heard the gunshot, and the screams of the other people praying.
      [1-point Stability loss for Geronimo here.]

      \nEpisode IV: Why Do We Give Our Love to the Past (Part 3)

      "We have no need of worrying about Walker anymore," said Geronimo when he reached the bungalow. Quite calmly, he told them the story of his encounter at the church. "I suggest we try to find the ultimate source," he said, "since Walker spoke of many of these things."

      "Do we want to get rid of the one here?" asked Dr. Orange. "Because we can do it, but it's a big thing to do."

      "We must," said Geronimo flatly.

      [This was a Hard Driver on Geronimo's Duty drive.]

      "Do we know it would even hurt it?" said Jimmy.

      "If I blow off your arm, even if it doesn't kill you it would hurt it," said Dr. Orange.

      "Do you know anything, Jimmy? Any better way?" asked Geronimo.

      "I don't know any one way. You just have to survive for as long as you can."

      [Me: Casualties were actually pretty light the last time Jimmy tried this!]

      "These things...we can't kill it. We can banish it. We can delay its influence on the world. Hopefully until after our time. But they will come back, eventually. Stomping out the little pieces will help...but we need to find the big one."

      "Can't we stomp this one on our way out?" said Millicent.

      "We can stomp this on our way out," sighed Jimmy.

      They went over the architectural plans that Dr. Orange had borrowed from the FBI, marking the hidden basement over it. Dr. Orange proposed crop dusting it with thermite, but was convinced by Jimmy's look of exasperation to table that plan. They decided to build a carefully calibrated demolition charge to take out the building--or at least the thing in the basement.\n

      "Bernie? Jimmy here. You left a bunch of messages with me."

      Jimmy pressed down the receiver button on the phone and then dialed Senator Grey to catch up. "So, Jimmy, what's going on now?" asked Grey when he came on. "The Germans going to bomb LA?"
