      \nEpisode VI: Woodrow Wilson's Guns (Part 1)

      Millicent and Betty were walking out of a small art gallery in the Zocalo when they heard people shouting about the riots in Coyoacan. They hurried back to the hotel, but Millicent grabbed Betty's arm as they approached it.

      "That crossed out chalk mark," she said, pointing at a odd looking glyph sketched on a wall. "That's a sign from Mr. Wright. The hotel's been burned."

      "I gotta place we can hide out for a while," said Betty. "I made a list of them for an occasion like this."

      They hurried off into the teeming streets. \n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Ruby and Geronimo limped back into the commune, having seen Dr. Orange and Trotsky off; the Russian planned to lie low outside the city for a while.

      "Lie down," said Geronimo to Ruby, gently putting her on a kitchen table. "The bullet went through your arm, but I have to clean it up."

      There was a clatter from the courtyard. Geronimo furtively shot a glance out of the window. A crowd of wounded refugees from the riot was assembling there.

      He stepped out of the house. "Why are you here?" he said quietly in Spanish.

      "Please, senor...the people here have always tried to help us," said an old man. "We have many people who need assistance."

      Geronimo sighed, and lit a cigarette. "Bring them inside," he said. He glanced around. "Start with the woman who is in labor."

      [So, here's an attempt by me to start creating some more interesting moral situations. It didn't quite fly here, mostly because I didn't create any stakes like "help these people but don't have time to heal yourself", but it was a start. GP and RP used this time to take their refuge (five minutes into the session!) but they were extremely banged up at this point. I ended up charging a point of Medicine to Geronimo. GP told me at this point that Geronimo's Medicine comes from his caring for animals back on his farm in Aragon.]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Jimmy was brought to a local station of the Federal Police. Somewhat to his surprise, he was treated...professionally. Nobody beat him, and he was left to cool his heels in an interrogation room.

      On one wall were several pictures of men in uniform that he guessed were of former officers at the station. He idly glanced at each of them until he saw a face that made his blood run cold--a handsome man in his twenties, wearing an older style uniform. Under it was a plaque with the name of the officer:

      Coronel Ramon Echevarr\xeda

      "Excuse me!" he shouted in English, hoping to get the attention of a guard.

      [Me: Right, Spanish isn't one of your languages.
      JP: Jimmy speaks no languages!
      Me: Wait, you literally went around the world, and you never learned any other languages?
      JP: It's part of his shtick!
      Me: Dr. Mwimbe spoke four different languages in her house!]

      Eventually a cop and a detective came in to speak with him. "Mr. Wright," said the detective wearily, "why do you come down to my country and start riots and fights and kill people?"

      "Technically I was trying to prevent riots and protect people."

      "You stink of cordite! You shot two men! We have witnesses!"

      "They were shooting at me."

      "And why would that be, Mr. Wright? Because you were in the company of an arch-Communist? Because the Los Angeles police department has a file on you as thick as a phone book? You are currently wanted in Los Angeles for the assault of a man whose house was blown up!"

      Jimmy was silent.

      "How do you respond to these charges, Mr. Wright?"

      "It was all a misunderstanding. Lost in translation. As it were."

      "Mr. Wright, I am a detective in the Polic\xeda Federal. I long ago lost my capacity for a sense of humor."

      "Everything I have been dragged into, it was all with good intents."

      "Tell us about the Communist Jonathon Brooks."

      "I came to Mexico to investigate him."

      "And of course you did the right thing and came to the police to inform us of this."

      "You know how it is."

      "No, I do not. Please inform me 'how it is.'"

      "Cops. Private Eyes. It happens a lot."

      "Yes, we have private investigators here in Mexico City as well. They are a low sort."

      "So you can see how you don't always want to go to the police, because you try to help, and the next thing you know--you're in jail. How is the woman, by the way?"

      "Ah, the young lady whose blood is all over your clothes? She is resting comfortably. She probably will make a recovery. She was hit very hard in the back of the head. Probably with a gun. Much like the one we recovered from you, with blood and hair on the barrel."

      "I think I want to talk to my abogado now."

      [JP made a Law spend here to get sprung from the station, though I'm sure there was some money exchanged as well.]

      A few hours later, Jimmy and a coterie of lawyers were signing papers at the front desk. "This will get you released on your own recognizance," said one to him. "Fortunately the prosecutor owes me several favors. Which you now owe me."

      Jimmy nodded. "What about my passport?"

      "I'm afraid they've confiscated it. I can see--"

      "Don't bother. I have it covered." He put on his hat, turned to go, and then paused. "Excuse me," he said to the desk clerk. "There was a picture of a man in my interrogation room that I think I knew once. Echevarr\xeda, I think it was."

      "Yes, Colonel Echevarr\xeda," said the clerk in a bored tone. "He was with the Polic\xeda during the Revolution. He was a very brave man. They say it was because he had nothing left to lose."

      "Did he retire?"

      "I do not know what happened to him. After the Revolution, he left Mexico."

      \nEpisode VI: Woodrow Wilson's Guns (Part 2)

      "We've picked up a tail," said Millicent to Betty as they headed towards one of Jimmy's dead drop sites. "But I can't figure out who it is. They're good. Let's duck into that dance hall up ahead."

      "Is this a good time to go dancing? We got a guy on our tail!"

      "We can watch the door and see if we can tell who it is."

      "Yeah, that's a good idea! Unless it's a Mexican guy, then we'll never be able to tell."

      They found a likely looking place not far away and made their way through the entrance. The dance floor was in an open-air courtyard in the back. There was a spirited band playing waltzes and folk songs. A crowd of young men in beautifully worked shirts surrounded them almost immediately.

      "What should we do, Millicent?" asked Betty.

      "Dance?"

      "OK!" Betty glanced around, and latched onto a nearby man who was drinking a beer. "You! C'mon, let's dance!"

      "Que?" said the man, startled, as Betty dragged him out onto the dance floor.

      "You know how to jitterbug?"\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Jimmy dropped by the hospital Elena was convalescing in. She was still unconscious but seemed out of the woods. He made arrangements for a private nurse, and then hit his dead drops.

      At one, he found a note from Millicent acknowledging the hotel had been burned, and that she and Betty were being followed.

      As he began to think about how to find them, a car pulled up next to him. The door flew open and Gonchi del Toro waved for him to get in. "Your girls are in trouble," he said. "Come on in."

      Jimmy slid in and shut the door. "I guess my luck really is better now," he mused.

      "I should have just taken your money," grumbled Gonchi as he threw the car into gear.

      "You did take my money."

      "Oh. Right."

      As they pulled up to the dance hall, Jimmy rummaged into the back seat and pulled a clean shirt out of Gonchi's suitcase. "Good thing you were packed to leave," he said, pulling on the shirt.

      Gonchi seemed to be counting silently to ten. "Your girls picked up a tail, and your dead drop's being watched. We probably have a tail now. The girls hit a dance hall up there, but they'll get cornered there. We have to hurry."

      They parked the car and hurried into the hall. The girls didn't stand out like a sore thumb--they stood out like a sore thumb someone had painted red and tied a neon sign to. Betty was jitterbugging away despite the Latin music, and Millicent was trying to remember her paso doble steps from her long-ago dance classes.

      "What is wrong with these girls," said Gonchi.

      "They're girls."

      "That's sexist, man. My mother's a girl."

      "They're young girls."

      "Yo ni puedo," muttered Gonchi.

      "Just go grab that blonde girl."

      "The one picking up that guy? I mean, literally?"

      "Yes."

      Gonchi ran out on the dance floor and grabbed Betty by the wrist. Barely missing a beat, she turned and decked him.

      Jimmy hurried up. "Boss!" said Betty. "This guy was getting fresh with me!"

      Gonchi moaned and rubbed his jaw.

      Millicent ran up. "Mr. Wright! We should leave!"

      "Yeah. One minute." Jimmy turned, pulled out his wallet, and tossed a bunch of bills in the air. "Come on," he said as people began to shriek and dive for the money.

      They rushed through the kitchen, past the out of work American roughnecks who were working in it, and slipped down an alley and into the crowd.

      [Stealth check by MP, with the other PCs and NPCs piggybacking. Millicent actually came close to blowing the roll--she got a 10 and the TN was 8, because their tail is very, very good.]

      \nEpisode VI: Woodrow Wilson's Guns (Part 3)

      Gonchi drove them to the commune in Coyoacan. Millicent helped Geronimo and Ruby do triage in the courtyard, at least until they all dropped from exhaustion after midnight.

      Around dawn, Millicent woke up a stretched, trying to work out the kinks in her back she'd picked up from sleeping on the floor. She walked out into the courtyard and watched the sky get light. Nearby, Geronimo slept hunched over a table, his head nestled in his arms. A few birds were sitting on the ridgeline of the house. As she watched, several more came up in groups of three and four.

      There seemed to be a lot more birds than normal.

      "Mr. Cuevas!" she called out. Geronimo picked up his head and looked blearily at her.

      As if on cue, the birds rose as one and swarmed at them.

      "Run!" shouted Geronimo. He pulled Millicent toward the door as the birds swarmed around her.

      "They don't have beaks!" shouted Millicent. The birds swirled around and came in for as second pass, their horrid mouths, filled with jagged misshapen teeth, wide open.

      As Geronimo pushed Millicent through the door, several started to bite at his hands and face. He pulled the door shut behind him, bleeding from several cuts. The birds slammed into the door, and they could hear the sound of gnawing as they tried to eat through the door.

      Jimmy rolled off the couch, and Ruby jumped up next to him. "We need an O'Donnell cocktail," he muttered.

      "Would these work?" asked Ruby, holding out a couple of pine torches. "They had them in a box labeled 'Party Supplies'."

      [Seeing the birds was a 4 point Stability loss, but Geronimo got back 2 points for fulfilling his Duty, and Ruby and Jimmy clawed back a point for following their drives. RP made a Preparedness roll to find torches.]

      Jimmy had just finished lighting the torches when the slats on the shutters over the windows collapsed and a dark cloud of screeching birds burst into the room.

      Jimmy and Ruby waved the torches around and several of the birds dropped smoking to the floor.

      [GP: You have anything that can help us, Jimmy?
      JP: Only Cthulhu Mythos...
      Me: I am really curious as to how a Cthulhu Mythos spend will help you out here.
      RP: I am curious as well.
      JP: I am curious as well, because I am trying to think about it exactly...
      Me: You don't know any spells--you forgot them.
      JP: I never knew any!
      Me: You knew that one at the end...

      We negotiated an Outdoorsman use here to maybe reduce damage. I mentioned flipping blankets at them, and then we realized...]

      Geronimo swept up a lace mantilla someone had draped over a chair. "Take this!" he shouted, tossing one end to Jimmy. They shook out the shawl and swept forward, catching the birds in the fine mesh of the scarf. Behind them Ruby swept the torch around, dropping another few birds. Several birds pushed their way forward, however, and bit Ruby in the face.

      [Each point of Outdoorsman gave them 2d6 birds they could catch. We made this up on the spot; I hadn't prepped that.]

      Millicent grabbed a torch and jabbed it at the birds as Jimmy and Geronimo pulled their improvised net closed. The few remaining birds broke as one and fled out the windows.

      Jimmy and Geronimo beat the netted birds to death with the extinguished torches.

      "Those birds...they must have been sent," gasped Jimmy. "If they didn't know where we were, they probably do now."

      "I'll start packing," sighed Millicent.

      [Me: No, no, you totally should have expected to be able to save the world while sitting in your office.]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      With Gonchi's help, they laid low at a mob doctor's office to heal up and plan.

      "We need guns," said Geronimo. "We can compensate you handsomely."

      "What do you need?"

      "Pistols. Rifles, shotguns. Explosives."

      "Those...shouldn't be a problem."

      "Thompson gun?"

      [I've been using some custom rules to cover auto/rapid fire:

      When you fire a gun quickly, hold +Ammo. Spend your ammo, one-for-one, to:

      --Cover a location
      --Make another attack this round
      --Use suppression fire to prevent someone from attacking

      Most guns have +0 Ammo. Autofire weapons have Ammo +1. Guns with large magazines get ammo +1/+2 if extremely large capacity. Firearms rating of 8 gives you +1 Ammo.

      When you have used all your Ammo, your weapon needs to be reloaded. Guns with Ammo 0 reload in "drama time" as normal.]

      "We can get you one. With the riots, they're in demand."

      "I am thinking," said Jimmy, "that maybe we can try and use Gonchi to put someone inside with Brooks. Someone who knows how he talks, can pretend to be a Communist, speak Spanish..."

      Everyone looked at Geronimo.

      "Can you do a Mexican accent?" said Milicent.

      "Yes, I suppose I can pretend a cat pooped on my tongue," muttered Geronimo.

      "We can say he's a comrade from Spain. Pancho or something," said Jimmy.

      "Pancho!" said Geronimo.

      [RP made some Flattery spends to give Geronimo a 1-pt Flattery pool...call them elocution lessons.]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Jimmy staked out the intersection that Javier Luna had pegged as the place he and the band had been taken. After studying the area for a while, he decided that his most likely target was a pair of houses--a decrepit hacienda, and a modern house painted blue. Suspiciously, there always seemed to be two or three men at the blue house, watching the hacienda. On his way out, Jimmy walked by the fence around the hacienda. There was a padlocked door leading into the cellar of the building.

      [Evidence Collection spend by JP.]

      \nEpisode VI: Woodrow Wilson's Guns (Part 4)

      "This is Pancho, he's a comrade from Barcelona, he wants to join up," said Gonchi to the leader of a group of street fighters who were wearing red armbands.

      "I have been driven away from my land," said Geronimo.

      "It's terrible what's going on there," said the leader. "Well, you can join our Red Brigades and fight on the streets tonight--the riots are still going on, and we're going to take the Revolution to the cabrons."

      "I believe my skills will be more useful at the executive level," said Geronimo.

      "You want to speak to the First Secretary?"

      "I wish to offer my services to Senor Brooks personally."

      "Hrm...I know he's very interested in the war in Spain. Well, come on. Forgive me, comrade, but we're going to have to blindfold you."

      "Of course. Very sensible."

      He was led to a truck and had a bag slipped over his head. The frisking was thorough, but failed to turn up the gun taped between his shoulder blades or the knife strapped to his thigh. Never thought having been searched by Germans would actually end up being useful, he thought.

      He was driven in circles for a long time before the truck stopped and he was led out into a building of some kind. He was taken down several flights of stairs. The air grew slightly colder, and he sensed he was underground.

      When the bag was removed, he found himself in a recording studio that looked like it had been built in an old wine cellar. Jonathon Brooks was there and came up to shake his hand.

      "Always a pleasure to meet a comrade from Spain," Brooks said.

      "Yes. I am unable to return to my home while the Fascists are there."

      "I understand what it is to be an exile, even it is one who exiled himself. You come on an auspicious night, but also a difficult one. It seems counter-revolutionaries are attempting to destroy our work here."

      "I am sorry to have come at such a difficult time."

      "Not at all, comrade, for tonight we shall light the true lamp of revolution. All who hear this call will be inflamed with the same desire that you and I have to overthrow the evil capitalists. Our names will go down in history!"

      "You speak with such passion. It intrigues me. I wish to help in any way. I have many special skills."

      "You understand the concept of the false consciousness that so many of the proletariat--who should be our natural allies--fall prey to? They believe the lies of the capitalists and the oppression they receive every day. But suppose I were to tell you that it is possible to override these emotions."

      "How do you mean?"

      "I have managed to discover a...substance, that in its weaker form makes people susceptible to hearing the call of true revolution. However, when the substance is purified over and over again, even a whiff of its scent is enough to make people open to any suggestion. Tonight, we hope to finish our radio mast, and my wife's music will be broadcast throughout the city. Those who are susceptible to it will awaken to its call and fight the capitalists, and we shall create a new Soviet, here, in Mexico!"

      [RP: Susceptible...does that mean anyone who's taken Nectar?
      Me: Yes. They've been selling Nectar all around town.
      RP: I was more worried about if I heard it...
      Me: Yes....]

      Brooks walked over to the mixing board and slapped a hand down on it. "I have no doubt, comrade," he said, warming to the subject, "that you will be there beside us when we raise the Red banner over the ruins of Tenochtitlan!"

      "This weapon you say you have devised...it proves to me that you are not just dedicated to the cause, but one who has harnessed science to our needs!" said Geronimo. "It is quite brilliant."

      "I know little of science," said Brooks smugly. "I am more of a romantic. Although some of my correspondents are quite educated in that line. Then again, one is an absolute idiot, consumed with the belief in some 'god'. While I know for a fact, comrade, that there are intelligences greater than our own--a fact predicted by science--I do think that if you're going to talk to one of them, you should know which one you are talking to! My colleague in Los Angeles is completely mistaken. He thinks he is talking to some, I don't know, witch-coven devil figure! No. I have scientific evidence that here, in Mexico itself, that a god--let us call it that, its capabilities are so far beyond our own as to make the comparison apt, although like you I believe in no supreme being--walks here in this country, and his cult still lives! These are all true things. And when we have completed our work in the Federal District, and raised the flag of revolution over all of Central America, I myself will visit this place. For the moment I have only been able to send a small expedition to prove the veracity of my theory."

      [Brooks does love the sound of his own voice. And he's full of projection.]

      Brooks poured himself a glass of wine and drained it. "Of course, we must also prepare ourselves, for I know the counter-revolutionaries are going to attack us tonight."

      "I am amazed at the depth of your preparation," said Geronimo.

      "Our organization has many contacts and arrangements with local groups."

      [MP: ...and magical birds!]

      "Excellent."

      "Yes, an organization we are affiliated with has been watching them for some time. Why, I am sure that they are gathering outside as we speak."

      The radio crackled and a familiar Georgian drawl came over the speaker. "Mr. Brooks, they're entering the hacienda now," said Bethany Mae Hampton.

      "Very good," said Brooks. "Come in and help me manage the situation."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      At that moment Jimmy was showing Ruby and Millicent his rabbit foot as they waited outside the hacienda for a likely moment to infiltrate the grounds. "This burn mark is from when I fired off a flare gun at someone," he said, pointing to a scorched spot.

      "How did the flare get the rabbit's foot?" asked Millicent.

      "It happens when you're within ten feet of the target. These salt stains are from the Indian Ocean. And these burns are from when I was struck by a lightning gu....when I was struck by lightning." He looked up. "Come on, nobody's looking."

      [JP took a Stability refresh scene.]

      They crept across the open lot behind the hacienda. Jimmy made quick work of the padlock and they took a flight of stairs down deep under the surface. They came out in a darkened room. Beyond it lay a glassed in room, a recording studio of some kind.

      Jimmy saw the glint of light on several pistols as they were leveled at him. He jumped back into the stairwell. Bullets ricocheted around the walls. From above he heard the sound of someone trying to force open the storm cellar doors.

      Good thing I jammed the doors, Jimmy thought.

      [Preparedness roll by JP.]

      \nEpisode VI: Woodrow Wilson's Guns (Part 5)

      Geronimo heard the sound of gunshots from beyond the studio. "Good," said Brooks. "They've arrived."

      "Let me help you drive them off," said Geronimo. I need to get out of here, he thought, before Bethany gets here and blows my cover.

      "Though it is selfish of me and not befitting a true Communist, I'd like to keep you here. It's so rare that I have a chance to talk to an intelligent and dedicated comrade. However, I know your place is on the front line. I will stay here and coordinate. For Socialism!"

      "For Communism!" said Geronimo, grabbing a pistol and dashing off.

      [GP spent that Flattery point Ruby loaned him.]

      He ran through the recording studio and slipped into the darkened room beyond it. Four men with pistols were crouched down behind crates.

      "Brooks sent me," he said.

      "Good," said one of the men. "We've got them pinned down, and those crazy gringos Senor Brooks is working with are going to come down the stairs. We have them!"\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "Be back," said Jimmy. He jumped forward into a commando roll, popping up in the middle of the room firing his Thompson gun. Bullets ripped through the crates on his left. Two men shrieked in agony as the took slugs in their legs and stomachs, but they managed to get some shots off at Jimmy.

      Geronimo dropped into shooter's stance and fired at the two men next to him. One man went down with a bullet in his head, but his companion managed to slip past him and sprinted for the recording studio.

      Ruby clattered down the stairs and saw the man running for the studio. She fired a shot off but shattered a window on his left. Millicent came up next to her and fired off another round, shattering the window on his right.

      [Actually, they both hit but for not enough damage to drop him.]

      Jimmy fired off a second burst at the last gunman on his left, ripping his chest apart.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "We need to seal off that exit!" shouted Geronimo. "Bethany and her people are on their way!" He knelt down by the stairs to the surface and began planting some of the dynamite charges Ruby had been carrying.

      Ruby fired off another round at the studio. Jimmy shoved her rifle barrel down. "Careful, that's load bearing," he said to Geronimo, pointing at the doorway.

      [Architecture spend by JP to let Geronimo plant the charges quickly.]

      Geronimo worked feverishly and then lit the fuse. "Run!" he shouted and they all hurried through the studio. There was a loud bang behind them, followed by the sound of masonry collapsing.

      "That should hold them," said Geronimo, lighting a cigarette with shaking fingers.

      [Assessed everyone 2 points of Stability except for Geronimo, who had the Military background and so only lost 1.]

      They cautiously made their way into the sitting room. There was a closed door which they guessed hid a stairway to a lower floor. Ruby found Brooks' speech next to a microphone in the studio. "It's twenty pages long," she marveled.

      "They're undoubtedly waiting for us down there," mused Jimmy.

      Geronimo lit the fuse on another stick of dynamite, yanked open the door, and threw the stick down the stairs.

      [Me: Sure, that will work...but just for fun, if you roll a natural 1, something horrible will happen.]

      Jimmy slammed the door shut. There was another loud bang which rattled the door in its frame, followed by some shrieks of pain.

      [RP: I want to shoot that Anne woman (Bethany).
      JP: She attacked me with ninjas!

      That was my chat status for a couple of weeks.]

      They made their way down the stairs, guns drawn. At the bottom was some kind of storage room. Judging by the distribution of bodies, it looked like there had been two men standing on either side of the doorway at the end of the staircase. The dynamite had gone off right between them. One man was dead, two were unconscious, and one was moaning in agony, his legs shattered below the knees.

      "You should put him out of his misery," said Geronimo to Jimmy.

      "Why does it always have to be me?" said Jimmy, but he fired a shot into the wounded man's head.

      The room was filled with crates. They opened a few with a crowbar. Inside each of them were dozens--maybe hundreds--of record albums. They were unlabeled, but it didn't take much to deduce that this was some of Leticia's music.

      There was a whine of feedback and the metallic click of a public address system switching on.

      "Adios, gentlemen," said Brooks' voice. "But here's something my wife made, to sing you to your rest."

      An eerie, lilting woman's voice began to sing over the PA system. At the same time, in a basso obligato, came a deep voice from somewhere nearby, rich in subsonics, seeming to shake the very air.

      [I called for a rare Stability check here rather than a fixed Stability loss. There was a moment of confusion while we sorted out what the effect of the earwax was, but Ruby and Millicent both ended up at 0 and came under the spell of Leticia and the Mouth.]

      Millicent gave a shout out of hell and launched herself on Ruby. She was otherwise silent, of course--her Uncle Jack had told her to never say anything if she was there to kill someone. Ruby rolled on the floor with her, trying to put out her eyes with her fingers.

      Jimmy began to drone the Nahuatl folk tune that Elena had taught him.

      [JP: Alouette, gentile Alouette...
      Me: That is not the song!

      The song allows people to refresh any skill that is not Sanity or Health, but for once Stability was not excluded.]

      "I'm going to kill you!" shouted Ruby.

      "Once you are gone," said Millicent calmly, "I will return to Vanessa."

      [And so MP got a Drive refresh.]

      As Jimmy kept singing, the two women slowly came to their senses and stood up sheepishly. The deep voice nearby kept droning on, filling their heads, driving out coherent thought.

      "Sing!" said Geronimo. "We have to drive its evil away!"

      "I am the very model of a modern major general..." began Ruby.

      "Salve regina, mater misercordiae, vita dulcedo..." intoned Geronimo.

      Millicent, who was a linguist, harmonized with Jimmy in Nahuatl.

      Ruby, harking back to her sorority days, began to sing rhyming instructions to them. Millicent caught on and they were able to talk to each other after a fashion.

      [They both had Art.]

      They moved to the end of the room, where it split into two separate hallways. Jimmy could see that the stonework was probably from the Aztec period. They moved down the hallway and came up on a vast well in the ground. Jimmy stuck his head over the edge.

      An enormous, lipless, snaggle-toothed mouth completely filled the bottom of it, twenty feet away. Faster than he could see, a long slimy tongue shot out of the mouth and wrapped around his neck.

      \nEpisode VI: Woodrow Wilson's Guns (Part 6)

      Ruby fired her rifle at the tongue. The tongue unwound itself from Jimmy's neck and snapped around Ruby's neck.

      Millicent tried to stab it, but her knife had little effect. Jimmy fired a burst down the well but the tongue kept up its grip. Geronimo fired shots into the tongue, then threw himself on Ruby, pulling the tongue off her neck. Jimmy shoved her back out of the room, and Geronimo pulled out his bundles of dynamite.

      "Mr. Wright, what should I do?" said Millicent!

      "Go!" he shouted. Ruby stumbled into the corridor. The tongue lashed itself around his wrist and yanked him back to the edge. Ruby scrambled forward and pulled him back from the edge, prying the tongue off of his wrist and pushing him into the corridor.

      Geronimo looked at his tools. He only had short-burning fuses left. "Get out of here!" he called over his back.

      [GP was out of Demolitions at this point, so Geronimo was planning to detonate the bomb at close range. And then...MP offered a Cthulhu Mythos spend. And I knew the time had finally come for me to reveal some of Millicent's power.]

      Geronimo heard the sound of footsteps retreating down the corridor. He lit the fuse and prepared to throw it down the well. He felt strangely at peace, knowing that he'd see his brother again soon.

      As she ran, Millicent turned to look down the hall. "Mr. Cuevas isn't coming!" she said.

      "He's making sure the bomb goes off," said Jimmy.

      "That's not fair," said Millicent. "That's not fair."

      She stopped dead and pulled her hand out of Jimmy's. She swiveled around and raised her arm, just as Geronimo tossed the bomb...\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Afterward, they were never quite sure what happened, as they all lost consciousness in the confusion. But to Geronimo it seemed that as he let go of the dynamite, the corridor...warped...growing longer and longer, faster and faster, until he was thirty...forty...a hundred feet away from the well, all without his moving at all. There was a whistling, eerie noise in the air, and it seemed for a second that he heard strange voices singing. Then blackness rushed in from the edges and he knew no more.

      [So I screwed up slightly--fainting only lowers the total Sanity loss to one. But it seemed too awesome to not have everyone faint to keep from losing a point a Sanity, as this Very Mythos Shock would have Shaken everyone.]\n

      \nEpisode VI: Woodrow Wilson's Guns (Part 7)

      They came to at the bottom of a well. Twenty or thirty feet above them was an iron grate, the only source of light they had. The floor of the well was a disgusting muddy ooze.

      Ruby came shakily to her feet. All around her was the scent of Nectar. She looked up and saw a woman standing next to the edge of the well. A thick veil concealed her face.

      As she stared, she saw horrid Mouths open all along the sides of the well, dripping Nectar.

      Steady, steady, old girl, she thought. Flopping around in the mud isn't going to make all this horror go away. And...whatever just happened up there...I need time to think about this. Jimmy and Geronimo struggled to their feet next to her. Geronimo put a comforting hand on her shoulder.

      [RP actually made the Stability test to not go for the Nectar!]

      The woman began to talk in a sing-song voice, with a strange lisp. "You think you're clever," she said. "But you cannot kill our god."

      That voice, thought Ruby. Leticia de la Luz. She slowly began moving her hand around to her back and inside her blouse. She could still feel the little .25 Colt she had taped under her brassiere strap hanging between her shoulder blades. It was clear the rest of their guns had been taken.

      [Big Preparedness spend by RP.]

      "You will have much time to contemplate this," continued Leticia, "as you sit here and slowly die of disease. But I do owe you a farewell...so I will sing you a lullaby."

      With a snarl, Ruby pulled the pistol free, spun it in her hand, and fired it directly up at Leticia. The shot buried itself in her chest. Black ichor began to pour out of the wound, and the veil slipped from Leticia's face. She bent down, glaring at Ruby, and then her face split down the middle, revealing ragged edges filled with teeth. A hissing growl filled the air.

      Ruby sighed and began to collapse into the ooze. As she slipped down, Jimmy snatched the gun from her hand and emptied the clip directly into Leticia. He stood there for several moments, finger spasmodically squeezing the trigger even as the hammer clicked on an empty chamber, black ooze dripping down onto his face from Leticia's lifeless body.

      Geronimo gently took the gun from him and lowered Jimmy's arm. "Millicent has fainted. I believe you can make your way to the top by stabbing the mouths with a knife and using them as a handhold. I experimented on some of the nearby ones, and they do not bite after being stabbed."

      Jimmy shook his head and grunted, and then began the long climb up the slimy walls. He glanced down to see Geronimo propping up Ruby. It was clear that some Nectar must have gotten into her mouth when she fainted the second time.

      When he reached the top, he swung out onto the grille, holding himself suspended by one hand while rifling through Leticia's pockets with the other. Eventually he found a key that unlocked the grille, and pulled himself up into another underground storage room. There was some rope nearby and he used it to pull the women and Geronimo out of the pit.

      Nearby, they could hear the sound of a gramophone playing some sad French Socialist songs.

      Geronimo found a couple of the kind of pistols Brooks' men had been carrying on a table in one corner. He handed one to Jimmy, and they walked toward the sound of the music, which was coming from behind a nearby door.

      The door wasn't locked, but Jimmy kicked it in anyway. On the wall opposite to them was an enormous poster of Billie Holliday, with the mouth defaced and scratched away. A pink carpet gave the dank chamber an incongruously cheerful note. Brooks was sitting by the record player, with his back to the door. A picture album with photographs of Leticia and him, while she was still human, was open on his lap.

      He straightened when they came in the room, but didn't turn around. "Is she dead?" he asked.

      Jimmy and Geronimo looked at each other, and raised their guns.

      Brooks looked down at his hands. "Useless," he said. "Useless--"

      There were two loud bangs, and then the sound of a phonograph needle clicking at the edge of a record. \n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      When they came back, Jimmy and Geronimo found Millicent trying to hold Ruby down. They could see that she was in the grips of a Nectar sexual frenzy. Geronimo yanked Ruby away from the girl.

      She wrapped her arms and legs around the Spaniard. "Oh, Geronimo," she sighed. "Let's not restrain ourselves." She began pulling off the buttons on his shirt.

      Trembling, Geronimo gently pushed her away. "Now is not the time," he said huskily. "I...cannot. Not like this!" Not when she is not herself. "Jimmy! Help me!"

      Jimmy shoved Ruby away from Geronimo and twisted her around. He handcuffed her behind her back and then pushed her into a corner.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Millicent searched the blood-soaked room that Brooks had been shot in. She found a small datebook with an itinerary neatly written down inside, the history of an expedition to the city of Merida in the Yucatan. She also found a letter from Brooks to SS, with one interesting phrase: "The more I think about it, the more I am convinced that it really does all come down to Merida--that everything comes back to her..."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      They went their separate ways to prepare for the trip to the Yucatan. Ruby met Captain Murphy in Puerto Vallerta and decided to take a relaxing Pacific cruise through the Canal and then looping back up to Merida. Murphy was surprised by how fragile she was.

      Betty flew Jimmy, Janet, and Geronimo back to Los Angeles. Geronimo spent much of his time going to church, and confessing how much he had been tempted by fornication.

      Jimmy took Janet out on the town, meeting with the local bigwigs and trying to repair his fraying network of connections, including Senator Grey, who he ran into one night at the Players'.

      "How did that whole poisoning the reservoir thing turn out?" said Grey.

      "It had an explosive result."

      "I'm going to forget I heard that, since I'm a member of Congress. You know, I often think about that night I first met you. Then I drink."\n

      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 1)

      Millicent was waiting for Ruby to arrive at Grand Central Air Field. As she flipped through the morning newspaper, she came upon a small item:

      Graveyard vandalized--Caretaker Injured

      "Wait...I didn't...did I? No, I only vanished that one time..." she said to herself.

      "You need some more coffee, hun?" asked the waitress.

      "Yes, sure," she said, distracted. Betty and Jimmy walked into the coffee shop.

      "Flying this trip should be easy," Betty was saying. "Jump to Arizona, then eventually to New Orleans, and down to Havana to meet the Captain. You ever been in Havana, boss?"

      Jimmy grunted and took a slug of whiskey.

      But the trip turned out to actually be easy for once, and a few days later they were drinking Cuba Libres with Captain Murphy and Ruby in Havana.

      "It's just rum and Coke," said Jimmy.

      "It's the surroundings, James," said Ruby.

      "I've done some research," said Millicent brightly, hauling several books up on to the table.

      She had been thorough. They were headed to M\xe9rida, named--like all the other M\xe9ridas in the Hispanophone world--after M\xe9rida in Extremadura, Spain. An unholy proportion of the conquistadors had been from that region, and many of those had been from M\xe9rida. Fifteen or twenty years ago, the M\xe9rida in the Yucat\xe1n had been one of the richest cities in the world, full of men who had made their fortune in the hemp ropes made from the sistal plant. The region had been ravaged in the nineteenth century by the Caste War, an uprising of the Mayan tribes in the region that had never quite died down.

      [Library Use by MP; this came without a spend...]

      An interesting bit of trivia came up: there had been a famous shipwreck in 1911 of a SS M\xe9rida, which was rumored to have been carrying a large amount of the treasury of the Mexican government, fleeing the coming Revolution. No one had yet managed to salvage the treasure, if it existed.

      The Mayan civilization of the region had vanished centuries ago; their ruined cities, built around the sinkhole wells called cenotes, still littered the jungle.

      [As an aside, the cenotes were caused by the dinosaur-killer asteroid! This came from the Library Use spend that MP made.]

      One curious tribe of the region had drawn her attention: the Xoxul. Their name was a Mayan word for outcast or evil people. In 1850, an explorer named Arthur Cartwright had found ruins he called Chichen Xoxul, centered around a pyramid dedicated to "sorcery and the stars." The site was pretty remote and probably a ritual area, not an actual city, and made by the Mayans; the Xoxul had captured it from them.

      While Cartwright had translated the word Xoxul as wicked people, Millicent's research revealed that while that wasn't the original meaning of the word in Mayan, it had taken on that meaning in the region--because the local Mayans considered the Xoxul to be an evil group of magicians. The Xoxul, according to them, worshiped gods associated with the nine Lords of the Night, especially one god, whom they had made massive amounts of human sacrifice to--Golxumel.

      "That sounds like Gol-Goroth," said Jimmy.

      "Might be the same guy," said Millicent. "The Mayans said he was toad or birdlike, and one name the Xoxul had for him translates as Fisher."

      "The Fisher From Outside," mused Jimmy. "That's a name for Gol-Goroth as well."

      "There was a conquistador name Francisco de Belacazar," continued Millicent. "He wanted to visit Chichen Xoxul. But his guide told him that he would not take him there, for 'I am no Xoxul, nor will I go to their place.' Francisco went anyway...and was never seen again."

      "Just where is this Chichen Xoxul?"

      "On the estate of a guy named Francisco de la Vega. He has a big sistal plantation."
      [This all ended up being a Library Use 2-point spend, for volume and speed of information.]

      "I remember something about this," said Jimmy. He flipped around one of Millicent's books. "Yeah, look. This Golxumel guy came to the Yucat\xe1n at the end of the Mayan period. And they say he's going to return one day."

      "Do you think this is the being behind the mouths?"

      "Maybe...he might fit the description."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      They flew down to M\xe9rida the next day. Murphy had already made the crossing, and met them at their hotel. Charlie stood behind him, holding the bags and looking intently at Murphy, as usual.

      "We're going to need an in with this guy de la Vega," said Jimmy to Ruby.

      "One of my father's friends is down here, an American wildcatter. He can probably a find us place to meet the locals. We're meeting him for drinks tonight here in the hotel salon."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n


      "M\xe9rida ain't exactly what you call a hopping town," said Hank Peterson. "If you're looking for social life, do what I do and fly back to Havana."

      "We've done Havana," said Ruby, sipping her drink and leaning back against the mahogany bar.

      Hank was typical for a lot of her father's friends--one of the first generation of the great American oil prospectors. He had a salt and pepper beard, hair that hung lankly over his forehead, and wore a bolo tie. He had a thick East Texas accent.

      "Well, there's a club in town. Might be hard to get you in, your name ain't Spanish. Though you are rich, and that goes a long way."

      "Oh, but I have a Spanish name now," said Ruby. "There's my husband coming now. Hello, Geronimo!"

      "Se\xf1or Peterson," said Geronimo, shaking Hank's hand. "An honor. Ruby has said much about you."

      "Well, I'll be," said Hank, eyeing Geronimo a little suspiciously. "Congratulations to you both. You down here prospecting for your pa?"

      [Hank is suspicious because Geronimo has Credit Rating 2.]

      "No, I'm on an archaeological tour."

      "That is a big deal down here. There's Chichen Itza, where the Maya used to have their shindigs, and Uxmal...I don't even know what that is really. Thought it was a kind of tobacco, but I guess it was a city of some kind."

      "I was hoping to see those, and another place...Chichen..."

      "Xoxul," said Millicent. "I'm her secretary, Mr. Peterson."

      "And you are...what the hell are you?" said Hank to Jimmy.

      "A friend. Jimmy Wright."

      "Well...I suppose you can head down to the Conquistador Club. Happy to have you as guests. Mr. and Mrs..."

      "Cuevas."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "I need a wedding ring," said Ruby to Captain Murphy.

      "Now, Ruby, we've talked about this. You're a great gal and all, but you know my mistress is the sea."

      "No, it's for my fake marriage to Geronimo."

      "What?"

      "It's part of my master plan."

      "I know what I have to do then," said Murphy. He went to his cabin and returned with a flat wooden box.

      "Oh, you keep your jewelry there?"

      Murphy opened the box to reveal a pair of matched pistols. "All right, Jerry, you and I are going to have a duel over this!"

      "Murphy, this is the second fake husband of mine you've try to shoot!"

      "I didn't try to shoot him, I shot him! In the leg counts, according to the Code Duello!"

      "It counts, but you were drunk and trying to shoot him in the head."

      "I only let him off because he was crying."

      "Of course. This is all for the mission, so just calm down."

      "I don't even know why you'd want to even fake marriage to some guy named Joseph McCarthy!"
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n

      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nSeptember 2015 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 2)

      The Conquistador Club was formal in the way that only old-school Spanish colonials can pull off. The men wore cutaway jackets or military uniforms. Their women wore severe black full-skirted dresses heavy with lace. In one corner was an old Frenchman, a subaltern under Maximilian who had stayed mostly out of spite.

      The club itself had a magnificent Belle Epoque cast iron facade. The main salon had a domed glass roof. An orchestra played Viennese waltzes, although few people were dancing.

      Hank took Ruby on a tour of the room, talking to the landowners with mineral rights. Ruby chatted pleasantly with them while scanning the room.

      "Oh, who's that?" she asked, pointing at an elegant middle-aged man.

      "Him? That's Francisco de la Vega, local bigshot," said Hank.

      "Let us go make his acquaintance," said Geronimo.

      De la Vega had heavy features, thick eyebrows, and a face that naturally settled into a frown. He graciously kissed Ruby's hand and made a quick bow to Geronimo. "I can tell by your accent you are Aragonese, yes?"

      "Yes."

      "I had occasion to visit Zaragoza once. Charming city. I hope you know Barcelona? I had many happy days there, before the current difficulties. Soon, though, I think order will be restored throughout Spain and the good work of Generalissimo Franco will allow the king to return. I give money to his noble cause, and the Church to support the refugees. One day the Communist and socialist scum will be driven from our mother country."

      Containing his rage with aplomb, Geronimo nodded agreement. "It is to be hoped for."

      "You may have heard that we have similar difficulties here in Yucat\xe1n. The Mayans are succumbing to the poisonous allure of these false ideologies."

      Ruby turned the conversation to archaeology. "We've been to Chichen Itza and the other sites. I'm looking for something different, something few people have seen. I've heard that you have some ruins on your property."

      [Archaeology spend by RP; this was to impress de la Vega that she actually had been to some of the other sites, and allay his suspicions.]

      "I am impressed," said de la Vega. "I've known few women who have climbed the Stairs of Quetzalcoatl."

      "I am not many women."

      "No, indeed you are not," said de la Vega. Glancing at Geronimo, he made another quick bow. "Con su permisso, se\xf1or."

      "We would like to visit Chichen Xoxul, if you'll allow us on your land."

      "I think you would not be impressed. It is nothing more than an old well and some stones. Chicen means well in Mayan, as perhaps you know."

      "Your pronunciation is excellent."

      "Thank you. I have both Mayan and Spanish ancestry. I do not hold with these stuck up old fools who are obsessed with pure Spanish blood. There is good blood in this country too."

      "How admirable. But I would still like to visit the ruins."

      "I'm sure they will disappoint. However, please come out to my estate as my guests. My man will work it out with your man. Just let me know where you are staying."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Back at the hotel, Betty and Millicent were studying. At least until nine o' clock, when Betty threw down her book. "There's an excellent bar in this hotel," she said. "Why are we sitting up here in this room like a couple of old maids?"

      "Did you get at least half the questions right?"

      "I got some."

      "Good enough."

      They got dressed and dropped down to the ballroom. There was a lively crowd dancing to the Latin band, and many beautiful women in evening dresses floated through the crowd like exquisite tropical birds.

      Millicent perched on a stool by the bar, talking with the bartender. "I met a man in Mexico City who said he had sent some men out this way to look at some local ruins. I don't know their names, but he was called Jonathon Brooks. Have you seen anyone like that?"

      "You should talk to the local guides," said the bartender. "They don't come to a place like this."

      Millicent ordered another drink. A woman of about thirty, in a long midnight blue evening gown turned to her. "Pardon me, I couldn't help overhearing you talking before. Are you an American?" She had a nice upper-class British accent.

      "Guilty as charged."

      "Oh, thank God. I thought I wasn't going to be able to speak English again tonight."

      "Even with an American?" said Millicent, grinning. "What brings you here?"

      "I'm in transit, actually. Havana, then maybe Vera Cruz. Perhaps New Orleans after that, and New York. We haven't decided."

      "Havana is lovely."

      "Happy to know it, thanks. Actually, this is a bit of a wanderjahr for me. My husband is back in England taking care of our children, and a friend of mine asked me to come out and look after some of her affairs in the Americas. In the meantime I'm able to enjoy myself. My goodness, I love my children, but I haven't had a proper vacation in a decade. Evelyn O'Connell, by the way."

      "Millicent Lowell. This is my friend Betty Auckland."

      "How ya doin'?" said Betty, pumping Evelyn's hand. "This guy, I think he asked me to dance or for a fiver. One way or the other I'm gonna find out more." She bounced off to the dance floor accompanied by a tall, dark, and handsome Mexican man.

      "She certainly has joie de vivre," said Evelyn, with a wry grin. "Reminds me a bit of my husband, actually. He's American too."

      "Have you been to Los Angeles?"

      "Haven't the pleasure."

      "Just keep in mind that the water is rather cold at the beaches...about...you prefer Celsius or Fahrenheit?"

      "I'm used to both. I've been to the Continent, to Africa...rather a bally lot of places, actually. You see, I studied archaeology in Egypt about ten years ago."

      "Really? I'm a bit of an amateur archaeologist myself."

      They sank into a pleasant conversation. Evelyn proved extremely well-read, and had a wealth of information on Egypt.

      [Of course she should. My players didn't twig to it, but this is the same Evelyn O'Connell from the Mummy movies.]
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 3)

      Ruby unlocked the door to the hotel suite they were renting. "My God, I thought that Jean would never shut up--"

      She stopped short. The room was in complete disarray. The beds had been stripped, the dresser drawers had been pulled out and tossed, the backs of pictures had been pulled out to see if anything was hidden behind them.

      "James," she said. "It happened again."

      "Professional job," said Jimmy. "Good tradecraft. Probably couldn't have done it better."

      "Why'd they leave it such a mess, then?"

      "To send a message."

      "I have to go," said Ruby, dashing past Geronimo.

      "Where are the girls?" he said to Jimmy.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Ruby pounded on the hatch of the Murphy's Law, which was tied up at a landing not far from her hotel. The door opened, revealing a rather disheveled Captain Murphy. "Why, Mrs. Cuevas," he said. "Whatever brings you down here?"

      "One question: did you mess with anyone's room?"

      "Why would I do that? The only reason would be to send a message to someone."

      "Did you send a message to anyone?"

      "If I was going to do that, I'd use Western Union!" Murphy took a step forward, and stumbled. A strong arm grabbed him from behind and pulled him upright. Ruby looked into the tatooed face of Charlie.

      "You've never lied to me," she said. "Is he telling the truth?"

      Charlie nodded gravely.

      "Wait a minute," said Murphy. "Someone was in your room? Was it Geronimo?"

      "No, no. We're just doing the sting operation together."

      "So you're in trouble, eh Rubycakes? You should stay here with me tonight."

      "Wait here. I'll be back if there's any trouble. Keep drinking."

      "I was going to do that anyway!"\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "I'm planning to go on an expedition to Ethiopia with professor Fauche later this year," Millicent said to Evelyn.

      "Professor Luc Fauche? I met him. Quite charming. Now if you'll excuse me, I need to make a phone call." Evelyn got up and glided out of the bar. She passed Jimmy and Geronimo, who burst into the bar and made a beeline for Millicent.

      "Good, you're all right," panted Jimmy. "The room was searched. Again."

      "Why? We just got here! Until...oh...we're being watched, aren't we? Who the heck is following us?"

      "Who the hell isn't following us at this point?"

      "I think it was Bethany. And we didn't do much to hide our presence--we took Ruby's plane, and Murphy's ship will be in the arrivals column," said Geronimo.

      "And that grave I told you about, somebody vandalized the cemetery and attacked the groundskeeper," blurted Millicent.

      Jimmy sputtered. "We'll talk about it later," he said. "Betty! Get over here!"

      Betty came up with a tall, dark, Latin stranger. "Mr. J! This is Alfonso. He's...uh...tall."

      "Forgive me se\xf1or," said Alfonso, shaking Jimmy's hand gravely. "I did not realize you were her father."

      [In retrospect, this was the moment the session transformed from a serious Cthulhu investigation into a Neil Simon sex farce. I consider this one of the nicest presents any gaming group has ever given me as a GM.]

      "Damn right," said Jimmy.

      "Au revoir, se\xf1orita," Alfonso said, elegantly bowing to kiss Betty's hand.

      "We don't have time for that!" said Jimmy, pushing him away. "Betty! Our room got tossed!"

      Betty blanched. "I'm sorry, Mr. J. You can have my resignation right away. I mean, that's terrible tradecraft! It's not like Millicent can help me, she's just some schoolgirl!"

      "They didn't search our room until we left!" said Milicent.

      "Wait...we're being watched!"

      "See, you figured that out all by yourself! We need you! Mr. Wright needs you!"

      [GP, to JP: You need to be supportive.
      RP: Yeah, be a good father.]

      Ruby ran up to the bar. "Murphy didn't do it."

      "Who thought he did?" said Millicent.

      "I did. He's kind of a jealous guy."

      "Betty, don't worry about it," said Jimmy. "It happens. But a private eye needs to plan ahead. Remember that."
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nSeptember 2015 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 4)

      "We must keep up appearances," said Geronimo, walking Ruby back to the suite. "If we are being watched, we must keep up the pretense that we are husband and wife."

      "Good point," said Ruby, walking into the debris of the room. She opened the door to her room of the suite. "We'll sleep together tonight."

      Geronimo stopped dead at the threshold of the room. The large crucifix fixed to one wall seemed to glare at him. Ruby obliviously went into the bathroom to prepare her evening toilet.

      "I can't," said Geronimo, waving his hands in front of his face. He gently lifted the crucifix from the wall and carried it out to the balcony. On the balcony next to his, an old man was standing smoking. He watched Geronimo with a puzzled expression on his face. Jewish? he mouthed at him.

      Geronimo shrugged and went back into the room.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Jimmy stopped at the front desk to collect Janet. He rang the bell and asked the night clerk to bring him the contents of the safe he'd given them when he checked in.

      "What do you keep in there?" asked Janet.

      "Some books."

      The clerk returned with a few bundles of letters, and a heavy algebra textbook.

      "Mr. Wright, that's my book! I've been looking for it!" said Millicent.

      Unperturbed, Jimmy opened the book. A section of the pages had been cut out in a neat square, creating a hollow containing a moldering old book with a cracked binding.

      "Isn't that one of the books we took from Trammel's?" asked Millicent.

      Jimmy nodded. "I like to hide those kinds of books. It's too dangerous to leave them where they can be found."

      "Jimmy, isn't that awfully paranoid?" asked Janet.

      "I can't remember the last time my room wasn't searched," said Jimmy, taking her arm and leading her towards the stairs. "I think my paranoia has justification."

      An old man came up to the counter as they were leaving and angrily stubbed out a cigarette. "I was assured," he said to the startled night clerk, "That you did not allow those people into this establishment..."

      While the clerk and the old man argued, Janet leaned in to Jimmy. "With everything that's happened tonight, I just...don't feel comfortable sleeping alone."

      "Fine," said Jimmy. "I'll take the couch."

      "Oh," said Janet. She paused a moment. "I suppose I should tell you, that in this tropical weather, I simply have to sleep in the nude."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Millicent and Betty returned to the room they shared and tried to clean up the mess. Why do they always have to be so thorough, Millicent thought to herself, and sighed. As she made her bed, she noticed that her copy of Tropic of Cancer was exactly where she had left it on the nightstand.

      That's odd, she thought. Why didn't they move it? She flipped through the pages of the book. Many passages had been underlined by her, with some notes scribbled in the margins. She was about to put the book back when she noticed something odd. There were some underlined passages that hadn't been there before; in fact, they were past her bookmark, in sections of the book she hadn't read yet.

      "So Millicent," Betty said, breaking her out of her reverie, "When you're done picking up your side of the room, could you clear out for a while? Alfonso is gonna come up to see me."

      "If it's just for that, then okay. But if he's going to kidnap you--"

      "Nobody's kidnapping me," said Betty, chambering a round in the large .45 automatic she kept under her pillow.

      "Good enough," squeaked Millicent. "I think I'll go tell Mr. Wright that Evelyn O'Donnell knows Professor Dreamy Eyes...just in case..."

      She ran through the living room and tapped on the door to Jimmy's room. Inside, Jimmy was nervously reading a copy of Popular Sistal Growing, which was in Spanish, and anyway he was holding upside down.

      "Jimmy," said Janet from the bed, "could you maybe give me a backrub? I'm really tense."
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n I understand why Geronimo resisted temptation. I'm not entirely sure why Jimmy did.
      \n

      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nSeptember 2015 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 5)

      Ruby stretched out on the bed in her silk neglig\xe9e, her sleep mask daintily tied over her eyes, blissfully asleep with one hand clutching the gun she kept on the nightstand.

      Geronimo stood on the balcony smoking, wearing only his undershirt and shorts. He looked down and saw a man climb up the balcony next to his. The man glanced at him, held a finger to his lips, and whispered "Shh! Se\xf1or."

      From the room behind the balcony, Geronimo heard Betty's hoarse whisper. "Alfonso! C'mere!"

      Geronimo looked over at the crucifix leaning up against the side of the balcony. "I'll give him twenty minutes," he said, and lit another cigarette.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Down at the Murphy's Law, Captain Murphy was sweeping the side of the hotel with his telescope. He saw the light from Geronimo's cigarette and focused in on the Spaniard. "He's smoking! You know what that means, Charlie! It means--"

      But Charlie would have to wait. Murphy's wild gesticulations and inebriated state combined to make him trip, stumble, hang for a long moment precisely balanced on the edge of the deck, and then tumble over backwards into the water.

      He came up sputtering. "Charlie! Stop pointing and grinning! Help me up outta here! Enough with your games!"

      Charlie held out one hand. "You are lucky the code of honor among my people does not allow me to attack you in such an inebriated state," he said in a South Pacific language of great antiquity. "One day you will be awake enough."

      With one great muscled arm he hauled Murphy onto the deck and then went back to sharpening his kukri.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Ruby awoke, oddly enough, with the dawn. She took off the sleep mask and saw Geronimo snoring quietly in a chair next to the French doors that led to the balcony. Somehow he managed to keep his back straight even while asleep, she noted. A cigarette had burned itself out while still clutched in two fingers. She gently removed the butt and then covered him lovingly with a blanket. She gave him a peck on the cheek.

      She stepped out onto the balcony. Glancing over at Betty's room, she saw a man climbing down out of her balcony. The man paused, then held a finger to his lips. "Shh! Se\xf1ora!" he said, and finished sliding down to the ground.

      Ruby shrugged, and turned back to go into the room. Noticing the crucifix that was propped up in one corner, she picked it up and brought it inside with her. She hung it up on the wall and went to make herself up for the day.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Neither Jimmy nor Janet had slept at all during the night. As the dawn light streaked across the sky, Janet yawned and sat up in bed, careful to keep the sheets pinned to her chest.. "Morning, James."

      "Morning."

      "I'm going to do my toilet, so maybe you should go to the other room."

      "Sure." Jimmy slowly made his way into the living room, where Millicent was folding up a blanket.

      "Morning Mr. Wright," she said chirpily. "See, I slept in the same clothes I was wearing, that's a plus, isn't it?"

      "I need a cup of coffee right now," said Jimmy.

      "Oh, I made some. Would you like a cup--"

      Jimmy grabbed the pot from her with a barely-concealed snarl.

      There was a muffled shout from Ruby's room. Jimmy ran to the door and yanked it open to find Geronimo staring at the crucifix, which was directly across from the chair he was sitting in. "I've done NOTHING!" said Geronimo to the wooden figure of Jesus. "I have done nothing but protect her!"

      "Easy," said Jimmy, guiding Geronimo out to the balcony. They stood for a moment in the golden sunlight.

      The doors to Betty's balcony shot open and Betty stepped outside. "What a morning!" she crowed, stretching magnificently. "Hey, how did you guys sleep last night?"

      "James," said Geronimo, lighting a cigarette. "Cafe, por favor."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Janet met Ruby coming out of her room, immaculately turned out as always. "So, how was your night?" she asked.

      "Oh, I slept beautifully," said Ruby.

      "Well. Congratulations to you, then."

      "You didn't sleep well?"

      In answer, Janet picked up the phone. "Room service? Could you send up a pitcher of bloody marys?" She looked at Ruby. "You want anything?"
      \n

    Eternal Lies: Masks of the Liar [Trail of Cthulhu]

      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 6)

      "You think Mrs. O'Connell was in on it?" said Millicent.

      "Yeah," said Jimmy. "She distracted you while the room got tossed."

      "Sorry Mr. Wright."

      "It's all right. But you had a good idea about finding out what happened to Brooks' expedition. Let's find some of the local guides."

      A day's worth of talking to people turned up three names: Pablo Garza, Guillermo Castillo, and a third man named Jacinto Espinoza. Nobody had seen Espinoza for a while, however.

      "They're scared to talk about him," said Jimmy. "Let's find out why."

      After a while, he pieced together enough by reading between the lines to get a fix on the story: Espinoza had been hired by a party to head out into the woods near the de la Vega estate; they went into them about a month ago, and nobody had seen any of them since.

      "Maybe it was bandits," said one of his informants. "A lot of Maya are still upset they lost their empire. Six hundred and thirty-seven years, you'd think they'd give it up by now, but they're still upset at the Spanish."

      "And you haven't seen any of the Mexicans who hired Jacinto?"

      "No. If you want a guide, I guess you could hire Pablo, he's okay, or Guillermo."

      Another man spoke up: "Or they could hire Nic."

      "Yeah, like I'd tell them to hire Nic," said Jimmy's informant with a laugh. "You would not survive, se\xf1or."

      "Who's Nic?"

      "No, se\xf1or, I respect you too much...Nic is also a guide, grew up here. But...Nic has a temper. You are obviously a hidalgo of great standing, I would not inflict that on you."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      De la Vega sent a car driven by a liveried chauffeur of obviously Mayan ancestry. He drove Jimmy, Geronimo, Ruby, Millicent, and Janet out to the de la Vega estate.

      "Tail us," said Jimmy to Betty.

      As they reached the gate to the estate, they saw the de la Vega coat of arms displayed prominently over the gate. But nearby, etched into a wall, was an older coat of arms, mostly obscured by plaster and paint. But Ruby could just make out some of the details, especially the prominent letter E.

      "Wasn't...Echevarr\xeda from the Yucat\xe1n?" she asked Jimmy, who just shook his head.

      The de la Vega manor was at the end of a long, winding cypress lined drive. It was in turn of the century style, the cross between Belle Epoque and traditional Mexican hacienda style they had seen in M\xe9rida. They were conducted to a sitting room where they met de la Vega's other guests, some local plantation owners and their wives.

      De la Vega made an appropriately grand entrance, striding into the room wearing riding boots and a white summer cutaway. A few medasl hung from the breast of his dinner jacket. "Se\xf1oras y se\xf1ores," he said. "I am so glad you are all here. It is so rare we get a chance to speak to so many charming norteamericanos, not to mention a brother of ours from Espa\xf1a."

      "Thank you for having us," said Ruby in her most flattering tone.

      "The honor is mine. Allow me to show you some of the few treasures I am fortunate enough to possess." De la Vega led them down a hallway, pausing in front of an old oil painting that Ruby recognized as being in the style of the sixteenth century. It showed a man with hot black eyes and a stern face full of angry hauteur.

      "Is that Francisco de Belacazar?" said Millicent.

      "Yes, he was an ancestor of mine," replied de la Vega. He led them through a pair of ornate double doors into the dining room. It was a long chamber lit with candles and the dying glow of the sunset. The table was covered with an excellent linen tablecloth and expensive place settings. De la Vega sat down in a large chair at the head of the table. There was a fireplace behind him, and on one side of it was hung a painting. It must have been six feet long by was rather narrow, nearly filling the gap between the mantel and the wainscoting. It was a full body portrait of a woman in a long dress with a broad fringe of lace. The woman's face stared boldly out of the portrait, angular and somehow aristocratic.

      It looked disturbingly like the pictures they had seen of Leticia de la Luz before her transformation. But the painting was at least twenty years old.

      The other side of the fireplace was blank, although discolorations on the wall showed that it must once have held a painting the same size as the one of the woman.

      Ruby made some small talk about the other objets d'art in the house before turning to the portrait of the woman. "She's quite striking," she said. "Who is she?"

      "Ah, that belonged to the previous owner of this house," said de la Vega. "It is a sad story. Perhaps not best for dinner conversation."

      [Me: This is me running up the flag saying, you need to make a spend to get this.]

      "I understand," said Ruby. "Still, I find myself fascinated by everything I've seen in M\xe9rida--this house most of all. I'd love to hear any stories about it; it's such an elegant place, I know it must be really the most interesting place."

      [aaand Flattery spend by RP.]

      "It was not originally my family's house," said de la Vega, pleased despite himself. "They were a sad family, the Echevarr\xedas. They must all be dead now--certainly the male line has died out. They made their money long ago, even before the sistal--and after that, they made their fortune. They fell on hard times. The son was involved in the Revolution, but he never returned to the Yucat\xe1n. That painting is his sister, Leticia de Echevarr\xeda. Most people called her M\xe9rida, because she was a natural child of their father. He legitimized her, but you understand how people are; she was clearly Mayan. They were very close...and she was once my betrothed."

      "What happened to her?" asked Geronimo.

      "No one is really sure," said de la Vega. "But my investigations indicate she most likely died in a shipwreck in 1911."

      "How awful," said Ruby. "I am sorry for your loss."

      "She was an exceptional woman. Her kind comes very, very rarely. But I am distressing my guests. Please, enjoy your dinner."

      The dinner proved to be mostly local fare, and obviously made as hot as possible. Millicent, who had grown up eating Singapore food, dug in with relish. Geronimo shrugged; he'd eaten gypsy food before. Jimmy and Ruby made the best of it they could.

      [It was, in fact, a choice between losing 1 Stability or 2 Health.]

      "Se\xf1ora Cuevas," said de la Vega over brandy, "have you decided what archaeological site you wish to visit? I could arrange a trip to Chichen Itza."

      "Already been," parried Ruby. "This Chichen Zoshul..."

      "Xoxul," said de la Vega.

      "Yes. I really am interested."

      "Well, how can I refuse a woman of your caliber? You have my permission to visit my grounds. But I must insist you hire a guide. It is impossible otherwise."

      "I've heard the names of a few...a Guillermo?"

      "Se\xf1or Castillo? Strangely enough, he is exactly who I would recommend. He is a man of breeding and aristocratic bearing, extremely knowledgeable, especially about the Mayan ruins. If any man could guide you to Chichen Xoxul, it is him."

      "And Pablo Garza?" asked Millicent.

      "A peasant. He is insignificant."

      "There was also another man," said Ruby. "A Nicolas?"

      "Oh, you mean Nic? Ah...Nic...well, se\xf1ora, if you insist on hiring Nic, you find that to be it's own reward."

      "Is he an odd fellow?"

      "One could say so, yes," said de la Vega smugly.

      "Does he know the ruins?" asked Millicent.

      "Nic's father was an archaeologist from the United States who married a Mayan woman, and Nic was raised in both worlds. If you insist on hiring Nic Luke, then you should go to the garage near the waterfront. I think you find Nic there, and decide for yourself how that will work for you."

      "We'll find a guide tomorrow, but I'll probably hire Guillermo."

      "I will have him call upon your hotel," said de la Vega.
