      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 7)

      After dinner, de la Vega brought out a small band and took everyone to the manor's ballroom. "May I dance with your lovely wife? Con su permisso, se\xf1or," said de la Vega to Geronimo.

      Geronimo glowered but let de la Vega lead Ruby away. "Come on, Mr. Cuevas, I'll dance with you," said Millicent, pushing Geronimo out into the dance floor.

      [Geronimo's Credit Rating of 2 got hammered in this scene; he simply wasn't equipped to deal with rich folks being jerks, didn't know the dances, didn't have the right table manners, etc. Listening to the tape I may have hit this note a bit too much, but de la Vega is a smug aristo and pretty suspicious of them all, so he pressed all his advantages.]

      "Dance me closer to the corner," said Janet in Jimmy's ear as he led her in a brisk Viennese waltz. "I want to hear what Ruby is saying!"

      "Se\xf1ora Cuevas," said de la Vega while guiding her through an elegant turn, "I must recommend you not go into the woods. It is not safe. There are bandits. You must be very wary of these Maya, they are without pity and do not take prisoners...of the men. I think you understand me."

      "I've been in hairier situations in the past," said Ruby.

      "I expected no less of a woman of your mettle."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      The next day Guillermo Castillo called on them at their hotel. He wore an immaculate white suit with spotless linen. He had a dancer's natural grace and stance, and stood smoking a long, thin French cigarette. "My good friend Don de la Vega asked me to come and see you. You are looking to put together an expedition? Good. If you are looking for Chichen Xoxul, I cannot advise it, for it is in extremely difficult terrain and to be frank...I do not think a beautiful woman such as yourself would be willing to make such a journey."

      "Well, luckily for me I'm not Frank. I'm Ruby."

      "Se\xf1or de la Vega told me you were extremely witty. But he did not do credit to your beauty."

      "Have you met my husband?" said Ruby, pushing Geronimo forward.

      Castillo backed away slightly from the Spaniard's grim face and iron handshake. "I will need a hundred pesos a day," he said quickly. "You will not interfere in the hiring of the porters as I only work with my own men. I will advise you in the purchase of equipment. If I tell you to buy a piece of equipment, you will buy it, or I will not come. If you try to interfere, fire, or otherwise disrupt my men, we will leave immediately. You must understand that while you are my client and I will do everything to fulfill the objectives of the mission, I am the guide. And you must follow my instructions absolutely in the woods. It is the only way to ensure your survival. Do you have weapons?"

      "We are very much prepared," said Geronimo.

      "You have an Aragonese accent, don't you?" said Castillo. "I have heard that only the anarchists and socialists have left Aragon, and the patriots were those who stayed."

      [RP: What a sh*tbag!]

      "It became very uncomfortable for me in that environment," said Geronimo with deadly calm.

      "Well, the war will soon be over. I must take my leave. If you wish to hire me, inform the concierge. Good day."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "I don't think he liked you very much," said Ruby to Geronimo as they trooped down to the waterfront.

      "I don't think many people here like me," said Geronimo. "I am sure they think I am some kind of adventurer who has seduced you."

      "Oh," said Ruby.

      They came upon a large garage perched at the end of pier. The place bustled with activity. Men in greasy shirts were crouched over all different types of engines--automotive, maritime, even an airplane engine. Ruby grabbed the nearest man. "I'm looking for Nic," she said.

      "For Nic? Sure, who's asking?"

      "I am. Can you go get him?"

      "Him? Sure, why don't you come with me."

      The man led them into an out of the way section of the garage. "He Nic, these gringos want to see you!" the man said to someone who had their head buried under the hood of a car.

      The person straightened up and turned around.

      "Oh," said Ruby. "Nic is short for Nicole."

      Nic was a shortish woman with long, straight brown hair she had tied up under a bandanna. She wore a man's sleeveless tee shirt that was stained with oil and grease. She had a hard but not ugly face. A cigarette dangled out of the corner of her mouth. She put a wrench in the pocket of her jeans, wiped off her hands on a rag, and said something in Yucat\xe1n dialect to her employee. They both smirked.

      "What the hell do you want in my garage," said Nic.

      "We've heard you're a guide--"

      "I'm not a guide. I'm not just going to lead you around from place to place. My father was an archaeologist, I am an archaeologist by training."

      "So am I. We want to go to--"

      "You're not an archaeologist. I know exactly what you are. You're one of those rich American dilettantes who come down here to 'make' a big discovery! See how the local people live! But do you care? You're going to leave what, a nickel for some poor Mayan kid who's half blind from eating millet? Whose parents had their legs cut off by the Spanish? This is why I don't work as a guide anymore. I'm tired of dealing with you rich Yanqui bastards coming down here."

      "Do you or do you not want our money?" demanded Geronimo.

      "Depends. What do you want me to do?"

      "Take us to Chichen Xoxul."

      "This your wife?"

      "She is."

      "I am very sorry, se\xf1or. Because clearly one of you must be dying if you want to go to Chichen Xoxul, and have decided that the best way to do it is to commit suicide! It is very romantic that you want to do it together."

      "Listen," said Ruby. "I'm here because I want to see stuff the way Bartolom\xe9 de las Casas described it, before the Spanish burned everything down. I am here to feel ten centuries of civilization stare down at me as I humble myself before the greatest pyramids of anywhere outside Cairo. I've read the Mayan codices, and I want to visit the tombs of those great men. To pay my respects, with sorrow."

      [Art History spend by RP to swing Nic around.]

      "You remind me of my father a tiny bit," said Nic. "He was a Yanqui but not a bastard. He helped people down here. During the caste war, he fought with the Mayans. You. Spaniard. What are you, Popular Front, or one of those assholes who work for Franco?"

      Geronimo stared back. "Don't mention that man to me, or remind me of the sorrow he has inflicted on Spain."

      Nic nodded. "I'll take you into the woods. You don't pay me. You don't have to pay me anything. You pay for the porters; I'll find them for you. You pay for the equipment too. What I want isn't money. I want a hundred rifles."

      "Only if you promise to save at least one bullet for this de la Vega," said Geronimo.

      "You've got a deal."

      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 8)

      The mist was just beginning to break over the jungle and blow back out over the water when Ruby heard the sound of a plane's engine. After a short time, a seaplane emerged out of the mist, engine spinning down as it glided into shore.

      A door opened in the back of the plane and Dr. Orange stuck out his head. "Ruby! You look...rugged?"

      Ruby was wearing khaki slacks, a military style blouse, a camp hat, and had a rifle slung over her back. "Good to see you, Doctor."

      Dr. Orange hopped to shore. "Got your message, and Comrade Trotsky sends his regards." A couple of Mayan campesinos began to unload long flat crates out of the plane.

      "Who's the dame?" asked Julius, nodding at Nic.

      Ruby grabbed his arm. "We need Nic, okay? So be respectful. Now come on, I'll take you down to the village."

      "You left the hotel?"

      "The housekeeping wasn't up to our standards."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Jimmy arrived at the Conquistador Club. "I'm a guest of Don de la Vega," he told the concierge, who silently led him to a private room in the back.

      The room was a study in contrasts: a tasteful sitting room in the English style...with some of the more graphic and gruesome examples of Mayan art lining the walls. De la Vega was sitting in an armchair in his immaculate ice cream suit.

      "Mr. Wright," he said. "I'm glad you could make it down here to talk to me."

      "It was a bit of a surprise, actually."

      "Are you still planning to make your expedition to Chichen Xoxul."

      "Yes."

      "I am here to warn and beg you not to do this."

      "Warn me? Why?"

      "You must understand that the cult of the Xoxul has never completely died away. But it is different than it was in the old days, just as the Maya today are much different than they were before the Spanish arrived. The Xoxul were a people that wanted to find knowledge. That they used techniques that to them seemed natural and normal but to us seem repellent is perhaps an indictment of the human race, not the drive for knowledge. But more than that, se\xf1or, things have changed even in my own lifetime. Chichen Xoxul is a cursed place now. I do not recommend you go there. And it is not the fault of the Xoxul that it has become like this. Something else has made it this way."

      "Trust me when I say if I had the choice not to go there, I would not go there."

      "Ramon was such a man as you were. He wanted to go beyond the old ways. He knew of them, of course; his family, especially on his mother's side, they all knew the old ways. But he went too far, I think; he did something terrible out there, and it had consequences that nearly destroyed him."

      [JP used Assess Honesty to determine that de la Vega really was genuinely concerned.]

      "Why should I trust you about this?"

      "You must understand that I had nothing to do with what happened to the previous expedition," said de la Vega. "I am not necessarily sorry they did not reach Chichen Xoxul...unless they did. And in that case, Chichen Xoxul took care of them."

      "Somebody has to right things. Somebody has to fix that mistake. And it looks like it has to be me this time."

      "You are a brave man, Mr. Wright."

      "I try not to think about it."

      "I have so far managed to keep the Federales from intervening. Oh, they are very interested in you!"

      "I appreciate it."

      "Are you sure that what you will do will not cause consequences to everyone else?"

      "No."

      "Then why should I not bring in the Federales, to stop you from doing this mad thing?"

      "If nobody does anything, the world is screwed anyway."

      "So you do this to protect others? Not for your own power?"

      "Yes."

      "In that case, go with God, Mr. Wright. Whichever one you call your own."

      "I think I've had enough of gods in my lifetime."

      "You may see many strange things at Chichen Xoxul. It is a very dangerous place."

      "Do you recommend a blindfold?"

      "No. There is no way to go through it except with your eyes open."

      "I was afraid you would say that."

      "But if I can offer you assistance, I will."

      "Do you have a map of Chichen Xoxul? From previous times?"

      "Yes. I will bring it to you. And please share a drink with me. It would be...my honor."

      [De la Vega is written as a straight badguy cultist in the original text, but I was getting a bit sick of the "If it's Tuesday, it must be Omar Shakhti" nature of Cthulhu campaign antagonists. So I decided to switch him around a bit; to make him actually trying to protect people by keeping them away from the site, as well as modifying the Xoxul rituals so that they were no longer one of Lovecraft's xenophobic murder/human sacrifice outfits.]

      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 9)

      Millicent decided to see if she could ask around about M\xe9rida Echevarr\xeda, the adopted daughter--and presumably, natural daughter--of Ramon Echevarr\xeda's father. She found out, by buying coffee and flowers from various abuelas around town that M\xe9rida came to the Echevarr\xeda household when she was ten or eleven, and almost immediately she and Ramon became extremely close. Maybe...too close. She uncovered a rumor that in fact the two of them were in a morganitic marriage when they were both 16.

      Both Ramon and M\xe9rida had been on the the steamer SS M\xe9rida that had sunk off the coast of Norfolk, Virginia. Fast-talking her way into the port warden's office, Millicent found out that while M\xe9rida Echevarr\xeda had left from Vera Cruz, Ramon met them when the ship arrived in Cuba. M\xe9rida was not listed among the survivors of the wreck.

      M\xe9rida had two children: Salvador, who died when he was a boy, and a girl most people called Rosacruz. Nobody has seen her since after M\xe9rida vanished; it was rumored she went to Mexico City to live with relatives.

      When Millicent finally returned to her hotel room, on her bed she found a copy of Lady Chatterly's Lover with a note in a feminine hand written inside the cover: "Thought you might enjoy this one too."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      By May Day they were all staying in a coastal Mayan village, the guests of Nic Luke and her friends. This was Zapatista territory, and as friends of Trotsky they were all welcomed by the local leftist guerrillas. Ruby was bothered that Geronimo seemed to have disappeared, but shrugged it off as part of the Spaniard's often melancholy need to be alone.

      They were sitting down to a wonderful meal of local Mayan dishes when a young man came running into the village, shouting in Mayan and Spanish. Everyone gathered around him. He had brought a copy of the International Herald Tribune from a few days ago which had a front-page story about the destruction of a Basque market town named Guernica by the Germans.

      Dr. Orange found himself stared in an unfriendly way by the villagers, who seemed to want to find and hurt a German, even if he was a Social Democrat. He went to Nic and asked her to try and calm them down. "I'm on your side," he pleaded. "I was fighting the Nazis in the 1920s!"

      [I offered an Oral History spend to give an inspiring speech, but OP was content with using Oral History to calm people down enough to keep them from trying to lynch him.]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n
      Geronimo still hadn't turned up by evening. Ruby spent some time pensively watching the jungle. "Where do you think he could be?" she asked Jimmy.

      "Safe," he said immediately. "He can take care of himself. Maybe he had to go do something important...but you can bet that he was thinking of you when he did it."

      Ruby nodded and turned away toward her tent.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      The next day they set out into the broiling, steamy forests of the Yucat\xe1n. Ruby, a veteran of previous trips into the African and Asian jungles, was the only one not immediately miserable; even Millicent, who still remembered growing up in Singapore, was wilting.

      "I hate the jungle," muttered Jimmy. "Why do I keep ending up in them?"

      "This is ridiculous," complained Dr. Orange. "Ridiculous!"

      "Didn't you study archaeology?" asked Millicent. "Doesn't this interest you at all?"

      "Ja, ja, it's great. I'm sweating in places I didn't know could sweat! Why can't we just study books on this, like a real archaeologist?"

      Every mile cost them untold sweat and hard labor; they were blazing a trail through practically untouched jungle, but slowly they cut their way through it. On the third day of the expedition, they came upon a beat up truck in a clearing, parked near a muddy skid trail.

      Jimmy searched the cab. He found some spent brass from a rifle, and what looked like a bullet hole in the door.

      "Somebody tried to hotwire the truck," said Dr. Orange, pointing to the wires dangling below the dashboard. "And the distributor is missing."

      "I don't know they're related," said Jimmy. "Locals might have tried to strip it after whoever these guys were bought it."

      "Look at all the overgrowth around the truck," said Ruby. "It's probably been here for a month or so."

      "Right when Brooks' expedition was in the area," said Jimmy.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Just before they pitched camp they came across their first artifact--a heavily carved column in the Mayan style, broken near the top.

      "This wasn't Mayan," said Dr. Orange. "But it was designed to warn them. The top probably had some kind of head or other image on it, but it looks like someone broke it off."

      [Archaeology use by OP.]

      "Think it was looters?" asked Jimmy. "Or archaeologists?"

      "What?"

      "I knew an archaeologist once...that would have been his style."

      They pitched camp near the pillar. The porters sang quietly by the fire, strumming a guitar for accompaniment. Dr. Orange took a few turns around the clearing. He stared into the gloomy jungle, stopped for a second, and then ambled over to Jimmy's tent.

      Jimmy rolled awake when Dr. Orange kicked the tent pole. "There's somebody watching us," said the German.

      "Wait here," said Jimmy, throwing on his pistol holster. "I'll find Nic."

      Dr. Orange shrugged, waited for Jimmy to leave the tent, and then plunged into the jungle, creeping as quietly as he could through the forest. It had rained recently and water dripped from the leaves all around him, sparking silver in the moonlight. Up ahead he saw two figures standing in a shadowy clearing, quietly talking to each other. But as he tried to get near to them, they suddenly fell silent.

      He turned around and ran back to the camp. Behind him, he heard crashing sounds as if the two people he had seen were running away from him as well.

      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 10)

      "Where's Nic?" said Jimmy to Millicent.

      "I haven't seen her."

      "Damnit. Listen, tell everyone to be on their guard. Somebody's watching us. Don't make a big deal out of it, just make sure everyone is ready. Where could Nic be?"

      Dr. Orange stumbled into camp. "They heard me!" he panted.

      "Who?" demanded Ruby.

      "I don't know! There's always a they."

      At just that moment, Nic came walking out of the jungle on the other side of the camp.

      "What's going on?" she said.

      "We're being watched," said Jimmy.

      "There are a lot of Indians in the jungle."

      "We're the twitchy sort," said Ruby.

      "You're paranoid even for gringos."

      "You know these Indians?"

      "I don't know every single Indian in the Yucat\xe1n."

      "But you know the area, right?" said Dr. Orange. "So let's go see who's watching us."

      "I don't think that would be a good idea."

      "Could they be hostile?" said Ruby.

      "There's always the possibility of hostility when you travel across other people's land."

      "And where were you, exactly?" said Dr. Orange.

      "I was checking on things. I am the guide. Do you want me to stop doing my job? I can just stop here--you know the way from here."

      Ruby shook her head. "She's not telling us everything," she whispered to her companions.

      [Assess Honesty use.]

      "Let's gather the mob and light some torches, wave some pitchforks," said Dr. Orange.

      "Pitchforks?" said Millicent.

      "Metaphorically."

      "The mob that she hand-picked, and speak Mayan?" said Jimmy.

      "We know where we're going! We can make it the rest of the way!"

      "Herr doktor," said Ruby, "where's the sun going to come up tomorrow? You don't know, do you?"

      "So what! We can do this! We've got hostages!"

      "No. They've got hostages. We're in their territory. We are their guests. Or their prisoners."

      [I ruled that Ruby was basically using Flattery unintentionally here to defuse the situation.]

      "Fine, you deal with it!" huffed Dr. Orange. He dove back inside his tent.\n

      \n

      \n

      Jimmy regarded Nic carefully. He didn't think she was being hostile, but he didn't know why she had concealed what she was doing. He walked up to her calmly and said, "You understand. We're in a place that's foreign to us. But we got you those rifles--you know we've seen a lot of action. So being watched in an unfamiliar place, and then having you not be completely honest about where you were--that's going to put us on edge."

      [Me: Wow, that sounds really Reassuring.]

      "You want to know what I was doing?" said Nic. "Fine, come with me. If you trust me."

      They walked into the dark forest, stepping off the trail and into the underbrush. After a short but difficult passage they burst into a tiny clearing. An old native woman was sitting by a small charcoal fire, singing atonally as she stirred a pot hung over the fire.

      "This is Estrella," said Nic. "She's a wise woman of the Xoxul tribe. She was telling me about the new danger that appeared in the area a few years ago."

      "New danger?"

      "You understand that Chichen Xoxul has always been a haunted place. But in the last fifteen years or so, there's some new terror that inhabits this place. Some people say it's a ghost, some say it's an animal...but whatever it is, it doesn't seem to be a creature of the waking world. I think it was dragged from the Mayan dreamtime myself. I'm superstitious that way."

      Nic turned and said something to Estrella in Xoxul. The old woman replied, and Nic struggled to translate. "It looks like...something toadlike....or birdlike...maybe like a jaguar. I was trying to decide if we should go forward--Estrella has always been right about everything she's said to me. Well, except my ex-husband. If I didn't like what I heard this time, I was going to get us 'lost' tomorrow."
      "And what was your decision?"

      "I hadn't made up my mind yet. And then my men said something about you planning to murder us all..."

      "No one was planning to murder you."

      "I assume that's what the German was saying. You know how they are."

      "Oh, him. He's had too much sun."

      "...all right. I'll take you to Chichen Xoxul. I don't think my men will want to accompany you inside, however."

      As they left the clearing, Estrella called out something.

      "She wants to know your name," said Nic.

      "Jimmy Wright."

      Estrella started laughing. "Jimmy, ha ha ha ha..." She said something in Xoxul.

      Nic looked puzzled. "What does 'the rest of the rabbit' mean?" she said.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Jimmy came back to camp to find Ruby and Millicent giving an impromptu reading of Lady's Chatterly's Lover, translating it rather freely into Spanish as they read. Dr. Orange was only able to sleep fitfully; towards dawn he became convinced that the monkeys were watching him. Jimmy slept like a rock; he was very tired.\n

      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 11)

      They were making good progress through the woods the next morning. Ruby was near the front of the group, taking her turn hacking the underbrush with a machete. Suddenly she dropped her blade and flung herself at Millicent, knocking her to the ground.

      A fusillade broke out from the trees ahead of them. Some porters collapsed, bleeding. A few more rifle shots rang out, forcing them to keep flat to the ground.

      "They'll try and swing some people behind us to catch us in a crossfire," said Dr. Orange. "Old Nazi trick."

      Jimmy crawled away from the rest of the group and into the forest. Millicent scrambled after him. "Damnit," he said. "You can come with, just stay quiet. If anything happens, head back to the rest."

      Millicent crawled ahead of Jimmy and then loped off like a deer into the woods. Once again Jimmy was surprised at her tradecraft--she was barely making any noise, and he could hardly keep up. Suddenly she stopped and slid behind a tree, making a small, quiet motion with her hand.

      Jimmy threw himself behind the trunk of a banana tree. He could see three men creeping through the woods, two carrying rifles and one a shotgun. The third man was also holding a bundle of dynamite.

      He braced his rifle against the tree, measured his lead, and then emptied his rifle at the three men. Both riflemen went down with terrible head wounds.

      The third man dropped his shotgun and dynamite and raised his hands. "I surrender!" he said.

      [So, using the Ammo rules I've made, Jimmy (with his Firearms rating of 10) was able to burn off all the rounds in his rifle since he had Ammo 1. JP also spent some Firearms points to do more damage, which is my standard rule--spend them before the roll to add extra damage.]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Ruby crept up a little bit and peered through the jungle underbrush. She could catch quick glimpses of the riflemen who had ambushed them. There seemed to be no more than four or five of them. All of them looked like local campesinos, except for one man who wore a clean white shirt and carried a fancy hunting rifle.

      "Guillermo?" said Ruby to herself. "I'm glad we didn't hire that jerk." She raised her rifle and put a bullet in his chest. He fell hard to the ground, bleeding badly.

      Dr. Orange stood up and started screaming in German in the most intimidating way possible--which was considerable. The surviving riflemen faded back into the woods as Jimmy came prodding his prisoner out of the woods.

      Dr. Orange dragged Castillo out from the trees and threw him to the ground. "Who the hell is this guy?" he asked.

      "A guide," said Ruby. "Did de la Vega send you?" she said to Castillo.

      "No..." he panted. He had a bad chest wound. "I came to kill you because you didn't hire me. I do that to keep people away from here. I tell everyone they're bandits. It always works, when you hire me you never meet any bandits..."

      Ruby's face grew hard. "We should just tie you to a tree and leave you to die," she said. "But I have a better idea. We're going to patch you up...and give you to Nic."

      "Don't worry," Nic said with a smirk. "We'll take excellent care of you."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      They pushed forward. After a few hours they came across another warning pillar, but this one still had the capstone, which depicted a...toadlike...creature with a large mouth that was using its tongue to accept the head of a sacrifice. But something was wrong--the mouth of the statue had changed somehow. Its mouth no longer fit with the style of the rest of the pillar, having been replaced by a lipless, grinning, snaggle-toothed mouth that looked familiar to them all. Most unnervingly, this changed mouth didn't seem to have been carved later. But how could that be?

      "I've read my dad's notes," said Nic. "They didn't used to look like that. The mouth is...wrong."

      "It's a lie," said Millicent. "The stone is trying to lie."

      "We're close," said Jimmy. He unrolled the map of Chichen Xoxul that de la Vega had given him. "These columns here," he said, pointing to a an odd assortment of columns on the east of the site, "they're pretty close. Let's go on through there."

      "This is where we leave you," said Nic. "We'll wait a full day...if you don't come back by then, you're probably not going to come back at all."

      "Fair enough," said Jimmy.

      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 11)

      As they approached Chichen Xoxul, Jimmy noticed something odd--the forest had become quiet. He didn't hear the constant background chatter of birds and monkeys. He didn't even hear the whine of insects. It was like animals didn't live in the area at all.

      In the overgrowth ahead a stone column suddenly loomed up. They pushed through the grass and found themselves on a broad pediment, strangely untouched by the jungle. The place was a jumble of square Mayan-style columns, everyone carved with hieroglyphics and petroglyphs. The tops of the columns were stylized skulls of men and animals.

      On a few of the columns they saw actual skulls. They looked human.

      To their right was a small stepped pyramid. Some low walls to the left looked like they were the remains of a Mesoamerican ball game court. In between the three sites was a broad plaza flagged with large stones, covered with high stands of grass.

      Then they found the heads.
      Perched up on top of several columns were the severed heads of Mexican men. They had looks of terror on their faces. They looked to be about a month old.

      "That one there," said Jimmy. "That looks like the description we got of that guide that disappeared. The one that led Brooks' expedition."

      "Mr. Wright," said Millicent, "something's moving in the plaza."

      "What did you see?"

      "I saw something move between those pillars over there...but I didn't see it before it passed the pillar, or after it passed that other pillar...it was like it wasn't there before!"

      "Run," said Jimmy, sprinting forward.

      Ruby and Dr. Orange scampered down into the plaza and took off in the direction of the well, plunging into the thick brush that surrounded the cenote. Jimmy and Millicent moved slower, trying to keep their guard up.

      [Ruby and the doc used Fleeing, so they went where I sent 'em. Jimmy & Millicent used Athletics, so they didn't get as far away, but were on their guard.]

      Something suddenly came into view on top of the pyramid. Jimmy was sure it hadn't been there a second ago. It was...toad-like, somehow, about the size of a car, crouched like a jaguar. Its tail...tails....flicked around in the air in a manner disturbingly like a housecat stalking a mouse. It opened its mouth, revealing row after row of razor-sharp teeth, and then projected a long, sticky tongue that was at least half its length. It gathered itself for a leap...and vanished.

      [3 point Stability loss for Jimmy and Millicent.]

      "I don't want it here. I don't want it here. I don't want it here..." muttered Millicent.

      [Me: Roll a d6 and spend as many points of Cthulhu Mythos as you like...]

      A shadow crossed the sun. Jimmy saw the creature above him, looking like it was finishing its leap. Millicent raised her hand, and the creature was engulfed in a ball of green slime and thrown with enormous force into the forest.

      Jimmy spun and stared at Millicent. Her face was chalk pale and her lip was trembling.

      "Come on," he said. "Let's find the others."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      They found Ruby and the doctor standing on the edge of the well. "Take a look at this," said Ruby. "You won't like it."

      The well was a typically rimless Mesoamerican well, but the mouth of the well looked like...a mouth. Or a Mouth, frozen in stone, with the same lipless grimace they had seen too many times already.

      At the bottom of the well there was still water, and something gold glinted in the dimness.

      Jimmy uncoiled some rope from his pack. "You guys lower me down," he said. "I'm going to take a look."

      He rappelled down the sides of the well, which were slick with slime and moss. About thirty feet down he found a small cross hanging off a bit of projecting stone. The chain was too small for an adult. On the back was engraved Salvador.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n
      He handed the cross to Millicent as soon as they pulled him back up. "I saw a cave leading from the bottom of the well," he said. "Went in the general direction of the pyramid."

      "Salvador means Savior in Spanish," said Millicent. "But it was also the name of Echevarr\xeda's son, the one that died."

      Dr. Orange was watching the plaza. To his surprise, he saw a man come walking out of the underbrush, dressed at what he could identify as the everyday clothes of a Mayan from seven hundred years ago. The man walked towards the well, not paying any attention to Dr. Orange and his friends. Suddenly he stopped, with a frightened expression on his face. He pointed at Millicent...and vanished.

      "Ghost..." said Ruby, looking at Jimmy, who shrugged. "Jimmy, when nobody else knows, you're our expert!"

      "It looked like he was just here to use the well," said Dr. Orange. As he spoke, the faint sound of drums and flutes was heard from the plaza.

      All of them watched as a large procession marched into the plaza, dressed in brightly colored feathered cloaks and long woven robes. Drummers followed them, and men were blowing into conch shells.

      "Do they see us?" said Jimmy.

      Ruby picked up a stone and threw it at an unoccupied corner of the plaza. Several people started, as if they had heard it, and a few turned around and pointed at Ruby. One man armed with an obsidian sword burst out of the crowd, running towards them, and another man raised a blowgun and shot a dart at Ruby.

      The dart passed through her shoulder like she wasn't there, and the entire procession vanished.

      "What does everyone know about ghosts," she said. "Let's discuss that now."

      "I met one once," muttered Jimmy. "Gimme a minute...I'm thinking. It's not just a phantom shift, where you see stuff repeating...but this is different...they could see us, sometimes...I think we're actually observing things that are happening. Or happened."

      [Cthulhu Mythos spend by JP, 2 Stability since JP didn't want to go all the way for the answer. (I usually ask my players just how much they want to lose and give them answers based on what they say.)]

      "We should head to the pyramid," said Ruby. "We have loud banging sticks, that should scare off any Xoxul warrior. And I'll bet you anything we'll find out what's on top of the pyramid."

      "Imagine what we could learn if we could contact the past," said Dr. Orange. "We have to go on."

      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 12)

      They crossed the plaza, Jimmy nervously covering them with his gun and spinning around to see if they were followed. The pyramid was...odd. The decorations at the base were typically Mayan, but as the pyramid ascended, it was clear that someone had altered the artwork. Dr. Orange assumed that it was the Xoxul. As they climbed the steps, he could make out the story they represented, of a Xoxul sorcerer who had built the pyramid in a single day.

      He also saw some odd looking slits carved into the side of the pyramid. He could tell they had been done after the pyramid had been built. As he peered at them, he saw some movement--and then the sound of a pistol being cocked. He leaped back as a shot rang out.

      On the top of the pyramid, Ruby was suddenly confronted by several Xoxul warriors who hadn't been there a moment ago. "We are friends from the future," she said hopefully.

      One of the warriors slashed at her with his war club, but it passed right through her. "Oh, that's spooky," she said, jumping back.

      "That gunshot was definitely not from 1500," said Dr. Orange. "You can smell the cordite. Someone is inside the temple!"

      "I just saw ghosts trying to kill me," said Ruby. "Give me a moment."

      "Let's move," said Jimmy.

      There was a small boxlike structure on top of the pyramid, open on one side. Jimmy pulled back both hammers on his shotgun and stepped through the entrance.

      Inside he could see a gigantic altar, carved with what Dr. Orange had told him were Xoxul hieroglyphics. In front of the altar, flush with the floor, was a large red disc of some metal that he couldn't identify. The rest of the chamber had a strange lack of decoration.

      He looked closer at the altar. It was carved in the form of a man on all fours, his wrists and ankles bound, with a large bowl on his back.

      "That's the inversion of the chacmool figure," said Ruby.

      "And those are bloodstains, very old," said Dr. Orange. "Look at the grooves carved from the bowl, leading to that disk."

      "You recognize that?" said Jimmy.

      "It's definitely not the sun or the moon, but those radiating lines...they're like the sun..."

      "Dr. Orange, look--there's a seam in the middle, it's really fine. I think it can hinge down like a trap door," said Millicent

      "Lemme try something," said Jimmy. He uncorked his canteen and poured it out into the bowl. Water drained down out of the bowl and flowed through the grooves on the floor.

      There was a shuddering creak and the disk suddenly split in two and each half swung down into the floor, revealing a pit of some kind. At the bottom of it was a man aiming a gun at him.

      Jimmy put a round into the ground at his feet. "No me maten, no me maten!" he shouted, dropping his pistol.

      They all dropped down into the room below. "Agua, por favor," said the man. Millicent handed him her canteen. "My name is Vasquez, I was sent here by Se\xf1or Brooks. Then the ghosts attacked...and the creature. It won't go inside buildings...I think. So I hid in here. I thought I was going to die, it's been three days since I locked myself in and I ran out of water."

      "Three days?" said Dr. Orange. "You've been gone more than a month."

      "How could that be, a month? I would have died of thirst!"

      "I don't understand," said Millicent. Ruby threw an arm over his shoulder consolingly. "I've seen many strange things," moaned Vasquez.

      Dr. Orange turned on his flashlight. "Looks like this is where they kept the carvings," he muttered. Most of the carvings were rather typical of other Mesoamerican sites he had read about...but then he found one that gave him pause.

      "Jimmy, look," he said. "See? A large circle, then four small circles...then four larger circles. And the sixth one has a line drawn through it, see!"

      "I don't get it."

      "It's the solar system, don't you understand? That third one is Earth, the sixth one Saturn!"

      Jimmy shook his head. "But...how? Uranus wasn't discovered until the 18th Century!"

      [Me: Doc, would you like to make a Physics spend?
      OP: I would love to make a Physics spend! It's what I'm about!]

      Dr. Orange found another strange illustration nearby, showing a large circle and then a smaller circle at some distance. A line was drawn between them, with the glyph for a campfire and a number.

      "One...85,000th...no, 86,000th...that's...a second...that's...that's...the distance between the earth and the moon, measured in light seconds. In light seconds!"

      Enraptured, he pored over every inch of the walls. Finally he pulled the rest of them over. "Look, I'm a pilot and an engineer. This section here? Every time I look at it I feel like...this is some kind of control panel. See, those bits here rotate, like dials? And there's a lever here..."

      They all looked at each other. "Well..." said Dr. Orange. He pulled the lever...
      \n

      \nEpisode VII: As the Gloom Begins To Fall (Part 13)

      The trap doors swung up and shut with a clang. Something...happened. They felt movement without movement, a sense of translation. The light changed, dimming and brightening faster and faster. Then they stopped.

      Millicent peered through the slits. The pyramid was gone, and they seemed to be hovering over a shallow sea. The air was hot and damp. She looked up into the sky and saw a star that was growing brighter and brighter, even though judging by the daylight it looked like it was around midday.

      "Mr. Wright," she said. "Look at that."

      Jimmy looked through the slit. "Get this thing out of here!" he yelled. "That's a meteor coming right at us!"

      "Was that a dinosaur that just flew by?" said Ruby.

      "Not again," moaned Vasquez.

      Dr. Orange manipulated some dials and pulled the lever...\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      They had that same odd feeling of motion without motion. Then the light grew dim, and the air very cold. They found themselves gasping for breath, as if there was somehow not enough oxygen in the air. Snow filtered through the slits in the walls.

      "Ahh," said Dr. Orange, not sweating for the first time in weeks. "That's more like it."

      They all rushed to the slits and looked out. They seemed to be on top of a very high pyramid, itself on top of a very high mountain. Snow and ice was all around them.

      "Based on the air, I think we're four or five thousand meters," said Dr. Orange. "No place in North America, I think. Maybe the Andes?"

      "James, I'm cold," said Ruby. "Fix it."

      Jimmy grabbed Vasquez by the collar. "You said, 'not again'. This happened before?"

      "The room...goes places. I don't think I've been here before."

      "We need to go someplace else, but the particular place we left," said Jimmy. "Doc, can you do that?"

      "Sure, I'll just figure out the ancient Mayan time machine," said Dr. Orange. "But...let's see...I'm pretty sure the settings were like this when we left."

      He fiddled with the dials, and then Jimmy threw the lever...

      [I was charging a point of Cthulhu Mythos each time they activated the lever, but the group had a lot of it...]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      When the device stopped this time, they felt humid air wash over them, the familiar Yucat\xe1n jungle atmosphere. "I'm happy...I guess," said Dr. Orange. The rest of them grinned, and Ruby came up to shake the doctor's hand for bringing them home.

      Then they heard the sound of conches blowing, and drums being pounded. Jimmy looked out of the slits. A ritual possession much like the one they had seen before was marching across the great plaza of Chichen Xoxul. There was none of the grassy overgrowth he had seen before--everything was neat and well-maintained.

      Some red drops began to fall from the seam in the trap door. Suddenly, it swung down. Two men wearing feathered cloaks stared down at them in surprise, holding the body of a man who had just had his throat cut between them.

      Ruby fired a warning shot at them with her pistol. From the slits a spear narrowly missed gutting her, and two men with obsidian swords jumped into the chamber with them. Two others hovered around the edge of the pit, waiting for an opportunity to climb inside.

      Dr. Orange swung his rifle around, trying to get it to bear on the closest one, but the warrior managed to slip his sword under the gun and push it out of the way. The other warrior smashed the back of his leg, throwing him to the ground. He just managed to twist away before he could be hamstrung by the stone knife the warrior carried.

      Jimmy fired off the other barrel of his shotgun, blowing away one of the men holding down Dr. Orange. The two warriors still in the sacrificial chamber stopped trying to climb into the pit for a moment, and Jimmy seized the moment to slam the trap doors up into place.

      The remaining warrior stared at Ruby with a look of surprise and confusion on his face. Ruby drew her machete and swung it at him, but the warrior caught her blade on the handle of his own.

      From outside the pyramid, they heard a man yell in archaic Spanish, "Wait! The great queen wants to speak to the European outsiders!"

      Before anyone could say anything in reply, Millicent threw the lever.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      This time it was different. The room gave a shudder, and everything vanished, leaving them hanging in a lightless, weightless void. This wasn't the emptiness of outer space; this was utter and complete nothingness, without any light, any air, any senses at all. They floated in total silence, unable to even hear their own thoughts. And this lasted for a second, for an eternity, for no time, for all of time. It was just long enough to drive them all completely insane.

      There was nothing left but the blackness, as it always was, and always would be.

      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 1)

      After forever and never, there came an Other.

      They couldn't feel it or recognize it, of course. They couldn't feel or understand anything. But the Other was curious. It wanted to know. And that need created a pressure, prodding them into the gradual realization that there were things in the universe, two at least: them, and the Other.

      Slowly, ever so slowly.

      Sparks against the dark. Not sensation yet, just awareness. And yet the Other persisted, pushing, trying to understand, creating a waveform. As if it were searching for something, some key, some way of knowing.

      And then it found music. They of course didn't know what music was, but out of the vaguest mathematical and theoretical postulates things became more and more comprehensible, the Other changing and adjusting, fitting itself into a shape or a form until finally with the dimmest spark of light that nevertheless blazed over them like a supernova, a chord burst forth: singing, rising, praising, pulling them in, giving shape to their most inchoate sensations and perceptions. Music flowed, snatches of counterpoint like Bach fugues made out of crystal, until multiple voices, instruments, tones played through the darkness and they knew themselves as separate from the Other and different and whole in of themselves.

      Floods of memories woke in them. They began to reassemble their mental maps of the world, to know sensation, to know thought. And slowly, infinitesimally their egos began to separate. They still didn't know who they were, but the first painful realization that they were different entities began, filling the void with the sweet sadness of existence. And like movie clips playing in an empty cinema, they began to relive their lives, dipping into their sharpest and most painful memories collectively.\n

      \n

      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 2)

      And the music stopped, and they knew who they were once again.

      They were standing on a stage, with the bright spotlights shining in their face. They seemed to be in some great opera house, with a silent audience massed in the shadows. Ahead of them they could see some kind of orchestra playing very quietly, and standing behind it, just a shadowy form in the glare of the lights, was the conductor. Words formed. There was no other way to say it. The words formed into something they could just understand.

      InTEResting. Humanoids. Planet Earth. Whooooo\u2026areyou?

      "I'm Ruby Fitzgibbons."

      Carborundum. Carbon crystalinelatticed a gem.

      "Also a name."

      Designation?

      "Yes."

      Manifoldal changes in the lightcone brought youhere. Why....haveyoucome?

      "We were in the temple?"

      Structure. Pillared? Pyramidal conicalrepresentation of fourdimensional events...you bear the Contagion.

      "Are you talking about what we call the Nectar?"

      Emanation. A condition a poison a TRANSLATION the presence of the other the OUTsiderthecontagion the one who speaks in prevarications

      "Lies," said Jimmy.

      Lieeesss. Yes. Who\u2026.areyou?

      "I'm no one."

      Incorrect. You are absolutely clustered in fourDIMensional space or so you think. One who has seen. Seen? Seen. Presence. Wrapped in elemental hyperdimensional linkage. One who has spoken. Spoken? Yes, spoken to the...to the Messenger. Ah. Yes. Communication...possible? Ah. And linked and joined with the one the one yes the one with the imperfection the flaw the mixture.

      "I don't understand," said Millicent, somehow knowing that she was being talked about.

      In fourdimensionalmanifoldal terms your notochord has a foreignobject.

      "I'm lost, and I still practice physics," said Dr. Orange.

      Physics? Physician? Physical....yes. And who\u2026areyou?

      "Julius."

      Julius...Julius? a time measurement a general? A calendar a scale?

      "It is all those things."

      You are an egocollection that thinks it knows more that has suppressed suPREssed the contagion but only partially in twentythreedimensional spacetime

      "What do you mean my notochord..." began Millicent.

      Not terrene matter but phased imperfectly through extrusional into HYPERdimensionalextract quiteadvANCED...communication musical reverabations through oralsoundwavepressure communicate patterns such as matheMATicsssss....very long--long? simultaneous ofcourse but for you longago I think in your course through fourdimensionalspacetime but\u2026then I spoke with...humans? humanoids? yesss, humans....

      WHYhaveyou come here doctorjuliusorange rubyfitzgibbons jimmywright AND...

      "Millicent."

      ...no. Incorrect. But I cannot understand nor tell you that...WHAT\u2026doyou wantotknow?

      "Who makes the...contagion?" said Ruby.
      Ah....you speak of the contamination ofcourse it is quitesimple even Iweourselves are not completely FREEofit...no it was infact anotherhuman who brought the contagion. Known toyou I think but notby person.

      "Echevarr\xeda?" said Millicent.

      Echevarr\xeda...I donot know audible designations mean nothing to me. I feel I know I understand but the sonicvibrations you use to determine identity meaningless to me...

      "Let me try," said Ruby. She furiously tried to picture the photographs she had seen of Ramon Echevarr\xeda, mentally running through everything she knew about him...

      Ah...yes it was earlier on his path through spacetime. But yes. WE are now eightyfivepercent contaminated but this is steadily holding.

      "Where did the contamination come from before Echevarr\xeda...gave it to you?" asked Millicent.

      Ah the another one somewhat SOMEwhat like meusourselves but not exactly notEXactly notquite no. Bound more into the spacetimecontinuum you inhabit the fourdimensionalspace that you have currently decided and agreed DEIGNed to call yourown your home. Bound, yes. Weusourselves I do not exist in the same sort of manifold that youconcurrently agree upon decide to call yourOWN. Yes. That is true. You understand time as athing that flows from onemoment to another like rocksfalling or waterdripping. We are the river.

      "Are you...Yithian?" asked Jimmy.

      Yithian? no we are ofcourse aware of the Greatrace and have had commerce with them in thepast...

      "Who are you?" asked Ruby.

      Soundwavepressure designation on Earth once I wascalled...ah. Yes. No. My properdesignation in your languageunderstanding would be...the Fisher. I am theFisher. Thefisherfromoutside.

      Click this link to see the MASSIVE spoiler

      "And the contaminant is trying to spread its contagion to you?" said Millicent.

      The contaminant spreads its contagion to allthings it is bound upon the fourdimensional understanding of spacetime that you stand in as well.

      "You are beyond that?"

      I am what I am made this way I function in such a proper existence. Holographically, ofcourse.

      "How is it that it can do this to you?"

      Do...this to me? Contaminate? Such is the contagions ability focus and purpose. A necessary artifact of the fixture of spacetime into an understandable manifold.

      "Is there a cure?" said Ruby.

      A cure? a CURE? How is the phrasing go in the place designated as Brooklyn...the cure is oft worse than the disease. But removed this perhaps canbe done but one mustlocate the place the NEXUS the...stomach of the mouths, yes. That would work.

      "Where is it?" asked Dr. Orange.

      That I donot know.

      "There's something you don't know? Then why are we talking to you?" said Dr. Orange.

      Your knowledge is incomplete should I mockYOU? You seek the formulaic understanding of the fourdimensional spacetime, yes? This can be found. The trialanderror methods that you seek to unite the threebasicforces and gravity under the quantum understanding that you have so recently CRUDEly arrived at will take many generations of your hominid DNA replication strandal... but there is one you could talk to known by jimmywright I think...would happily give to you the understanding...I see that you want this.

      "No," said Jimmy.

      It is possible to extrude a quantumunderstanding into the lightcone inhabited by you in your trail through twentythreedimensional spacetime. That is to say that a calling of us/we those who exist in this continuum. In other words to put it in the terms of your vernacular of magic a summoning spell--you are very strange beings! I am glad humans have not been our study. The Messenger is more interested in you at least the iteration you speak of. Yes. This knowledge may be imparted.

      "Let's do it," said Ruby.

      "Wait!" said Jimmy. "Summon the Messenger? Are you nuts?"

      No you misunderstand. Summoning the Messenger iseasy you must just think of Him longenough. Summoning us is difficult. We do not inhabit the same understanding of spacetime. In fact it would cause a glitch in the...in the...ah. Yes. We may not speak of this...it would cause a glitch. We may impart this knowledge thisforumula to you all or none. It is thesame to us. It will have had happened.

      "So...you'll tell us how to summon you, and you'll...destroy the Liar?" asked Ruby.

      Destroy fight purge the Liar from your terrene existence.

      "Yes," said Ruby.

      "Absolutely," said Millicent.

      "I've got to go for it," said Dr. Orange.

      EXcelllent...and jimmywright? Or has the Messenger marked you too much to speak unto ussss?

      "You don't actually need a subconscious," said Ruby.

      "Damn my sense of duty," said Jimmy. "Fine."

      Exxcelllent. We will reconfigure your endstate when we replace you into the stream.

      "What you said before...am I a contaminant thing?" asked Millicent.

      No...the contagion hasnot touched you. YOU are somethingelse. We are not to speak of...nor can we see clearly everything that hasbeendone in the warping of the spacetimemanifold...even through the twentythreedimensional hyperspacetime that we inhabit.       "You have an implant, then."

      "Maybe they had to do it when I was sick. When I was a child."

      Yess...things are blocked fromyou...NOR could we penetrate through the hyperdimensional manifold wrapped aroundyou...not easily. Nor is it possible in the point of spacetime that you believe you inhabit...perhaps in some furthertime in your lightcone you will discover it. InnnnnDEED. It seems to me that the coordinates you wish to return to are your homes.

      "Yes...and no," said Millicent.

      InnnTEResting. Ternary logic structures very advanced for a human of such...capabilities. Ahhhhhh. Yesssss. The Messenger is speaking of you....

      "We want to go home, yes," said Ruby. "Back to the temple we came from."

      "I don't want to go back to the Temple," said Dr. Orange.

      "You just don't like the jungle."

      "I hate the jungle, let's go someplace nicer. Can't we go to the town? Let's ask him."

      I donot have a biologicalexistence in a manner that you understand. I donot excrete nor do I engage in SEXual rePROduction. It is not particularly necessary to designate a gender for me. IT is inTEResting that you feel the need to doso. Even ruby doesthis. You are very strange creatures. I see now why the Messenger is intrigued in you. Ofcourse It wouldbe.

      "We could call you they," said Ruby.

      They? Yes we have many more characteristics than a single intelligence and are so much vaster than your own. The plural designation isnot insulting.

      "They, then."

      INteresting. Our followers never used such terms for us before. Ahhhhhh....you didnot bring a bloodsacrifice. Yes. Bloodsacrifices were done in the past as a way for us to analyze to sample which is ofcourse our function. We ARE the Fisher. It was never necessary merely desirable. We know more about YOU than you know about yourSELVES. Such is our function and not yours. IN fact we are not allowed to tell. And yet you hover on the edge oftruth and donot acknowledge it. Interesting...I donot think that was in thedesign and yet here you are. Innnteresting.

      "What truth?" asked Dr. Orange.

      Truth. The Truth. The true nature that is truly true. SUCH is what we are not allowed to divulge.

      "Why aren't you allowed to communicate it?" said Ruby.

      Such isnot our function.

      "There are lots of things that aren't in our function but we do them," said Dr. Orange.

      InnDEED.

      "We have choice," said Ruby.

      You do, yessss.

      "Don't you have choice?" said Dr. Orange.

      Choice is a strangeway to understand us. We...we are. We are such that we fulfill ourfunction and have no other way tobe but to fulfill our function.

      "Like how they say angels don't have free will?" said Millicent.

      Aaaannngellls...ah, no. Angels would be messengers. We are not they. They are different.

      "And you're not a planet because you don't wander," said Dr. Orange. "If you're going to play games with etymology."

      IN some ways we DO wander. Many other societies exist or are projected to exist in this conglomeration you call Milllkyy Waayyy...

      "So we know who the Liar is...and Nyarlathotep?"

      Ahhhh....Nyarlat-Hotep was the ancient name designation...the Black Pharaoh the Black Man the Thousand Masks the Bloated Woman, yes...

      "Not the same as the Liar?" said Millicent.

      The same...the same and different interesting qualities projected on...the Messenger is neither distinct nor indistinct but the Messenger is separate. Yes. The Messenger is the Messenger and the Liar is the Liar. These are different things. They are of course the same...but such is the manifold.

      "Maybe if the Messenger wasn't there--" began Dr. Orange.

      The Messenger is always there. Such is the function of the Messenger. No. Incorrect. The Messenger exists whenever the Messenger can exist. Yes. That is correct.

      "When can the Messenger not exist?"

      The Messenger cannot communicate with that which cannot talk to the Messenger.

      "So...when talking to the the Messenger there must be a Messenger, and when one is not there cannot be?" said Millicent.

      Yes. The iteration of the Messenger can only exist when the question may be asked. When the question may not be asked or CANnot be asked or willnot be asked, then the Messenger isnot. Ah. Yes. We have the clarification. When a species understands that the universe is more than what its sensoria can reveal, why, that's when the Messenger is going to appear. You see...Gol-Goroth is not so great at talking to monkeys. But the Messenger is VERY good at talking to them.

      "Because when you're teaching slower children you need to be better at it than when teaching smarter children?" stammered Millicent.

      So anyway, the three of you came here to talk to Gol-Goroth. Riiight. Hi, Jimmy, how have you been?

      "I don't want to talk to you," said Jimmy in a strangled voice. "I've had enough of that already."

      But that's what I do, Jimmy, I talk--I'm really good at it. And you should want to talk to me; you could have cut a whole loop out of this.

      "Yeah, but it always comes with strings."

      Right, you want me to put crazy back on the line? Anyway, you got most of the dope. And you want to go home. We can send you home.

      "How many of these things do you know?" said Ruby.

      "One," said Jimmy.

      "And..."

      Well, two NOW I guess.

      "Who are you?" said Dr. Orange.

      I'm the Messenger, doc! Haven't you been paying attention? I'll put GG back on the line. You wanna go home? Just click your Ruby slippers. Oh. Sorry, spoilers.

      "What?" said Ruby.

      Weeee apologize for allowing the Messenger to speak in our spacetime it was not easy for us as well. We...may potentially meetagain if the hyperdimensional spacetime trail achieves a high certain degree of probability. Yes.

      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 5)

      They all felt an urge to think of home. They took a breath. "Home is..." they each said right before everything went dark...\n

      \n

      "...Caltech," said Dr. Orange.

      "Julius?" said Dr. Born. "I thought you were out of the country?"

      "Uhh...." said Dr. Orange, and passed out.\n

      \n

      "So you see what I'm telling you Charlie," said Captain Murphy, "what I'm saying is that I'm all hung up on her and I don't know what to do. And if she were here now I don't know what I'd say."

      "...with Murphy," said Ruby, materializing on the deck of the Murphy's Law.

      Captain Murphy fell backwards, stumbled against the deckrail, and pitched over backwards into the Gulf of Mexico.

      Charlie grabbed his belly and began to laugh, until he caught sight of Ruby. He straightened up. "Oh," he said. "You must have come from the dreamtime. I'll go fetch the Captain."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "...with Janet," said Jimmy.

      "Jimmy?" Janet stood up from behind her hotel desk and dropped her pen. "Jimmy? You know you can't be here! The Federales have a warrant out for your arrest! They confiscated the plane! I'm stuck here until I can get a charter." She sat back down, nervously.

      Jimmy just nodded.

      "Jimmy...second question. How did you just appear out of thin air? What was that strange music I just heard?"

      Jimmy knelt down in front of her and put his head on her lap. "Oh," said Janet. "It's all right..."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "...with Vanessa," said Millicent.

      She looked around. She wasn't anywhere that she had expected to be. She was, she realized, in a plaza at the center of M\xe9rida.

      "What would Vanessa be doing here in the Yucat\xe1n?" she said to herself. A taxi cab suddenly pulled up next to her and the cabbie stepped out. He was a rather typical half-Mayan Yucat\xe1nero. In perfect English, he said, "Thank goodness, Millicent. You have to come with me. I'm a friend of Jimmy Wright's."

      She stared at him.

      "You do not understand how much danger you are in," the cabbie pleaded. "You have to come with me. I'll take you home."

      "Where's home?"

      "Okay...I'm still working on that. Do you know if Jimmy is in town...wait. I don't know that either. Damnit. Why did I have to pull this duty?"

      "Do you also talk about four and twentythree dimensions?"

      "Oh no, you talked to that guy. No, kid, my name's Kakakatak. Wait. Wait! I have a very important question! What color dress was Ruby wearing?"

      "She...wasn't wearing a dress, she was wearing khakis."

      "You sure she wasn't wearing a red velvet evening gown? Absolutely sure?"

      "She was wearing pants. Is that bad?"

      "Yeah, that's bad, that's very bad. Okay, great. Don't worry, not your fault kid. All right, we have to get out of here and the only question is if it's easier to do in a cab or something else. Where do you want to go, kid? Back to L.A.? I guess a plane then. You think they have anything in a twin-engine turbofan...wait a minute, wait a minute...what year is this?"

      "It's 1937."

      "Ah, damnit. Fine, fine. I'll take care of it."

      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 6)

      [Let's take a second to talk about what just happened; we took a break here during the session.

      First, this is a lot weirder and more apocalyptic than the encounter with Gol-Goroth in the actual text, which involves a time/space traveling pyramid observatory and an alien moon where you encounter a toadlike Gol-Goroth.

      I wanted--as is my SOP--to make Gol-Goroth a little weirder and a lot more ambiguous. So while thinking a lot about this encounter, I eventually came up with the Fisher's rather odd personality and equally odd delivery. I can't really capture it orthographically; it was a sing-song, high-pitched voice with the emPHASis put on odd syllables and a lot of words runtogether. Also, GG spoke with a lot of non sequiturs and technobabble.

      My reasoning is that it is a being that is outside linear time and so communication was extremely difficult. It was music that ended up providing the initial bridge to the PCs; the mathematical language of music, which is coupled with memory and emotion for most people, was understandable in some fashion to Gol-Goroth and that was how the PCs egos were reassembled. (OP noted that I was echoing Sartre with the self only understandable in opposition to others...maybe I should have called this campaign post-modern too.

      That whole section evolved in my mind over a while, because I didn't want the encounter to happen too quickly. I also embedded some clues in the locations they jumped too: the Yucat\xe1n before the K-T event was to demonstrate they'd moved in time but not space, the mountain pyramid is foreshadowing, and at least part of me thought maybe they'd try to find out who "the great Queen" was. Well, it will come back later, probably.

      I don't generally use music during my sessions, but I actually had a queue for this session, when the first realization of music came upon them in the void--the Introit for Faure's Requiem in D Minor. I found a recording where the attack on the initial organ chord was nice and loud, and gave a real sense of suddenly breaking through darkness. It would have been nice to find an appropriate Bach piece, but I didn't have time to trawl through the organ catalog (I'm more a fan of his keyboard pieces on piano in any case.) That said, it's Bach that formed the bridge to their shattered egos, so probably they have Dr. Orange's bourgeois German upbringing to thank. (Hey, I'm from a bourgeois German family; I can tell, because just about every member of my immediate family, including me, has a piano.)

      There were some mechanical things that came out of the freely RPed scenes where they explored each other's memories--I offered a point of Stability for a happy memory, or a point of Sanity for a sad memory, because paradoxically, sad memories did more to remind them of the human condition. Everyone took the bad memory option, and we put that in a pool they could use after we did the final tally on Stability loss. (I didn't bother until the end of the sequence.)

      It worked out to be a nine point Stability loss, which put everyone at Shaken and thus they lost a point of Sanity. However, I gave them back a point of Sanity for frequently blacking out and generally not really acknowledging how terrible it was--basically, the fainting option we did in Mexico City and yes I know that's not how the rule works but it was working for us. So while everyone was Shaken by this Ur-Mythos Shock, with the point back for blacking out nobody was actually down any Sanity. Ruby clawed back three points out of the pool of Sanity (Jimmy took the other point) and as you'll see she justified this with a number of changes to her character.

      There's another mechanical benefit but we'll get to that in a bit.]

      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 7)

      "Julius! Wake up!"

      Dr. Orange opened his eyes and sat up groggily. "Max..." he muttered. "It's good to see you."

      "You said you were going to Mexico..."

      "I was in Mexico."

      "Did you fly back?"

      "...I took a train."

      "However, I'm not sure how you got here. The guards don't allow anyone without a white pass into this section."

      "Must have been on a coffee break?"

      "Julius...it's somewhat interesting that you showed up like this...but you understand that if I tell you anything I am putting my career, and potentially my freedom and my life on the line?"

      "Or they'll kill us, I'm used to that."

      "Ja, it's like the old country. Come with me to the lab."

      They walked into a section of Caltech that Dr. Orange hadn't even suspected existed. ("There's no sub-basement 2!") Dr. Born led him into a lab crammed with unusual machinery. Eerie green light shone from some sort of beam projector in the center of the room.

      "Yesterday, we put a rabbit here. In theory we teleported it."

      "In theory? What theory?"

      "...I'll get to that. I just know that we ported it. It's not disintegration until 72 hours have passed according to the experimental protocols. Since then, a number of...unusual events have occurred."

      "Such as?"

      "I had a thirty second conversation with Leland Stanford. I thought that was a little weird."

      "Maybe I should catch you up on what I've been doing," said Dr. Orange.

      "Ja, and I can read you the requirements for Project Philadelphia."

      They talked for several hours. Dr. Born explained that back in 1926 the British Navy recovered a lot of odd equipment in the middle of the Indian Ocean, eventually sharing some of their discoveries with the Americans. These mostly related to teleportation, the opening of portals in spacetime, and other even weirder ideas--possibly including time travel. There is also some ballistics research going on; one of the finds was a piece of a rocket of some kind.

      "I can't get in on this right now," said Dr. Orange.

      "I understand. But I'm glad you know; it might be useful to have a man on the outside. I'm sure we can work out some kind of code. But of course...deportation, espionage, etc."

      "Let me tell you what I've been working on," began Dr. Orange.

      He talked for almost two hours almost without interruption. "...and that's how I ended up in your office," he concluded.

      [Me: Julius, you understand I don't have PC stability!]

      "You...spoke to an extradimensional intelligence?"

      "I spoke to someone who said, hey--Grand Unified Theory, just call this number."

      "Did he mention the name of the entity?"

      "The Messenger or something like that."

      "We should research this..."

      "Based on my experience, we shouldn't."

      "But Julius! Think what we could know! We could have flying cars by 1950!"

      "If we don't do the research for this knowledge, then we don't deserve it. We have to know how to not know it first. That's science."

      "Damnit, you always paid more attention to Karl Popper than me!"

      A rabbit suddenly fell at their feet.

      "A rabbit!" said Dr. Orange. "It's freeze-dried, I notice."

      "Ja...and it's a different rabbit than the one we sent. But you know what that means..."

      "A result!" they chorused together.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Ruby sat in her hotel room, writing furiously in a little journal. She was pushing to get every last bit of information about what had happened to her since January. She spent most of two days working on it, ending with a note saying goodbye to Murphy, along with the name of their daughter and where he could find her.

      Charlie drove her to the train station. "It is not an easy thing," he said, "to come back from the dreamtime."

      "No...it has not been easy."

      "Are you sure you are making the right decision with regards to Captain Murphy?"

      "I feel that...we love one another, but we also hurt one another. And if I keep bringing him into the crazy life that I found for myself...it will only hurt him even more."

      "With all due respect, that is a strange sentiment to come from you, Miss Ruby."

      "I'm not the same person I was before...my experience."

      "One cannot be, when one has been through the dreamtime."

      He stopped the car in front of the station. "Wait a moment," he said as Ruby made to get out of the car. He took a necklace off his neck--a simple cord with a piece of smooth basalt for a pendant. "Please take this. It belonged to a great matriarch of my people."

      "Thank you, Charlie," said Ruby, taken aback.

      [RP was doing a couple of things here: first, Ruby voluntarily gave up Murphy as her Solace; second, the necklace became Ruby's new Symbol.]

      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 8)

      Millicent and Kakakatak/cabbie were standing near the aerodrome at the M\xe9rida airfield.

      "That guy will do," muttered the cabdriver, pointing at a man in a pilot's uniform. He walked up to the pilot and stared in his eyes for a long moment.

      The pilot and the cabbie shuddered simultaneously, and then the pilot turned to Millicent. "Come, kid, let's go."

      Millicent fainted.

      "That happens all the time," sighed the pilot. He administered a sleeper hold to the cabbie.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Millicent came to in the co-pilot's seat of a twin-engine shot-hop air freighter. "I don't know why humans need two pilots to run these things," said Kakakatak/pilot by way of greeting. "They're easy enough. Although I am getting a bit stiff.."

      "I've been told I have a thing in my spine," said Millicent slowly.

      "Oh, that. Yeah, that's true."

      "Is that a good thing?"

      "It was sort of necessary. What I should be doing, kid, is pulling over to one of those states....I dunno, is Missoultuckey a state? and rearranging your brain. That's dangerous too, although I could probably pull of the whole memory block thing. That's probably the safest course."

      "Is it? I'm just going to end back up with Mr. Wright and we're fighting this...contaminant. Can I do that with my brain rearranged."

      "It's not a really fine-toothed ability...it wasn't too hard to cut out about two years before, but now I don't know. I'm reasonably sure you'd remember your name. We encoded that pretty hard."

      "Maybe it's not a good idea then.
      "You might be right. Where should I take you?"

      "Do you know where Vanessa is?"

      "Nope. Not omniscient, sorry. Close though."

      "I guess Los Angeles is close enough."

      Kakakatak/pilot yawned. "My jaw keeps doing that," he wondered. "Oh...right, that's fatigue. I always forget you guys need to sleep."

      "You should probably land and rest a while."

      "I've got a better idea."

      The better idea, much to Millicent's relief, was to land and put her on a train. "I should probably not see Jimmy," said Kakakatak. "It's really dangerous."

      "Should I tell him you say hello?"

      "What did you say Ruby was wearing?"

      "A pantsuit for the jungle."

      "I really don't like that branch...but I'll see if I can look him up."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      After about a week Jimmy and Janet, posing as a happy Canadian married couple, made it back to Los Angeles. Jimmy laid low at one of his safe houses.

      One day he got a call on the emergency line he had set up for people from the office to keep in touch with him. "Mr. Wright, you better get down here right now."

      "I'm on my way." He, Janet, and Betty piled into a car and drove to the office.

      When he arrived on his floor, he saw the doors had been knocked down and men in suits were milling around the reception area. A better-dressed version of them approached him. "James Wright?"

      "Unfortunately."

      "Summers, FBI. I got a warrant to search these premises."

      "Come on in," said Jimmy, handing his hat to one of his secretaries. "But...oh, I see that you don't have your third copy of this form."

      "I don't need that to serve you."

      "I disagree. Thomas! Take a look at this," said Jimmy to his brother-in-law/corporate counsel.

      "Clearly irregular," said Thomas in a thick French accent.

      "Nuts to that," said Summers.

      "Quoi?"

      [Law spend by JP to let Jimmy get to his office ahead of the FBI.]

      While they argued, Jimmy quietly slipped away and made his way to his office. He locked the double doors behind him. He had only minutes to hide the things in his vault safe.

      "Lightning gun. Magic armor. Those books..." he muttered, running over his mental inventory. Behind him there was the sound of some FBI agents demanding he open the door.

      Jimmy pulled out one key from the bunch he kept clipped to his belt and a penknife. With the knife he pried off the plate of one of the light switches, revealing a button and a small keyhole.

      The doors began to shudder from the blows of what he assumed were fire axes.

      He jammed the key into the lock, turned it, then pressed the button. There was the whine of hydraulics as inside the wall, his vault was lowered down in a manner remarkably similar to a dumbwaiter. The cycle had just finished as the door behind him shattered, giving him just enough time to pull out the key and press the switchplate back into place.

      Assuming it had worked, he had lowered into a place a dummy safe, containing interesting but non-mystical papers, behind his vault door.

      The agents burst into the room, shoving Jimmy up against the wall. One took an ax to his souvenir cabinet, breaking through the reinforced doors and then tipping it onto the floor. The pictures inside fell out and shattered on the ground.

      Summers fished out the picture of Jimmy and a large group of people on a rundown tramp freighter. "Who are these people? Where were you when it was taken?"

      "Oh that?" said Jimmy. "I was on vacation."

      "You being smart with me?"

      "Never."

      One agent picked up a necklace with a bit of brass metal dangling from it. "What's this?" he said.

      "Keepsake."

      The agent shrugged and dropped it to the floor. Jimmy surreptitiously kicked it into a corner.

      "We want to talk to you," said Summers, grabbing Jimmy by the collar. "Come on."
