      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 9)

      After seventy two hours, they cut Jimmy loose, but his office was closed down. "Scene of a pending investigation," was the excuse. The charges were nebulous, but involved rumors of drug trafficking, gang violence, involvement in some murders, and a possible international espionage angle.

      Jimmy met with Buchwald to go over his finances.

      "You have enough on the books to pay everyone for maybe six months," said the accountant. "After that...who knows?"

      Jimmy nodded. "Keep paying them until I figure out what to do next," he said, and then had Betty drive him out to Pasadena, to have his reunion with Ruby, Dr. Orange...and Millicent.

      Once again he rued the mystical effects of his meeting with the Gol-Goroth entity. Damnit, none of us were to know! he thought. Now we're all in danger. Damnit, Millicent!\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "Doctor," said Jimmy. "Ruby, good to see you."

      "Nice to see you and Janet," said Ruby. "What's with everything I'm reading about you in the Mirror?"

      Janet hid her face in her hands. "Oh, God," she said.

      "Janet used to work there," muttered Jimmy.

      "Wait," said Ruby. "Now I remember! Weren't you married to the editor?"

      "Harold's being a complete ass," said Janet. "I'd call him, but I promised never to speak to him again."

      "Er redet nur Scheisse \xfcber dich," muttered Dr. Orange.

      "Ja, stimmt," said Jimmy.

      "Sie haben keine Anklagengeschrift! Das macht mich verr\xfcckt," said Ruby.

      "Das ist voll nervig," agreed Millicent.

      They all paused.

      "What the hell just happened?" said Jimmy.

      "Were we all speaking German?" said Ruby.

      "I know German," said Millicent. "I didn't think you did!"

      "I don't!" said Jimmy.

      "Here, read this," said Dr. Orange, shoving a physics book at Jimmy.

      "I...can't. It's in German...what gives?"

      "Let me write something down. Do you know calculus?"

      "No."

      "Now, concentrate really hard. I know the answer to this problem...how would I solve it?"

      "Integration," said Jimmy without missing a beat. "There, where the limit approaches zero...what the hell?"

      "We must still be...linked, somehow," said Ruby. "From what...happened to us. Maybe we can...borrow each other's knowledge somehow."

      They all stirred uncomfortably, trying not to remember what had happened to them.

      [So, here's the other cherry from their journey beyond time and space: once per session, each PC may spend Stability one-for-one to gain points another PC has; like borrowing Jimmy's Law or Dr. Orange's Physics. This hasn't been used that often yet, but it does come up in the next couple of sessions; plus it's a neat way to cover for missing players.]

      "On that subject," said Millicent, "I met a friend of yours, Jimmy. Sort of."

      "Could you narrow that down?"

      "He was two guys," said Millicent miserably. "First one guy, then another guy."

      "Oh, all right."

      "I'm so glad that makes sense to you," said Millicent.

      "I'm going to need to go back to the office to get...some things I need," said Jimmy.

      "Could you use a hand?"

      "All the hands I can get."

      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 10)

      "Jimmy," said Ruby.

      "Not James?"

      "No. Jimmy, you're my friend. We've been together on this trip. I've seen some of the things you deal with, and I want to help. There is something I am thinking of doing that we could work together on. It's a little more clandestine than we're used to, but I feel it would be a benefit not only to us, but to the rest of the world. I mean, this isn't the only problem like this that's going to happen, right? We're dealing with this now, but who knows what strange creatures are out there manipulating the world in ways that are even more terrifying! Read this."

      While Jimmy looked over Ruby's documents with incredulity, Millicent leaned over to Dr. Orange. "Professor, are we really all just...math?"

      "Yes."

      "I don't understand how a bunch of numbers can order a soda pop...even if the soda is just math too."

      "Everything can be expressed digitally," said Dr. Orange. "Every single thing in the world."

      "But why did the stock market crash if everything's numbers?"

      "The Los Angeles Society for Archaeological Studies," said Jimmy. "What the hell?"

      "Rich people like to do things with their money,\u201d said Ruby. \u201cWe can set this up to fund our own work. Create a tourist attraction for the things that are merely interesting, and everything that is really dangerous we'll bury deep where it can't be used to hurt people. Will you help me?"

      "A non-profit would help some of my problems," mused Jimmy. "But I'm a PI, not an archaeologist."

      "We'll need an investigator, though," said Ruby. "One who is well-traveled. I know the people who would be more than happy to donate. I'll be the face, you'll do the actual dark stuff. And we'll launder stuff--you've got a good accountant for that. What we're involved in is beyond the law."

      "I don't care about breaking the law," said Millicent. "But we need to be able to get away with it."

      "If we're careful, we can do it. I mean, we know someone in the California university system..."

      [So, this is how we built LASAS:

      --I required a 2-point Credit Rating spend

      --Then a five-point combined spend from Law, Bureaucracy, Streetwise, or Credit Rating. I told the players I would note down what they spent, as it would affect the nature of the foundation--if there were a lot of Streetwise, that would mean something.

      As it was, it went Law, Bureaucracy, Streetwise, Law, Library Use, and Archaeology (we negotiated the actual spends) plus Ruby threw in some Architecture to allow for some secret rooms in their fort.

      Ruby used Cryptography to acquire an Enigma machine, which were commercially available.

      Ruby and Jimmy split the Credit Rating spends, leaving them as two principal shareholders.

      I pointed out that they would probably need an academic of some kind to be the front for the group, but we decided to figure that out later.

      During that conversation, we noted Jimmy and Ruby had been kicked out of all the best schools.

      RP: I was kicked out of Hogwarts.
      JP: Jimmy is such a Hufflepuff.
      Me: Really? Not Griffendor? Oh, I know. The Sorting Hat was like "Griff--" and Jimmy shouted "No! Hufflepuff! Hufflepuff!"]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Jimmy made plans to break into his office and retrieve his secret items from the safe. He borrowed a car from Ruby and set Betty up with a company car. "When we leave, you drive the company car away from the building and try and draw off anybody watching us, while I get away in the sports car."

      "Good idea, Boss. By the way, do I still work for you?"

      "Definitely."

      "Good. Next question: am I going to become a private eye, or are we doing something different now? Like, maybe I'm going to need to be a soldier of fortune, like Miss Ruby."

      "I have a fortune, and I shoot people," said Ruby. "I guess that's accurate."

      "We're still a little fuzzy on that," sighed Jimmy, trying to ignore Ruby. "Just no matter what, you'll be taken care of."

      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 11)

      The night of the break-in, Jimmy and Millicent went to the roof of the building next door the Mason building, where his office was located. He used a flashlight to signal to Dr. Orange, one building over and armed with a scoped rifle, that they were in position.

      Then he threw a grappling hook over to the Mason Building. Millicent tied the rope down on their side and they shimmied across to the narrow ledge that ran around the tenth floor of the Mason Building.

      "This is filthy," muttered Jimmy. A pigeon flew up in his face and he clung to the side of the building, startled. "I'm getting too old for this."

      Millicent lightly ran ahead of him. He marveled again at her smooth grace. Following her, they came to the window of his office. He peered into the gloom inside. The Feds hadn't bothered to clean up their mess, but otherwise it looked empty.

      A few minutes with his lockpick kit was all he needed to spring the window open. He pulled up the sash and then he and Millicent clambered inside, looking carefully around. He took a step forward, and broken glass crunched under his shoe.

      "Nobody move," said a voice from the darkness. It was a woman's voice, with a rather tony English accent. "We have you covered."

      "Not moving," said Jimmy.

      A figure dressed in a black leotard with a balaclava pulled over her face stepped into the dim light of the window and tossed a pair of handcuffs at Jimmy. He could dimly see the other figure holding something that glinted very much like the blued steel of a pistol in the shadows.

      Jimmy gave Millicent the nod he always had given Francis before he went into action and plowed forward at the woman who'd tossed him the handcuffs. He knocked her to the ground but she rolled over and popped up quite lithely. Millicent ran for the deeper shadows further into the room. There was a flash and the muffled report of a silenced handgun as the other woman fired her pistol.

      Across the street, Dr. Orange had seen Jimmy throw up his hands earlier. "Why are they always waiting for us?" he muttered. When he saw the flash of the pistol, he didn't think twice--he fired his rifle at where he expected the shooter to be.

      Inside the office glass shattered as the high-velocity rifle bullet smashed through it and buried itself into the floor at the feet of the woman with the gun. Millicent jumped on top of her from the shadows but couldn't knock her to the ground. She was cracked across the jaw by the barrel of the other woman's gun.

      Jimmy tried to grab his opponent but she nimbly jumped up onto the desk. She knows what she's doing, he thought. But so do I.

      The woman with the gun swept her leg in a quick kick and threw Millicent to the ground. She jabbed the gun into Millicent's neck. "Mr. Wright, I really don't want to have to hurt anyone. Perhaps we could start over, eh?"

      Millicent got a far-away look in her eyes. "You really don't want to use that gun. You really don't want to use that gun," she said in a level monotone.

      [Intimidate spend by MP.]

      "Mr. Wright, I really don't want to shoot this little girl," said the woman with the gun. "Let's all move to the center of the room and I'll put down my gun."

      "I don't know you," said Jimmy. "Put your gun down first and then we'll talk."

      The woman backed away from Millicent, keeping the gun trained on her the whole time, and backed towards Jimmy. Finally she stopped in front of him, knelt down quickly, and dropped the gun at her feet.

      Millicent turned on the lights, so that Dr. Orange would have a better shot if he needed to take one.

      "I think we owe these people flowers," said Millicent. "They're always breaking into our hotel rooms."

      "I think they're with Epsilon Sigma," said Jimmy.

      "Same difference."

      "We can neither confirm nor deny any of our activities," said the Englishwoman.

      "Did you like the book?" the woman on the desk whispered at Millicent. She nodded.

      "We're here to recover any items of interest," said the Englishwoman.

      "I'm here to recover items of interest. My items," said Jimmy.

      "We seem to be at a bit of an impasse."

      "We could call the Feds and report a break-in," said Millicent.

      "Who are you?" demanded Jimmy.

      "I really don't think that's important," said the Englishwoman.

      "It is. Depending on who you are, I might just let you walk away with the stuff."

      "I'm not at liberty to give out my name."

      "You're asking us to trust you with sensitive items and you won't trust us with your name?" said Millicent.

      "Er...no, we were just going to take them. Unfortunately we both chose the same night. To be honest, I really don't care about your articles, but orders are orders."

      "You're not with the sorority?" said Millicent.

      "We take our orders from...higher up."

      Jimmy narrowed his eyes. The woman was a pro, he knew--superb tradecraft. But he had a man with a rifle across the street. "Do your superiors prefer you alive or dead? I'd prefer the former."

      "I agree. Why don't we just walk out of the office."

      Jimmy nodded.

      "All right, Mr. Wright. I'm sorry we couldn't meet under better circumstances." The two women in black backed out of the room, and then ran into the office.

      Jimmy fiddled with a piece of wood at the baseboard, prying it up with his knife, and then using another key from his ring to activate the hydraulics that would raise his real safe back into position. While he was fiddling with the controls, Millicent saw something flash in a corner of the room. She walked over and fished out the necklace with the brass pendant from the broken glass and trash. Uncle Jack's necklace, she thought. She put it on.

      [Me: Bwu-ha-ha-ha. I mean, good. (Millicent saw it because of her In The Blood Drive.)]

      Jimmy went through his inventory. One lightning gun, charges unknown. Several old books. That notebook Noor was always writing in. My "magic" armor. That box of various stuff...that's everything except Jack's necklace...

      He turned around and saw that Millicent was wearing it. "How about we wait until a little later when we know what that thing does," he said, reaching out a hand to lift it off her neck.

      Millicent grabbed it and stepped back. "I'm not going to do anything with it," she said petulantly. "I'm just wearing it."

      "Why don't you keep it in your pocket?"

      [Me: I'll give you two points of Stability to keep wearing it...]

      "It's the only thing my, my father gave me!"

      "I'm not asking you to get rid of it, I'm asking you to keep it and not use it. We understand each other, right? I...I know who you are. Who you really are. I know you read Jack's letter...and you know that we hid you away, so that even I couldn't know your new name. You saw all that when we had that...experience. I know you feel the connection to the world that isn't our reality. I'm just asking that you keep it in your pocket until we understand what it does."

      "But I want to wear it."

      "Please."

      "Oh, all right." Millicent took it off, but wrapped it around her arm like a bracelet when Jimmy turned away with a sigh of relief.

      As they were getting ready to leave, the phone rang. Jimmy gulped and picked up the receiver.

      "Tell Betty to take the alternate route. Trust me on this; you told me about it personally. We'll probably talk soon...old friend."

      Jimmy hung up. On the way out, he gave Betty the high sign, and she threw her car into reverse and spun around in a bootlegger's turn. Right as she did, another car came swooping out of a side street, barely missing her. Apparently the Englishwoman's friends were planning to hijack her. Fortunately, with her head start she was easily able to evade them.

      \nEpisode VIII: No Maze to Unwind (Part 12)

      The offices of LASAS were located on the site of an old Spanish hacienda. "There's a nice deep wine cellar we can use for temporary storage," Ruby explained, as she led Jimmy through the offices. "Sorry there's no place to sit, the furniture is still on its way. So hard to get real teak tables nowadays."

      "Not if you pay enough, apparently," said Jimmy, wincing at the thought of how much everything had cost. "What about permanent storage?"

      "Found an excellent place out in Nevada, far away from here...or any earthquake faults. There's absolutely nothing around for miles, just rocks, desert, and salt flats. We have an old silver mine that we can use to stash things in, near a place called Groom Lake."

      "Good. Nothing should ever happen out that way."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Eventually Millicent was able to eventually lift Noor's notebook off of Jimmy. Perhaps he didn\u2019t make it very hard, having resigned himself to her curiosity. It was a small, completely ordinary hard-bound notebook of the type archaeologists used. It was also heavily splattered with a dried red-brown substance. Many of the pages were stuck together.

      "Noor al-Buraki," she read, "formerly a graduate student of Dr. Ali Kafour of the Cairo Museum; currently an investigator into the ancient mysteries. Notes to our researches, including a concordance of several tomes and excerpts from a translation-in-progress of the Al-Azif."

      The book contained lots of details on various entities, almost in the manner of a general researching the weaknesses and strengths of his opponents. Sometimes she found penciled notes in another hand, mocking Noor's surmises or demanding more research. She also found snatches of various texts copied out in both the original (generally Arabic or archaic French) and English translations in a graceful hand on the facing page.

      About the Liar she found some different opinions. Some described it as a minor nuisance, or at least as minor a nuisance as an extradimensional malevolent entity could be. Others said that it had come to Earth long ago, and had been screwing things up ever since.

      The main markers of the Liar were the lack of a head--its avatars were nearly always headless--and mouths on the palms of hands. It was known to be able to possess people, especially people who went to deep into the research of the Liar. There was also a tradition that he was a god of the dead, or that "the dead belong to him." It seemed to be able to take the form of people who had died under its influence. It was also rumored to be a sexually transmitted disease of some kind. Millicent also found a note with a date that made it one of the last entries in the notebook: "12 August 1925: Poss. av. Nyarl."

      A lot of the rituals to the Liar were similar to those of Gol-Goroth, making the Fisher a good cover for the Liar--both like orgiastic rituals. However, after the experience in the Yucat\xe1n, Millicent suspected they had different aims, because the Liar shared one important characteristic with Nyarlathotep: it was one of the gods that talked. For whatever reason, it comprehended humans in a way most of the other entities didn't, or couldn't.

      Unanswered questions abounded: why did Echevarr\xeda summon the Liar? What does the contagion of Gol-Goroth mean? Why couldn't the Messenger see Millicent?

      "You three," she thought. "That's what he said. Not you four. And Trammel couldn't see me that well...and he thinks the Liar is Nyarlathotep."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Ruby went to Millicent one day. "I have to tell you something I remembered after we left Mexico City. When we were in that pit that Leticia threw us into...when you and I fainted the second time...well, afterwards, I got some Nectar in my mouth and you know what happened to me. But I remember: so did you. And you weren't affected at all."

      "I did? I hadn't realized...of course if you're right, I guess I wouldn't have." Millicent sighed. "I think that sorority is looking for me. I don't want to have delusions of grandeur, but I think they started the whole thing to look for me."

      "Jimmy!" called Ruby.

      He reluctantly slunk into the conference room at LASAS headquarters Ruby was using for her "Millicent Intervention."

      "Jimmy," repeated Ruby, "what don't we know?"

      "There's somebody who has my face and is buried in a grave!" blurted Millicent.

      "I don't know all the details," sighed Jimmy. "I only know part of the details."

      "I think they gave me some dead girl's face, to be on the safe side," said Millicent.

      "It was mostly K's plan."

      "Am I going to keep doing strange things?"

      Jimmy paused, remembering a little girl who had walked through the side of a freighter in a flash of light. "You are extremely special and particularly gifted...at getting into trouble. And at understanding things. An innate understanding."

      "That's bad, isn't it?"

      "Probably. There is one...person...you must never meet."

      "The one who couldn't see me?"

      "Yes. If he ever does, bad things will happen."

      "What kind of bad things?" said Ruby.

      "World problems, let's say."

      "Like boiling oceans? Apocalypse?"

      "If I get my brain scrambled again, will that stop it?" asked Millicent.

      "It might delay it."

      "Does this have to do with the thing in her neck?" asked Ruby.

      "It's part of the countering...I think. I only had a small part to play. We all did. We all did a small thing and nobody knew the whole plan, so that we could never betray it. And...it's why Francis, my best friend, hasn't talked to me in ten years. So it's extremely bad that I know who you are now, and it's extremely, extremely bad that you know...or any of us knows!"

      "If your friend does that to all of us, isn't there a chance you won't remember...well, anything?" said Millicent.

      "It might be worth it," said Jimmy.

      "How much does Vanessa know?" said Millicent.

      "She was one of two people who knew your new name. But she didn't know what was done, just who you were. Whatever else she figured out, I don't know."

      They began to make plans to go to Bangkok.

      \nPart III: Epistrophy

      Episode IX: Blue Monk (Part 1)

      The sun rose over the mountains, illuminating the Abbey of our Lady of Sorrows in red and gold. As a bell mournfully tolled, Geronimo Cuevas slid into a confessional and began to recite his sins.

      "Stop, my son," said the priest from behind the grillwork. "My son, you've been with us for a couple of weeks. No one works harder; you keep a vow of silence even though our order doesn't. But I feel you have not completely confessed everything that troubles you."

      "There is a great darkness that haunts me."

      "Yes, I can sense that. I am not sure that you have the right temperament for a communal life. I want you to think on that. I'll absolve you of your sins today...and we shall see what happens."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Ruby got a telephone call. "Ruby, this is Howard."

      "Howard Hughes? Good to hear you again."

      "Would you mind having lunch with me out at the yacht club tomorrow?"

      "My pleasure."

      The next day she motored out to Malibu. Howard graciously took her down to a small but elegantly set table on a pavilion near the water. As she drank her iced tea, a two-engined flying boat swooped out of the sky and landed in the water. It ran into shore and then rode up the boat slip on its own wheeled landing gear.

      The plane was remarkably beautiful, with sleek lines and a parasol wing. The engines were mounted over the wing. On the rear of the fuselage there were two blisters, enormous clear plexiglass bubbles.

      "Little project the government wanted me to look at," said Hughes. "Consolidated is building it. War Department wanted me to review it as a bomber and observation plane."

      "What a fantastic machine," thrilled Ruby.

      "I want you to have it."

      "What? Why?"

      "Let me be honest with you. I'm probably the person who's flown fastest, highest, and furthest of anyone in the world. There are things up there, Ruby. I've seen them. I hear from the grapevine that you've seen things like that too. And you're working with Jimmy Wright..."

      "I've seen things that most would not bring up in public. Or in private. Or with anyone, actually."

      "I think this might be pretty useful to you. I've rigged out the interior like a flying yacht, for your comfort."

      "What can I do for you?"

      "Just knowing that you're using it right is my reward. Shall we have lunch? Hope you like lobster."

      [The plane is in fact a prototype of the Catalina, which was used in anti-sub reconnaissance during WWII. After the war, a few were rigged out as literal flying yachts!]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Jimmy was holed up in one of his safe houses in Marina del Rey when there was a knock on his door. There was a man outside in a bad suit, with that certain tough-guy look only former cops have. "Mr. Wright? My name's Lou Columbo. I sorta work for you. Can we talk?"

      They sat in the living room. "I know the Feds shut down your office," said Columbo. "I'd like to remind you that you have a second office and they haven't shut us down yet. Sure, a lot of guys left after all the receptionists vanished, and your unexpected trips out of the country...but we've brought our wives in to work the phones and we're still solving cases. I just wanted you to know that Special Branch is still out there and working for you."

      "Just don't get yourselves killed."

      "Yeah. Thanks Mr. Wright. Gotta go back and take care of my sister's kid Frank, he's visiting from Brooklyn." \n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "Brother Cuevas? you have visitors."

      "Really, brother?" said Geronimo, sitting up on his pallet. "Who are they?"

      "An American and his servant."

      Geronimo went out to the courtyard of the abbey where much to his surprise he saw Captain Murphy, Charlie--and a little girl, maybe five or six years old.

      "Jerry!" said Murphy, jabbing out his hand to shake with Geronimo.

      "Where is Ruby?" said Geronimo.

      "Ruby gave me the oddest letter. It's led me some strange places, including to the orphanage in town where I picked up this little one. The Sisters tell me she speaks good English."

      "What reason would you have to pick up this girl?"

      "She's my daughter. Ruby's letter opened my eyes to a lot of things. The thing about me and Ruby is that she's a great gal, but we're just too alike. She needs someone who can provide stability and take care of her."

      "That's what she hired me for."

      "Well, if it doesn't hurt too much to point out--you kind of quit. I think you should go back to L.A."

      "I didn't think she needed me."

      "I think she needs you more than she needs me." Captain Murphy was holding a small journal in his left hand, clutching it very tightly.

      "What do you plan to do with your daughter?"

      "Find a good school for her, and then try and raise her. Raise her right! Teach her the things she needs to know, like a sheepshank! And which fork to use!"

      "I'm not sure a ship with a bunch of sailors is the best place..."

      "No, we'll have to settle down. Maybe Groton, or Boston...someplace like that."

      "I'm not sure settling down is the best course for you."

      "True. Maybe we'll keep on the move. We'll go to London! Paris! Zurich! Maybe give Berlin a miss."

      "I'm not sure it's the most stable lifestyle for a child...especially without her mother."

      "I don't think Ruby's going to settle down anytime soon...so it's my job. Anyway, I'm giving you Charlie to take you back to L.A."

      "The white devil speaks true," said Charlie, with a grin. "I will accompany you to Los Angeles, if you wish."

      "Why should I go to Los Angeles?" said Geronimo. "I'm comfortable here."

      "No offense, Jerry, but whatever's bothering you, you won't work it out among a bunch of cassocked priests," said Murphy. "Mumbo jumbo and waving their hands over you, that's not going to fix anything! You need to go out and do God's work."

      "What is God's work?" said Geronimo bitterly.

      "Well, it's up to you, Jerry. You want to stay and wither away here in Mexico, go ahead--it's a good country to do it in."

      "Hey!" said a couple of Mexican priests walking by.

      "My stay here has run its course," said Geronimo. "I will travel to Los Angeles. Let me get my things."

      Geronimo returned to his cell, picked up his razor, his picture of his brother--and his gun.

      \nEpisode IX: Blue Monk (Part 2)

      "I think you are doing the right thing," said Charlie to Geronimo one night when they were standing on the deck of the cargo ship that had taken them on as extra hands. "Miss Ruby must be going through a difficult time, for I saw her step out of the dream world. And that is not a good thing to do."

      "Dream world?"

      "\u2026May I say, Mr. Cuevas, I have known you and the Captain and Miss Ruby for a long time. When the Captain found me, I was much like you--I had great shame I needed to atone. That is why I was trying to commit ritual suicide. The Captain found me and stopped me. For a long time, I was very angry at the white devil for that. When I met Miss Ruby, I thought, 'Well, the Captain and she deserve each other--perhaps one day they will kill each other and resolve all our problems.' But then through her I met you. And there came a day when I realized that Captain Murphy did not deserve Miss Ruby. And I realized that was because if you would follow Miss Ruby, then she must have something more than just what Captain Murphy saw in her."

      "I am glad to hear you think so highly of me. I am not so sure I see that much more in Ruby. She is who she is."

      "She came out of the dream world. That will change a person."

      "Then perhaps she is a stranger now."

      "Perhaps." Charlie turned back to his French copy of Rousseau.




      Millicent did some research on the vandalism at Evergreen Cemetery. She paid a visit to the caretaker who had been hurt during the incident.

      "I don't know what to tell you," he said. "Somebody cold-cocked me from behind. Messed me up pretty good, even took a bite out of me! Probably one of those drugged up Mexican gangs, I hear they been biting people lately."

      "What were they doing?

      "Dug up a grave. Some little girl, Leticia Adams."

      "Can I see it?"

      "Sure."

      When she saw the grave, which hadn't been filled in, Millicent couldn't shake the feeling that there was at least a possibility that the grave had been dug out from inside. "Shame they dug up some poor girl's grave," she said.

      "Yeah, everything's going to hell," said the caretaker. "The damn Roosevelt's in office, the mayor's a crook. What are you going to do?"

      "Did they take the body?"

      "No idea, we haven't exhumed the coffin. I figured they were disturbing the earth, maybe trying to dig up the tombstone. Kids today."




      Dr. Orange was reading a copy of the Los Angeles Daily Mirror. "Jimmy Wright: Phony Tribune of the People!" screamed the headline.

      "Dr. Orange," said Geronimo from the entrance of his office.

      "Ja?" said the doctor, not looking up. "Wait, where the hell have you been?"

      "Taking care of my needs. I was hoping that you could help me find Ruby."

      "She's got some charity, the Los Angeles Society of Archaeological Studies. Look it up in the phone book. Unless you have something important."

      Dr. Born ran into the office, erased one character from the chalkboard that was covered with equations, and wrote in a Greek letter.

      "That changes everything!" said Dr. Orange.

      Dr. Born walked out, followed by Geronimo. He had just reached the lobby when Dr. Orange caught up with him. "Wait, maybe you can get Ruby to fund us," he said, shrugging into his coat.




      "Mr. Cuevas," said Millicent from behind the receptionist's desk at LASAS. "You're back!"

      "I have returned, yes. I want to see Miss Ruby."

      "Did you come back the normal way?"

      Geronimo started to say something and paused. "Let me just buzz you in," said Millicent quickly.

      "Ruby!" said Dr. Orange, rushing into the office. "Can you look over my grant proposal? Also Jerry's back."

      "I see," said Ruby. "Millicent, can you take care of that?"

      "Can you explain your proposal?" said Millicent.

      "That's what undergraduates are for!"

      "Maybe you could put it in terms that director we worked with would understand?"

      "Oh, all right. It uses bad magic."




      Ruby led Geronimo into her office. She gave him an affectionate, tender hug, taking the Spaniard by surprise.

      "Perhaps you have changed," said Geronimo.

      "Who said I changed?"

      "Captain Murphy and Charlie. They found me in the abbey. I also had the pleasure of meeting your daughter."

      Ruby just stared.

      [And that's you shut up! I said. 1 point Stability loss to Ruby.]

      "I think the Captain means well but I am not sure that is the best environment for a child," said Geronimo. "Ruby, how long have I known you? More than two years. I know I have only been your employee but I thought perhaps I knew you better."

      "I was younger. I got caught up in an idiotic situation...I put her up for adoption because I thought anyone would make a better mother. I didn't know how to be responsible then...and maybe in that way I've changed."

      "What does this place you have founded do?"

      "It will protect people from the kinds of things we've seen...things people might not even believe in but can harm them."

      "Does this mean there's no room for me in your life?"

      "Of course not. I need my friend, my companion...I know you're hurt as well. I want to make you feel better as well."

      "Don't you think your daughter would be better off with you?"

      "Mixed up with all this?"

      Geronimo paused. "I do see a difference in you. But where do I fit in your life?"

      "Stay with me. Be my companion," said Ruby, holding his arm. "And if you need any help with anything..."




      "Charlie!" said Ruby, coming out of her office. "I didn't know you did crossword puzzles."

      "For a long time I thought they were a spell used by the white devil to imprison me. Now I realize they are a passtime. Captain Murphy lied very often."

      "What's your real name, by the way?"

      "Ra\u2019iarii."

      "I'll just call you Charlie, then."

      "Most people do."

      "Would you like to join our organization, or do you want to go back to working for Murphy?"

      "I do not wish to work for the Captain, nor am I able to return to my home. And if you are truly now a creature of the dreamtime, I think you will need my help."

      "So this is going to happen again?" said Millicent, miserably.

      "It has all happened before, so it will all probably happen again."

      "What has happened?" said Geronimo, puzzled.

      "While you were away..." began Ruby. She glanced around. "We shared an experience. Call it a reconception. You're nothing, and then you're born, and...then you grow up...so....it's like a birth...well, we spoke with more than one of these...elder...beings..."

      "Your sins have been forgiven. You have been reborn. Deo gratia," said Geronimo.

      \nEpisode IX: Blue Monk (Part 3)

      "I spoke to the caretaker at that cemetery that got vandalized," Millicent said to Jimmy.

      Jimmy twitched. "Why..."

      "Do you remember when we put that part of an arm in the icebox?"

      "I try not to think about it."

      "Well I took it out to look at it and it told me a plot to go see and that was the plot that got vandalized and it was some six year old's grave and the picture of her was the picture that Vanessa took of me but it's not the same as the one Uncle Jack took of me..."

      "An arm, that was separated from its body and was still moving gave you an address and you followed it!"

      "It was only on the way to my dinner with Dr. Fauche!"

      "We still have to talk about that!"

      "And the caretaker said he got attacked and the ground was all dug up and I don't know if it was from above or below..."

      "There's a multi-layered plan to keep you safe," said Jimmy. "Unfortunately, when our security measures start to get untangled they bite us in the ass. Don't go back there to snoop."

      "Snoop on what?"

      "You always find something to snoop on! Just leave it alone, it will be fine. Because if we start investigating, it might cause people to notice."

      "And the other thing we talked to couldn't see me, the Mess--"

      "And we're going to stop talking about that too Is there anything else?"

      "Mr. Cuevas is back!"

      "Great." Jimmy paused. "This is going to be weird..."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Bangkok! The heart of the Kingdom of Siam, a crossroads for Southeast Asia. Bangkok! The steaming riverbanks, the narrow canals threaded between densely packed blocks of houses. Bangkok! City of thousands of shrines, millions of people, and a smile on all of them! Everywhere they looked they saw something new, something exotic to them, something they didn't understand.

      [I charged everyone a point of Stability for general culture shock--thanks to Bill White for that idea--and then we had the de rigeur playing of "One Night in Bangkok."]

      Jimmy nervously pawed through his flash cards. "Uh...sawatdee...khrup?" he said to Millicent.

      "Very good, Mr. Wright! Let's review the numbers," she said. They had been trying to pick up some Thai during the preparations for the trip, a task the multilingual Millicent found far easier than Jimmy, who had never bothered to learn another language.
      They had arrived during the wet season. Rain poured down on them, steaming off the roofs of the buildings near the wharves. The air, muggy and warm, was stifling.

      "What's our first task?" said Jimmy.

      "Bangkok hasn't really gotten up on the whole house numbers concept," said Millicent. "So we need to find that address."

      "Do we know anyone here?" said Ruby. "I know rich people, and Jimmy you know scoundrels."

      "Lot of overlap there," said Jimmy. "I think I know someone...I heard she moved here from Shanghai..."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      They went down to the red light district, which was conveniently nearby. "This is the place," said Jimmy, pointing to a small bar with the world "Lily's" written in English over it, along with longer signs in Siamese and Chinese.

      "Wait..." said Ruby. "I think I know what some of those characters mean..."

      Jimmy shrugged and led them into the bar. It was dimly lit, with movie posters tacked up along all the walls. Several heavily made up people were lounging at little cabaret tables scattered around the place, some talking to Siamese businessmen who were nursing their drinks. Behind the bar, a middle-aged drag queen with immaculately applied makeup looked up as they entered.

      "Hello, Lily," said Jimmy.

      "Wait a minute..." said Lily. "I know you...you were looking for Jack back in Shanghai. Jimmy, wasn't it?"

      "How are you?"

      "I'm older."

      "You don't look it."

      [Me: So you're using Flattery...]

      "I want to be clear, you're not the first white man to chase me down, even after ten years. What can I do you for?"

      "These are my colleagues."

      "Well," said Lilly, giving Geronimo a once-over. She glanced at Ruby. "Oh honey, that's so last year."

      Ruby glared back.

      "...and my goodness, this is a total tear-down," continued Lily, shaking her head at Millicent. "I see you need our services."

      "I get that a lot," said Millicent.

      "But you did bring such a handsome friend," said Lilly, smiling at Geronimo.

      "I...do not...I'm not...quite...sure...if I'm the...right..." muttered Geronimo nervously.

      "She helped me out with a case once," said Jimmy.

      "Anyway," continued Lily, "A, thanks a lot for bringing in so many white people, it helps with the advertising. B, why are you in Siam (I hope there's a wedding ring involved)..."

      "Sorry, Lily."

      "Always a bridesmaid..."

      "Actually, we're looking for an address."

      "I'm just a social director, eh? Let me see the address. Hrm...the good news is, it's in an ex-pat neighborhood, I'll give you directions. And...is that all I can do for you Jimmy?"

      "A drink would be great."

      "You know, we also have a show. Very reasonable cover. Two-drink minimum. Water's not a drink."

      For what it was worth, the show was entertaining.

      \nEpisode IX: Blue Monk (Part 4)

      The address they had lifted off the letters from "SS" proved to be another Bohemian neighborhood, teeming with artists, writers, and musicians, as well as the usual teeming mix of food stalls, flower markets, and Buddhist shrines. The building itself proved to be a townhouse.

      Jimmy waited until the first street kid tried to pick his pocket, and then nabbed him to get information about the house. Squirming under his grip, the boy said, "Yeah, there's a white guy lives in there. We call him Waen."

      "Waen?"

      "It means 'glasses'," said the kid, making circles around his eyes with his fingers. "He wears these big spectacles all the time. American, I think. Talks like you do."

      The kid explained that Waen didn't seem to do much, just spend most of his time in the house, although he did make fairly regular trips out into the neighborhood. Jimmy gave the kid a few baht to pay for his tourist greeting services and then they set down to watch the house.

      A few hours passed, and then Geronimo, watching from a silk seller's stall, saw two men dressed like stevedores go down the alley behind Waen's house. He followed them to the entrance of the alley, and saw them pound on the back door of the house for a while, calling out "Waen! Waen!" After a while they gave up and left the area. Ruby trailed them down to the river, where she saw them meet a crowd of dock workers and have a heated conversation in Siamese with them.

      [Shadowing test by RP.]

      Geronimo, Jimmy, Millicent, and Dr. Orange made plans to break into the house, since "Waen" wasn't home. While Millicent watched the alley to make sure nobody interrupted them, Jimmy easily picked the lock on the back door and the rest of them slipped in.

      The house was sparsely decorated with modern furniture, but they noticed a few unusual things. There didn't seem to be anything personal anywhere--no pictures of family, nothing that looked like a keepsake, no personal letters. The clothes in the closet were all conservative American-style summer outfits.

      Under the bed Jimmy turned up a small wooden box with several dozen vials of nectar inside. There were two styles of vials; one was stamped with something in Siamese. Next to the box was a record album from Luz Records in Mexico City.

      In the closet they found a basket full of bundles of baht, several thousand dollars in U. S. currency.

      Jimmy found a handkerchief with the monogram "DL" on it, the only thing that gave even a hint of Waen's identity.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      They set up a rotating watch on Waen's house, and in the evening they saw a man in a suit very much like the ones they had seen in the house bound up the steps to the townhouse. He was wearing a fashionable pair of horn-rimmed glasses. He unlocked the door and let himself in. After a while a light came on inside, and they heard the sound of classical music playing on a gramophone.

      "Ruby, go charm the man," said Geronimo.

      "Someone needs to come with me," pleaded Ruby. "You said he has Nectar!"

      "I will go," said Geronimo.

      They walked up to the house and knocked on the door. It opened to reveal the man they had seen come in. "Can I help you?" he said in a pleasant, Middle-American accent.

      "We've heard this is a place to have some fun," said Ruby.

      "Don't know who would have said that, this is just my house."

      "Some of the dockworkers mentioned something fun and exciting, and we thought we'd give it a shot."

      The man paused for a moment. "Sure, come on in," he said, ushering them inside.

      They stepped into the living room. "So...this is for both of you?" said Waen, dubiously.

      "Yes, we'd like to try and experiment...hands up!" said Ruby, pulling her small automatic out of her handbag.

      "Now, hold on a moment..." began the man, quickly raising his arms. "I don't have a lot of money..."

      "We're not interested in your money. We not interested in what you're selling. We're interested in where it's coming from and who's supplying it!"

      "I thought you wanted to go to the fights!"

      "We're not interested in them. We want the name of your supplier, and where they're getting it from. The Nectar!"

      "...you must be one of Samson's little fellas. May I put my hands down or are you going to shoot--"

      "Keep 'em up!"

      "I manage the fight business around here, and the Nectar is used for in them. That's all I know! I made myself useful to the organization."

      "What organization!"

      Waen hesitated. Geronimo loomed behind her menacingly. "I can tell you where the fights are held," squeaked Waen. "Is that enough? Frankly, if you go higher up than that there will be consequences. The fights are all held at the Noble Pali Monastery."

      [Intimidation spend by GP; I asked for an interpersonal spend, because Waen is pretty cool beneath his meek demeanor.]

      "Who's supplying it?"

      "That's all I know."

      Ruby fished out several hundred American dollars from her bag. "We never came here, you never spoke with you, all right?"

      [Bargain spend by RP.]

      "You're not really from Samson, are you?" said Waen.

      "We dealt with him."

      "And what is your intention here?"

      "We enjoyed Samson's product, but we can't get it in Los Angeles anymore. So we're coming here to get some."

      "You know it's different here in Siam?"

      "Honey, Nectar's Nectar. And I'm jonesing."

      "Well if that's all, I could just get you in the fights, I'm sure you'd enjoy it..."

      "Thanks, but I prefer my Nectar in a safe environment."

      "There's very few safe places in Bangkok. Maybe I could see clear to sell you some Maltese Nectar."

      [Stability Test time for Ruby, TN 5!

      JP: Spend 4 or nothing.
      RP: I'll spend...3.
      Me: An 83% chance isn't so bad...
      RP: Never tell me the odds!

      But Ruby passed.]

      "No thanks," said Ruby through gritted teeth.

      "And what are you here for?" Waen asked Geronimo, putting his hands down as he did.

      "Just to make sure you answer questions," Geronimo replied smoothly.

      "And what exactly was the question? In all this confusion, I seem to have lost the thread of our conversation."

      [JP: Oh, this has gone from they're in control to he's in control...

      (It's always nice to know your "project an air of silent menace" is working.)

      JP: No shots have been fired...
      GP: Not yet.]

      "You won't tell anyone we came," said Ruby.

      "Oh, I promise. I won't tell anyone," said Waen. "And when you get to the monastery, just tell them you've come to celebrate the rites of old. They'll take good care of you."

      [Bargain Spend by RP.]

      Ruby and Geronimo backed out of the house, and then started walking rapidly away, careful not to even glance at Millicent, Jimmy, and Dr. Orange. They walked for a half an hour but were confident they had thrown their tail.

      [Sense Trouble by RP, and it worked--they did throw their tail. For the moment.]

      \nEpisode IX: Blue Monk (Part 5)

      The next day they went out to the Noble Pali Monastery. Millicent decided to head out to watch Waen's house--or Daniel Lowman, as her research on him had finally turned up.

      The monastery was a long, low building, mostly walls surrounding a large open courtyard. Towers piled high in the traditional Indian fashion rose from the corners of the inner court.

      Once they got past the guards at the gate, they began to notice odd things. The inscriptions and hangings inside the temple were a strange and eclectic mix of Theraveda Buddhism, Zen, and traditional Hinduism.

      In the center of the courtyard was a large Zen garden, which was extremely out of place, as were the monks who wore blue robes instead of the normal saffron or orange of Thai buddhists. The blue robed monks were practicing some kind of martial art that looked a bit like Tai Chi.

      [Theology use by Doc Orange to pick up on the oddness of the monastery's decoration.]

      Eventually, one of the blue robed monks came up to meet them. "Welcome," he said.

      "We're Canadians," said Ruby. "We like seeing the local architecture, culture..."

      "This is a place of worship, however."

      "Yes, but we are seekers of knowledge."

      "As was Buddha. What are you interested in learning."

      "I am a practitioner of karate. I would like to study your fighting style."

      "You understand for us there is no difference between the practice of Buddhism and the practice of martial arts? It requires purification and dedication."

      "Can we speak with someone to learn more?"

      "I'd like to learn too," said Dr. Orange. "I want to know how Tai Chi made its way down here."

      "It's not exactly Tai Chi, nor is it exactly gongfu," said the monk. "Our abbot developed the style after many years of study and training. We also incorporate muy thai, of course."

      "This should all be meditation, not fighting," muttered Dr. Orange under his breath. Out loud he said, "I'd like to meet the abbot."

      "Well, you are unclean foreigners, if you'll excuse the expression. I don't speak English very well," said the monk.

      "Oh, but we'd love any chance we could have to learn more," said Ruby winningly.

      [Flattery spend by RP. I asked for an Interpersonal spend here, although listening to it now...well, I'm not sure meeting the abbot is a Core Clue, and this is certainly an easier way.]

      "Very well, I will take you to him."

      They followed the monk through a long colonnade and into a pleasant garden in a courtyard. "Abbot Udom will see you know," said the monk, gesturing them into the garden.

      They pushed into the courtyard and suddenly all stopped still. Sitting cross-legged on the ground in front of them was a wiry middle-aged man, who carried with him that air of steely grace Jimmy had seen only in the greatest fighters. But that was not what made them freeze.

      An enormous tiger was lying next to him, its head on his lap.

      "You are my new Canadian disciples?" the man said in English. "I am Thawi Udom. It is somewhat unusual that people of your persuasion should find us. How did you discover this monastery?"

      "We've been visiting several monasteries, actually," said Ruby. She rattled off the list of obscure monasteries she had paid a local guide to tell her about.

      [Preparedness spend by RP to have this knowledge.]

      "At the Noble Pali monastery we pursue a new line of Buddhist thought. For many years I served in various mercenary groups, including the Foreign Legion. I fought many small wars, but then I had a revelation: I should live in peace. So now I bring the discipline of the fighting arts, and the many different religions I took inspiration from."

      [I based a bit of Udom's story on the biography of Morihei Uesheiba.]

      "We have come to celebrate the rituals of old," said Jimmy.

      "All three of you?"

      "I have," said Jimmy.

      "Come to the side gate this evening," said Udom, "and we will conduct you to the rites. We will accommodate those who wish to watch."
      \n

      \nEpisode IX: Blue Monk (Part 6)

      Around mid-morning Millicent and Betty saw Lowman stride merrily out of his house, a basket over one arm. The same basket, Millicent noticed, that they had found all the money in.

      Millicent fell into her shadowing routine, following Lowman to a government office of some kind. He went inside for a short period and then returned--without the basket. She kept on his tail as he entered a seedier part of town.

      Lowman stopped at a noodle stand to talk to a Thai man who was sitting there. Lowman talked to him for a while, his face always pleasant and open. But by the end of the conversation, the other man was shaking and seemed to be pleading for something. Lowman slapped him on his back and left the noodle stand.

      After a while Lowman stopped at a cafe and met with several white people. Millicent crept up close to them so that she could make out what they said. They were having a low conversation in French.

      "How could you lose them in the marketplace," Lowman was saying. "I thought I trained you better than that."

      "We're sorry, sir, but they proved remarkably effective at slipping away."

      "Make another mistake like that," said Lowman, "and I will report you to your supervisors. And I think we both know what will happen then."

      "Yes sir. We've already found their hotel."

      "Good. Watch them. I need to check in with Udom."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Betty gave Jimmy and company the news that their hotel had been burned. Again.

      "Perhaps Lily could help us," said Geronimo.

      "Sure," she said when they asked. "I have some people who owe me favors."

      "Are they trustworthy?" asked Jimmy.

      "No, but they're not going to rat on you to any organized crime people. Not after you pay the cover, at least."

      "They'll probably rifle through our stuff," mused Ruby.

      "We're used to that!" said Millicent.

      "Your stuff, maybe," said Lily to Ruby. "Her stuff, probably not. Sorry. And they'll probably want pictures of your bodyguard there."

      "Fragrant Honey Shop," mused Jimmy. "We've heard that before."

      "That bum!" said Ruby. "The one who broke into my house! He said to go there for the nectar...and you had to say something..."

      "Let me check my notes," said Millicent. "It was, 'I have come for the exhibition.' That got you in to watch the fights. But...wait. This SS wrote Trammel that if you wanted to fight, you said 'I have come to join the circle of excess.'"

      "Neither of those match what Lowman told us," said Jimmy. "I'm willing to bet that what he told us to say was something like 'Kill these interlopers.'"

      [I walked a tightrope on this one--I didn't want to overrule the spend, so I made it clear that Lowman hadn't ratted the PCs out to the cult; but he did give them the code message meaning to not trust the speaker.]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Millicent and Dr. Orange went out in search of the man Lowman had talked to at the noodle shop. Some asking around finally got them a name, Siripong, and a location, which was a dive bar.

      "Great, more white people," he said when they sat next to him at the bar. "You going to ruin my day too?"

      "We just want to find out how the other white guy ruined your day," said Millicent.

      "I don't have any pretensions. I don't pretend to be a nice guy. Maybe you heard there's an underground fighting circuit? I was thinking, they got their thing in their territory, so I could start my own in mine. But Waen came by and he told me that if I didn't stop he'd send some guys over who knew how to torture. The words castration and flaying worked their way into the conversation. He's pretty creepy, he has a bunch of Europeans who work for him. He's mixed up with Thawi at the temple...but I think he works for someone else higher up. But anyone who tries to find out who that is...ends up dead."
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \nEpisode IX: Blue Monk (Part 7)

      They evolved a plan to go to the fights, but as observers. It was pointed out that four of them could be recognized by the people at the Temple.

      "I know disguises," said Jimmy. "I can do your makeup."

      "Oh bitch, it's on," said Lily.

      "You can help me pick out an outfit!" said Millicent to her.

      "Thank you, Buddha! About time."

      Pretty soon they were all in costume. Jimmy was now wearing a beard, with hair graying at the temples, and an expat's immaculate white suit. Geronimo looked like a Basque sailor. Ruby was wearing a jet black wig and a decadent evening gown; she was made up to look older and uglier than she was. Dr. Orange was in a clean white jacket, the perfect valet to Ruby and Jimmy. And Millicent...Millicent...she looked like...

      "A prostitute," said Lily. "Trust me, it's the best disguise, you can be Geronimo's pickup. Plus you look like Veronica Lake in this wig! If you squint. And were nearsighted."

      "James," said Ruby, "when we have a chance, I want to talk to you about Lily. Because honey, I want details."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      They went back to the Noble Pali Monastery, going in through the main gate, tickets in hand. The zen garden in the middle of the central courtyard had been cleared, with a wooden paling fence erected around it, and temporary risers rigged up on all sides.

      The crowd was mostly Siamese, with some Chinese and even a few Japanese there; some of the latter two groups were in uniform. There were clumps of Europeans in some of the more elaborate boxes. Dr. Orange recognized a few of them as quite clearly German embassy staff--and by embassy staff, we mean spies, of course.

      [Bureaucracy spend by OP, followed by a Cop Talk spend to let him recognize the actual spy.]

      "That guy, I've heard about him in the underground--Hugo J\xfcrgens. A real Nazi for sure," he told the others, as the first fighters were led into the arena.

      [Of course at this point OP started playing the Mortal Combat theme on his phone.]

      Sixty-six seconds later, the fight was over--one of the combatants had pulled the arm out of a socket from his opponent, and then used the severed limb to beat the third fighter to death.

      The next fight had a Roman theme--two teams of five armed with tridents and nets murdered each other in a gruesome free-for-all.

      [Mostly a 2 point Stability loss; I knocked off a point for Geronimo (soldier) and Ruby (Adventure drive).]

      Geronimo and Millicent, down with the groundlings, decided to try and sneak off into the rest of the monastery. Up in the boxes, Ruby and Jimmy tried to keep from throwing up; Dr. Orange dropped out to talk to the "other" servants.

      "Wot terrible form," said a Cockney he met outside a box with a few Englishmen inside. "'Enry's me name."

      "How often do you come to these things?" said Dr. Orange.

      "Every other week or so. You get used to it--oh, look at that! Poor blighter, I liked 'im. There's a lay order 'ere, some of the foreign bigshots belong to; they don't fight or nothin', just get in the inner circle. Lately there's been more foreign blokes 'anging a round, actually--Germans, Russians, even some Yanks and English. They talk with Udom a lot."

      [JP: Militarization of the Mythos!]

      "Do you know what they use to make them fight like that?"

      "Nah, don't know where it comes from. I don't think Udom is even in charge of it. Doesn't strike me as that educated a bloke--'ardly Oxford material."

      "Have you seen him talking to anyone?"

      [Me: I don't know, woi don't you make a spend from one of yer pools?

      This turned out to be a Flattery spend by the doc; solidarity of the working class and all that.]

      "Well, I 'ave seen this one lady about on occasion, Siamese lady. Name of Savitree, I think. She seemed pretty 'igh up. One of 'em emancipated ladies, capable of running an organization for 'er 'usband. Oh, you stupid blighter, watch the bloody trident! They always forget the trident."
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \nEpisode IX: Blue Monk (Part 7)

      Geronimo and Millicent mingled through the crowd and made a dash for what looked like the dormitory of the monastery. They found a room with little partitions set against the wall to form cells of a kind. They were floored with woven mats, and had sleeping blocks instead of beds. A few were occupied by blue robed monks in lotus position, deep in meditation.

      Further down they began to hear the sound of low voices, interspersed with the sound of flesh being struck. Peeking around the corner they saw several people in blue robes sitting in meditation postures, being struck by other men--with fists, with clubs, with whips.

      They scurried past that area and headed down another corridor. At the end was a room that was obviously Udom's office, and just as obviously not the office of a Buddhist monk; it was well-appointed, with teak furniture and silk wall hangings. There were pictures of Udom from his mercenary and French Foreign Legion days. In the desk they found letters and telegrams from SS, most referring to the testing of new formulas that were being sent to the monastery, or requesting a higher rate of "production" so that something could be used in tests. A man named Pramoj was referred to several times.

      "Look at all these letters from embassies," said Millicent. She wrote down the countries that had corresponded with Udom.

      "This is an invitation," said Geronimo, waving a piece of paper. "To some meeting on 'the island.' What could that mean?"

      They left the office and followed the sketch map Millicent had made of the monastery based on the exterior layout. At one point they heard men coming up the corridor towards them and they ducked into a monk's cell. The men walked by carrying heavy buckets. "It's made so much tonight," one groaned. "Get Pramoj to clean up."

      [GP and MP had a 3 point "General Stuff About the Monastery Pool" they used to find Udom's office, and Millicent's map was a 3-point Preparedness spend.]

      A man in a ragged French Foreign Legion uniform came out in response to their calls. He was carrying a mop and wore a surgical mask over his face.

      "He was in one of the pictures in Udom's office!" said Millicent. "Let's follow him."\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "Isn't that Lowman?" said Ruby. "Over there, with the Germans and Udom."

      "Why is he hanging out with them?" said Jimmy.

      "I don't know, but one of the Embassy guys just passed him a folder. Come on, Jimmy. I need to find the bathroom."

      Taking Jimmy's arm, Ruby staggered over to the German box. Lowman intercepted them. "Pardon me, ma'am, but this is a private box."

      Ruby gagged and pressed her hands over her mouth.

      "Oh, I see," said Lowman quickly. "There's a bucket over by the stands. It's not quite dignified, but this sort of thing happens a lot here."

      Meanwhile the very Prussian-looking man Dr. Orange had told them was named J\xfcrgens drew himself up with affronted, barely-controlled rage. "I am sorry, edle Frau, but this is not a box for civilians such as yourself."

      "Hey, that's my wife!" said Jimmy, blocking J\xfcrgens' view. "She insisted we come, but she can't take it. Lay off her!" He took a step back, bumping into Lowman, who stumbled into Ruby, dropping his folder.

      Ruby swept it up off the floor, slipping some papers out as she did. She passed it back to Lowman without a word, and then threw up.

      "Verdamnte Amerikanerin!" shouted J\xfcrgens.


      [Me: I don't really need to know why Ruby can throw up at will, right?

      It was a Filch roll by Ruby to get the papers, set up in the fiction by Jimmy's bump and grind with Lowman.]
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \nEpisode IX: Blue Monk (Part 8)

      Geronimo and Millicent followed the man in the mask down the corridor. He disappeared through an open doorway into a larger room.

      "Is he talking to someone in there?" said Millicent.

      "He's talking, but I don't think to a person," said Geronimo.

      From the room they heard the masked man ask, "But what is the difference between your production at different times?"

      "Sacrifice helps," said a deep bass voice.

      "You are a liar," said the masked man in reply. "It has nothing to do with that."

      In reply, the deep voice only laughed, a horrible grating noise like boulders tumbling down a mountain. Millicent and Geronimo sped back up the corridor to rejoin their friends.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      The place that Lily had found for them was a modest boarding house mostly occupied by drag queens. While the others set up their room, Dr. Orange went over the papers Ruby had lifted from the Germans.

      Most of them were from the Sicherheitsdienst, and seemed to be profiles of some kind. On one page he found a photograph of himself. Wanted for return to Germany. High-value target, the notation said. There were also files on Ruby ("Well, I had a lot of ex-boyfriends, I guess one of them was bound to be a Nazi," she said), and a rather extensive file on Jimmy. The notes on him boiled down to trouble-maker who pokes his nose into too many things--terminate if possible.

      There were also orders to the local agents working for the Germans to keep all of them under surveillance. There was an entry in the file that the SD had received a report on them from an agent codenamed Brille.

      "That means glasses in German," said Dr. Orange.

      "Lowman," muttered Jimmy.

      "Why would whoever is in charge of the Nectar here try and reach out to other countries?" said Millicent. "And why would they want it? It's just trouble."

      "You could put it in a bomb," mused Ruby. "Drop it on the other soldiers and attack during the confusion."

      [That was one I didn't think of.]

      "Don't forget that Brooks had some way to use it for mind-control," said Jimmy. "The local stuff doesn't seem to work like that...but they're experimenting."

      "How can there always be a fifteen-minute wait for the bathroom?" said Geronimo, looking down the hall.

      "It's just like school," said Millicent.

      "Less bitchy, more mascara," said Janet.\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      Millicent set out to find this mysterious "Savitree" who she thought was the "SS" from Brooks' and Trammel's correspondence. Fortunately most Siamese indexes used the first name to organize information.

      While there were several candidates she finally settled on one. "Dr. Savitree Sirhan," she told the others. "MD, PhD in biochemistry. She was educated in Zurich, comes from a Chinese-Siamese family, and is interested in biological experimentation."

      "Can we just kill her?" wondered Dr. Orange.

      "I think I found this Pramoj guy too," she continued. "Or at least his grandfather, who fought in Indochina. But his grandson was also in the Foreign Legion, although he didn't serve on the Western Front like Udom."

      "Wait, what?" said Jimmy.

      "Udom was part of a FFL battalion sent to France. I think he mostly did labor, but he was there."

      "What about Lowman?"

      "He has a nice long paper trail...but not all the details hold up, and I can't find confirmation for some of the things."

      "Count on it," said Dr. Orange, "he's a spy. I can catch the whiff of secret police from here."

      "There's one more thing," said Millicent in the miserable tone that usually preceded her revelations. "I was doing some research on the monastery...but when I was reading a book on local little-known temples, I found Ramon Echevarria's name stamped on the check-out card, from 1922."

      [Two Library Use spends by MP.]

      "What was it about?" said Jimmy.

      "Among other things, something called the Shrine of the White Buddha. I don't know what that is, but it doesn't seem very well-known."

      She flipped open the book to some photographs of the temple. Like most Siamese temples, it was based on the Indian style, with the tall conical representation of Mt. Meru in the center. Like many Siamese temples, it was cruciform in shape.

      "Why does that thing keep reminding me of a European church?" said Ruby.

      "It's very subtle, but one arm of the temple is longer than the other," said Dr. Orange. "Maybe that's it...but that's strange. On the other hand, it's pretty much assumed that the Buddhists influenced the Gnostics...maybe somebody repaid the favor."

      \n Actually, what I remembered saying was that Millicent placed herself completely in Lily's hands. But, the Veronica Lake bit was great.

      This section was odd to play because I didn't want to metagame. A lot of the other chapters, it was very clear that you'd changed enough I didn't have to worry, but the whole business with Udom's colleague was a tricky line to walk.

      \n Yeah, that scene went on a while although I don't know why I didn't use the verbatim line...sometimes I adjust stuff for flow. Also I tend to transcribe with only one cup of coffee in me

      I also cut the part where Lily tried to teach Millicent the price schedule of a European prostitute...

      \n
      \nEpisode IX: Blue Monk (Part 9)

      The shrine seemed too good a lead to pass up, so the next day they arrived in the out-of-the way section of the Old City that it was located in. When they showed up, they found a man in saffron robes sweeping the front stairs.

      "Welcome," he said. "We so rarely get Europeans here. I am Phajol Khadpol."

      "Why is it called the shrine of the White Buddha?" asked Millicent.

      "It is descriptive; the interior is finished in white stone."

      Jimmy narrowed his eyes. Phajol was dissembling about something, but was it because he couldn't share the teachings of his temple to Europeans, or a more profound secret.

      Inside the shrine proved to indeed be made of white stone. The walls were covered with bas-reliefs of Buddha's Enlightenment, the churning of the Sea of Milk, and scenes from the Ramayana. But things seemed to be off somehow...a few of the carvings seemed to almost appear to be based on European art of the 11th century.

      [RP made an Art History spend.]

      There was a rather tall and muscular white man with a shaved head and wearing saffron robes cleaning the floors. He regarded them with suspicion, but otherwise left them alone. Jimmy started to pace around, muttering to himself, and finally rejoined the rest of the group.

      "Remember how the outside had one longer arm than the others? Inside they're all the same length...I think there's some kind of secret room here," he told them.

      "I'll distract him," said Ruby. "Millicent, I'll need you to translate into Siamese."

      "Ce n'est pas necessaire," the big man told them.

      "He speaks French," said Millicent.

      "How fascinating," said Ruby. She pointed at one wall. "Could you tell me about what that means?"

      "I am not a priest...I fought in the Indochinese wars but now I am a monk..."

      "Oh, but I'm sure you know something..."

      [I think in-session this was spun as Reassurance, but it's clearly Flattery.]

      While Ruby kept him distracted, Jimmy and Geronimo dashed for the arm that was suspiciously short. In one corner they found a small doorway with a curtain draped in front of it.

      [Architecture use by JP, and accompanying Stealth roll with Geronimo piggybacking and contributing a point, which was good because JP rolled poorly.]

      The room they found looked like it had been built by Siamese artists, but the style was distinctly western European, as was the enormous cross carved into one wall. Under it was an inscription:

      Pauperes commilitones Christi Templique Salomonici


      "The Templars," said Jimmy in a strangely high-pitched voice. He began to read more of the Latin inscriptions.


      "I thought you didn't speak Latin," said Geronimo.

      "I don't," said Jimmy. "But Millicent does..."

      [Hey, someone used their Gol-Goroth cherry! JP made a Stability spend to pick up a point of Latin.]

      The art and the inscriptions related a history of the appearance of giant Mouths in the world, and the growth of a cult centered around combating them.

      The very first mouth, as near as they could figure out, seemed to have appeared in Ethiopia. Other mouths spread out across and around the Arabian Sea, crossing into Into India. For some reason, they seemed to have been driven out of India (Geronimo, remember his history reading, thought it might have occurred during the suppression of Buddhism in India.) Eventually the cult made its way to Siam.

      Then the story got really weird. A trio of Frankish knights, come east for the Crusades, kept going east. Somewhere in the Himalayas, they found a thing described as a "Yawning Chasm". After this encounter, they journeyed still further on, eventually reaching Siam. Two of them stayed, having joined with the local groups, but the third returned to Europe, where he seemed to have been important either in founding the Templars or the groups associated with the birth of the order. Meanwhile, it seemed that the First Mouth was destroyed around the birth of Christ.

      "What mountain did they climb?" Geronimo asked Jimmy.

      "Somebody chiseled it out...recently. Maybe fifteen years ago. My money is on Ramon." He took out a small camera and began to take photographs of the inscriptions.

      [While I had planned this Templar revelation--don't worry folks, this isn't in the actual book; this is all me--in the same episode as they found the Nazi connection (also all me), but what the heck.

      As RP said, "Now I'm officially in a Pulp game."

      As it turns out, there's just a sliver of plausibility here; the Gnostics really were influenced by Buddhism, the Templars have long been suspected of having included Gnostic elements into their rites, and the communication across the Indian Ocean and Arabian Sea was a lot more common than is commonly understood. So the idea of an anti-Liar cult spreading among the Buddhist (and Jewish! and ultimately Christian!) communities of southern India, which were spread in a diaspora into southeast Asia.]\n

      \n

      \n

      \n

      "Thank you," said Millicent to the big man. She could see Jimmy and Geronimo sneaking back into the room. "Are there any other shrines nearby we should visit? We're trying to see as many of them as we can."

      "I suppose over towards the river you can find some," said the big man.

      "Thank you," she said. They all streamed out of temple and stood in the muggy sunlight. Above the monsoon clouds were already beginning to sweep in from the sea.

      "Templars!" they kept repeating to themselves.

    Eternal Lies: Masks of the Liar [Trail of Cthulhu]

      \n Yeah, by "short break" I obviously meant "almost a gosh-darn month." My apologies; I got caught up in a bunch of things, including the Mets losing the Series and the prep for another "season" of my Whitechapel game. But I finally managed to get the writeup for Episode X finished, I hope it will be worth the wait.

      In this chapter, I get to go all Bond villain for the first (but not last!) time in the campaign...and Jimmy went to a very, very dark place.

      \nEpisode X: Ruby, My Dear (Part 1)

      Dr. Orange, having decided that avoiding deportation to Germany was the better part of valor, left to meet Dr. Born in Paris. The rest of them tried to decide which path to follow to untangle this knot of troubles they found themselves bound in.

      They tried to formulate a plan to get back into the monastery and find Pramoj, going over and over different iterations while drinking watered down alcohol at Lily's bar. They were close to finding a plan when a couple of tough looking Siamese men came in.

      "Those don't look like Lily's crowd," said Jimmy. They got up as inconspicuously as possible and went into the kitchen, hoping to warn Lily. But before they could reach the back door, it was kicked in and a couple of Siamese street muscle and a European man pushed their way inside.

      Millicent shoved Ruby and Geronimo behind a counter, and then she and Jimmy tried to fade into a corner. From the main room there was the sound of a burst of automatic fire, followed by the sound of someone getting slapped, hard. They heard Lily scream.

      "That was a German gun," said Jimmy to Millicent. They could hear someone shouting in German-accented Siamese, "Tell me where they are!" The sound of breaking glass came from the other room.

      Jimmy's face grew grim. He gathered himself and dashed for the back door. One of the thugs fired off a burst behind him, but he was too quick and managed to dash up the alleyway. He doubled back around the front of the bar and kicked in the front door.

      [Athletics roll for Jimmy to get out the door, made fictively possible by the element of surprise.]

      Two submachine guns were leveled at him by Siamese thugs. A German man had his Luger to Lily's head. "Mr. Wright," he said. "So nice of you to join us."

      "You think I would run in here without a plan? You think I don't have something set up? You should know by now what happens to people who hurt my friends," said Jimmy.

      [Intimidate spend by JP to keep the Germans from shooting anyone.]

      "H\xe4nde hoch," said the German. He barked something to the thugs. They relieved Jimmy of his pistol, and then shoved him into the street with the barrels of their guns.



      Millicent dashed through a market square and into a dilapidated teahouse. "There's trouble at Lily's," she said breathlessly in Siamese. "Germans are breaking the place apart."

      From behind a table, the man she had been told was the one to whom Lily paid protection money yawned. "I don't get paid to fight Germans," he said. "I get paid to keep the police from shutting down that [slur]'s place."

      [Oral History spend to find this guy.]

      "You're going to let some Germans come in and push you around on your turf? And look weak in front of everyone?"

      [RP: You're the mob! Have some self-respect!

      Intimidate spend, creatively, by MP.]

      "All right, all right," the gangster sighed. He picked up a club and nodded at two of his soldiers.

      "They have guns," said Millicent.

      The gangster grabbed a shotgun.



      When they arrived in front of Lily's, Millicent and the gangsters could see two thugs trying to shove Jimmy into a car.

      "Ooo boy," muttered one of the gangsters.

      Jimmy, sensing his chance, suddenly burst forward, slipped across the back seat of the car, and then out the other side.

      "Halt!" shouted the German. One of the thugs raised his gun, but then glanced back at the German, unsure if even the Nazis wanted him to open up on a crowded square.

      "You two get him!" shouted the German as he waved them towards Jimmy. "You two get that Amerikanerin!"



      Jimmy dashed through another crowded market square. People with baskets of fish and rolls of silk crowded through the square, past the vendors barking their wares aggressively. As he ran, he nearly plowed into a man in a beat up fedora and weathered leather jacket.

      "Jimmy?" said the man, incredulously.

      "Indy?"

      "No time!" they chorused together and ran off in opposite directions. Jimmy began to scale a pile of crates leaning against one building.
