      \n Of course, the Betty scene meant so much more to you guys -- it's the sort of thing that you have to have been through the previous campaign to truly appreciate. I, naturally, glomed onto the Millicent/Mirabelle scene. I think Millicent fell in love with her sister after watching her punch out an invisible monster.

      The scene where they didn't combine read better than it played, as you filled in a lot. I was confused, having forgotten for the moment that Millicent had two bodies, even if one technically wasn't real. So, I thought the question about her combining with Mirabelle was about whether she'd live at the cost of her sister's life. Getting to live with a sister is wonderfully complicated. (I can see her explaining, "Yes, my sister is a sociopath. But, she tries to be polite. It's really very nice of her.")

      I'm curious what scene Dr. Orange's player glomed on to the most. The one I am fondest of with him was from the Fiasco session, where Millicent asked him if all the gobbledygook in the shooting script had any resemblance whatsoever to actual science, and he said, "Of course not! But let's pretend."

      I seem to recall there being at least one casualty due to the paradox we'd wracked up? Or was the Geronimo, who got to undo it? As I recall, he's technically heartless? Or is there some device that substitutes?

      And Millicent still doesn't get that she's not the daughter of Vanessa and Jack. I mean, she understands that there's some god somewhere in the mix, because everyone told her so and the evidence indicates it's true, but she's also been told gods don't procreate the way humans do. She still thinks she and Vanessa are basically normal. I mean, okay, she's not normal, and not normally-real, but I think she's decided the chosen one, whatever that means, was really always her sister. Who now has her necklace. And apart from those two and the other PCs, I think the person she's fondest of in the campaign is Lily from Bangkok. If things had gone differently, I could have seen her deciding to vanish in that city.

      Of course, the Betty scene meant so much more to you guys -- it's the sort of thing that you have to have been through the previous campaign to truly appreciate.       \nI...suppose? I mean, yes in terms of Jimmy's arc from lovable schlubb to big damn hero to broken man who sacrificed it all to save the world.

      But I think I established Betty well enough that there was some genuine loss.\n

      The scene where they didn't combine read better than it played, as you filled in a lot. I was confused, having forgotten for the moment that Millicent had two bodies, even if one technically wasn't real. So, I thought the question about her combining with Mirabelle was about whether she'd live at the cost of her sister's life. Getting to live with a sister is wonderfully complicated. (I can see her explaining, "Yes, my sister is a sociopath. But, she tries to be polite. It's really very nice of her.")
      \nWhen I do the writeups, since the primary place they get published is here, I assume my reader wasn't actually there

      So I do tend to smooth out things that sometimes took a long time in play to explain; like the consequences of combining/not combining. (I always saw it as possible that Millicent would survive in her "dreamform"...)
      \n


      I'm curious what scene Dr. Orange's player glomed on to the most. The one I am fondest of with him was from the Fiasco session, where Millicent asked him if all the gobbledygook in the shooting script had any resemblance whatsoever to actual science, and he said, "Of course not! But let's pretend."
      \nNo idea. I didn't always have the strongest read on OP.

      \n

      I seem to recall there being at least one casualty due to the paradox we'd wracked up? Or was the Geronimo, who got to undo it? As I recall, he's technically heartless? Or is there some device that substitutes?

      \nYeah, the paradox points accumulated required that "A loved one dies." So we went with Geronimo. In play I indicated he no longer had a heart, but in thinking it over I think the deathlessness works better the way it did in "Torchwood: Miracle Day" where you just don't die, allowing wounds that would normally be fatal to heal...if slowly. N never promised Geronimo a pain free life...
      \n

      And Millicent still doesn't get that she's not the daughter of Vanessa and Jack. I mean, she understands that there's some god somewhere in the mix, because everyone told her so and the evidence indicates it's true, but she's also been told gods don't procreate the way humans do. She still thinks she and Vanessa are basically normal. I mean, okay, she's not normal, and not normally-real, but I think she's decided the chosen one, whatever that means, was really always her sister. Who now has her necklace. And apart from those two and the other PCs, I think the person she's fondest of in the campaign is Lily from Bangkok. If things had gone differently, I could have seen her deciding to vanish in that city.
      \nI will never understand why JP brought back that one-note NPC from the first campaign but I am quite glad about how that worked out

      As for the rest...a certain unwillingness to see what was right in front of her face was one of Millicent's most charming features...and survival mechanisms, come to think of it.

      \n Wonderful to see you here! Finishing these is always bittersweet for me as well, and not just because I beat myself up about how much better the finales could have been.

      I am looking forward to the third leg in the tale of Jimmy: the redemption arc, complete with the opportunity to mentor the next generation of Fitzgibbonses.

      \n

      Agreed. I try to make my NPC's as memorable and usually fail miserably. So yeah, you're pretty fantastic at it. Part of me is glad the write up is done, so i don't have to refresh the page ten times a day but another is also sad since this is what i read on the bus. hah.
      \nWell, I haven't seen your NPCs (hint, hint.)

      I haven't given a ton of thought to my process with NPCs, although I guess I have one. Sometimes, casting choices help: deciding to use James Mason for Montgomery Donovan made it easier for me to find a nice supervillain rhythm. Sometimes just the accent can help: knowing that Betty was about 18 and "toiked loik dis" let me lock her into the brassy would-be action hero she became.

      Betty also points at something: she had a motivation, to become an investigator. So when in doubt, I could hit that as an approach to her scenes. When she and Millicent began to interact, I saw right away I could have fun by contrasting Millicent's relative straight-lacedness with a party girl attitude for Betty.

      I guess I generally try to find a hook to hang the NPCs on, then come up with a speech pattern and accent, and go to town. For example, Sir Godfrey was easy for me to play after I came up with the concept--"ruthless Templar not afraid of modern tech"--and his rather gruff but elevated tone and accent. (There were some ideas that lurked in the back of my mind with Godfrey--I had planned a reveal where it was clear that as a Templar he was in fact in favor of Echevarria's plan to destroy the universe--but I didn't get a chance to bring that out; so it's probably no longer true in-universe.)

      Ultimately, there's a give and take. I wanted to make Betty someone Jimmy wanted to protect, but it might not have gone there. (I had my suspicions that it would work based on how you played Jimmy; but I was willing to abandon the idea if it wasn't going anywhere.)
      \n

      Will you start a new thread for the new campaign? That is my wish. Because I only started reading this in the last few pages. Trix, it's sometimes a bit hard for me to follow along with what's happening since somethings are a bit abbreviated, but that's OK. I know I can ask.
      \nI was of a couple of minds about that. On the one hand, I was viewing the project as potentially something I might pitch around to publish. The enormous amount of work that entails has me backing off of it somewhat. And on the other, I'm not sure what readership (if any) I have here...

      But on the gripping hand, it would be hard for me to turn down such a lovely request.

      My main issues right now for both the new campaign and the scenario I need to have done (and tested!) before Dexcon is figuring out a quicker way to organize my prep than a full blown writeup.

      And of course the elephant in the room: the two Cthulhu campaigns I've done so far were riffs on existing work; I might have changed them practically out of all recognition, but I still had the text to lean on and react to. What will happen when I lose that prop?

      \n I hear you about not having a prop to lean on. Dracula Dossier is an interesting, and often bumpy middle, middle road -- but easier, I suspect, than Armitage Files, because we do have the novel and over a century of reaction to it to lean on.

      When I did CthulhuPunk and Kerberos Fate, I used published scenarios from elsewhere (Cubicle 7's Victoriana saved my butt several times with Kerberos!), and take plots from movies, manga, whatever. But neither of these is the tight focus I think you'll be going for.

      \n Yeah, I've been pondering if there's any way to hack some texts to use a skeleton but I think in the end that won't help much--besides, I'm already in love with the locations I chose and those would require a lot adaptation. It's not like in Masks where I was able to swap Paris for London; I know Paris pretty well so I could make it work.

      OTOH, I swapped Zanzibar for Kenya. But I don't know much about either of those places, so it balanced?
